font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.24\u2014 tasya heturavidya</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Lack of spiritual\nunderstanding (avidya ) is the cause of the false identification of the seer\nwith the seen. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avidya and maya are the\nsame, but avidya is individual and maya is cosmic.&nbsp; &nbsp;Maya\nis only an instrument that Brahman uses to project the universe. &nbsp;Through maya Brahman projects Himself as many.&nbsp; Amalgamating of prakrti with purusa can\neither lead to emancipation or block one's progress by enmeshing one within\ndesires and emotions.&nbsp; Avidya, ignorance\nor lack of awareness, is at the root of the confusion that fetches suffering to\none as well as pleasure. Vidya (discriminative knowledge) destructs ignorance,\nbecause a fire will burn only as long as fuel lasts. &nbsp;When discernment relegates doubt, pure\nunderstanding begins the process of disownment and detachment which releases\none from the pinions of possessing and being possessed.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avidya is the first of\nthe 5 kleshas (which means coloring or veil), it is the first veil that covers\nthe non-dual formless Consciousness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\n5 kleshas are avidya, asmita, raga, dvesha, abhinivesha.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avidya appears in four stages: 1) dormant or\ninactive, 2) attenuated or weakened, 3) interrupted or separated from\ntemporarily, or 4) active and producing thoughts or actions to varying degrees.\nAvidya means without Truth or without knowledge. It is the first form of\nforgetting the spiritual Reality. It is not just a thought pattern in the\nconventional sense of a thought pattern. Rather, it is the very ground of\nlosing touch with the Reality of being the ocean of Oneness, of pure\nConsciousness. Avidya is usually translated as ignorance, which is a good word,\nso long as we keep in mind the subtlety of the meaning. Ignorance is something\nthat is removed, like removing a veil that obstruct the view. Then, with the\nignorance removed, we see knowledge or Vidya clearly. Prakriti is known as\nMaya; when impure (being mixed up with rajas and tamas) it is called Avidya.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once the basic principles of Avidya (Veiling,\nIgnorance) are understood, as well has how they progressively move awareness\noutward through Adhyasa (Projecting, Superimposition), it is easier to see the\nway in which these two are systematically reversed so as to attain the highest\ngoals of traditional Yoga. Avidya (Nescience) or Maya, is also the\nUndifferentiated. There is no Ignorance (Avidya) outside the mind. The mind\nalone is Avidya, the cause of the bondage of transmigration. When that is\ndestroyed, all else is destroyed, and when it is manifested, everything else is\nmanifested. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the rise of Vidya or\nrealization, the entire effects of Avidya, even though beginningless, are\ndestroyed together with their root \u2013 like dreams on waking up from sleep. The\nknowledge of the identity of the Jiva and Brahman entirely consumes the\nimpenetrable forest of Avidya or Nescience. For one who has realized the state\nof Oneness, there is no seed left for future transmigration\u2014seeds are fried. The\nGurus as well as the Shrutis instruct the disciple, standing aloof; while the\nman of realization crosses (Avidya) through Illumination alone, backed by the\ngrace of God. Nescience or Avidya has two functions: Avarana or the power to\nconceal and Viksepa or the power to project. You don\u2019t see the universe as it\nreally is because your perception of the universe is individual. You see things\nonly partial through a little window of your eyes. This partial knowledge (\nnarrow window bandwidth / squelched senses ) has nothing to do with the\ntotality of experience ( six blind men and the elephant ) and thus cannot be\nconsidered to be truth. The knot of ignorance and the knot of karma ( past soul\nsamskaras /impressions ) compose the nature of avidya.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jiva is endowed with\nall the same qualities as Brahman, but jiva, through its association with avidya,\nthinks itself to be limited.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">. When the\njiva, the individual soul, learns to be free from the strong clutches of\navidya, he realizes his true Self and becomes one with Brahman. You can remain\nin the bondage of avidya or you can release yourself. It is your choice. You\nare the way you are because you wanted to be this way. No one else has\ndescribed for you or made any plans for you. This is your own planning. Each\nindividual creates avidya. Thus it is your own ignorance and superimpositions\nthat are responsible for your suffering. Without eliminating attachment and\npassions, spiritual knowledge does not arise. The joys of the sensory\ngratification that one delights in are short-lived, and when the fruits of\nthese actions are exhausted, one again falls back into the cruel clutches of\navidya or ignorance. The term maya is closely related to with avidya. Maya can\nbe described as apparent reality\u2014that which does not exist though it appears to\nexist. Ma means \u201cno\u201d, ya means \u201cthat\u201d. An example of maya is a mirage in the\ndesert. Even though you think you see it, it doesn\u2019t exist. Maya can cause you\nto have an accident, but it cannot enlighten you. Maya is the reason you see\nthe one absolute truth as many. The process of unlearning, </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">is about freedom from the conditioning or\nfrom the known. Unlearning things that are no longer useful can be an extreme\nform of changing, like an almost physical casting off of inner clothing.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlearning involves a conscious individual\nconfrontation of the past with the future, involving paradigms or beliefs that\ncome from the fully formed past at odds with those that come from a future,\nstill in formation. If you need to fill up water in a bottle, the ( hot ) air\nwhich served the bottle well for long time, must be allowed to escape.\nUnlearning is about moving away from something rather than moving towards\nsomething. Unlearning is not about right or wrong. It is about being open to\nand exploring something that lies underneath the judgment, underneath the right\nand the wrong. The learning cycle, which should be a virtuous circle that\npositively feeds itself. Our habit of planning</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">in a particular way may have to worked wonderfully well in the past, but\nunknown to us, it has become a primary cause of our inability to adapt to\nchanges in our context.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even in\nmild</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">forms, these habits can become ingrained,\ncomfort zones, addictions, hiding places of denial and self-protection. Often\nour ability to see something, to appreciate its true nature, is skewed or\nhidden by the judgement we give it, the pigeon-hole we have prepared for it. .Old\ningrained habits that do not serve us take time to break and some may never be\nbroken. Behind the fears live the memories that gave rise to them . The cat who\nfell in hot water is circumspect with cold water too. We cannot disprove our\npast or invalidate our memories. We go back and work gently with what happened,\nsee the memories afresh and hopefully find the strength necessary to free\nourselves from their power with active help from yoga. It is painful to unlearn\nthose deep, hidden and sometimes painful patterns that mask and influence the\nway we do things. Added to this are soul samskaras ( phobias ) </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">picked up from past lives. Ultimately, we have\nto acknowledge that it is not our methods, strategies, tools or techniques\nwhich define the core and quality of our development practice, but\nourselves</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">our past, our present and our\nfuture, and the will we can find to face these. In Sanskrit when an \u2018A\u2019 is\nplaced in front of a word it means \u2018not\u2019 or \u2018without\u2019 that word. So \u2018A\u2019 in\nfront of vidya means not vidya. Vidya is a word used for the highest Truth,\nKnowledge, or Knowing. When one truly experiences the non-dual formless\nConsciousness, one really knows, one lives in vidya, one lives in knowing the\nAbsolute Reality. Therefore avidya is a state that means you are not living in\nvidya, the truth is forgotten, is veiled, and therefore is it a state of\nignorance of ignoring truth. To remove everything that is not vidya will bring\nthe experience of vidya. Therefore it is the avidya that we have to deal with,\nget to know and move beyond. We need to un-color this coloring in order to find\nvidya. To say that we live in ignorance doesn\u2019t mean that we are dumb or\nstupid, it is merely a realization that we are ignoring our true Self (that we\nlive unconsciously while our true nature is pure Consciousness) and that this\navidya needs to be removed. Avidya is all bad, because if the veil would be\nlifted all at once we would not be able to take it. Even our fives senses have\nnarrow bandwidths and are squelched to prevent overload and breakdown.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We dont need to see the waves going from the\nTV remote to the TV.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is so much unconscious movement\nunderneath the veil that it would flood us if it would be presented to us at\nonce, probably make us literally crazy. Therefore this veil is like a mother,\nwho lovingly hides what we cannot take until we are ready to take the\nresponsibility. When our responsibility grows we will be able to allow the\nunconscious movements to come forward and not get sucked into them. We would be\nable to know that these movements are not who we are and will be able to stay\nnon-attached to them. Therefore, it appears as if avidya and vairagya are\ndancing to together. In the beginning avidya has the lead, lovingly keeps us\nprotected as a mother, but slowly with practice vairagya will take over this\ndance until the whole veil can be lifted and the Self rests it its own nature. avidya\nis used when we speak of individual ignorance, and the word maya is used when\nwe speak of cosmic illusion. The word maya is used is regard to Brahman, when\nthe Absolute Reality seems to play as maya. &nbsp; Mind you, these explanations are\nNOT for the shallow minded.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">IX: They enter into\nblind darkness who worship Avidya (ignorance and delusion); they fall, as it\nwere, into greater darkness who worship Vidya (knowledge).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">X :By Vidya one end is\nattained; by Avidya, another. Thus we have heard from the wise men who taught\nthis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">XI: He who knows at the\nsame time both Vidya and Avidya, crosses over death by Avidya and attains\nimmortality through Vidya. Those who follow or \u201cworship\u201d the path of\nselfishness and pleasure (Avidya), without knowing anything higher, necessarily\nfall into darkness; but those who worship or cherish Vidya (knowledge) for mere\nintellectual pride and satisfaction, fall into greater darkness, because the\nopportunity which they misuse is greater.- &nbsp;<b>Isha\nUpanishad 5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Om Purnamadah\nPurnamidam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purnat Purnamudachyate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purnasya Purnamadaya<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purnameva Vashishyate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Om shanti, shanti,\nshanti\u2014&nbsp; <b>Isha Upanishad 5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Om. That is infinite,\nthis is infinite;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">From That infinite this\ninfinite comes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">From That infinite,\nthis infinite removed or added;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Infinite remains\ninfinite.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Om. Peace! Peace!\nPeace!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The path that avidya\n(or ignorance) leads one to and the path that vidya (or knowledge) takes one\nthrough are extremely different ones and are very far from each other. O\nNaciketas! I understand that you are the one in search of knowledge since you\nare not interested in fulfilling all the worldly, material desires that I\noffered to grant you. Those desires did not move you even an inch from your\nstrong focus (of attaining the knowledge).&nbsp;\n<b>Katha Upanishad Chapter 2 Verse 4\n-5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cWhen all things that\nhave a beginning are ruled out, what remains is the truth \u2013 which is the\ncessation of avidya or ignorance. You may regard it as something or as\nno-thing: that is to be sought which is when ignorance has been dispelled. The\nsweetness one tastes is not experienced by another: listening to someone\u2019s description\nof the cessation of avidya does not give you enlightenment. In short, avidya is\nthe belief that there exists a reality which is not Brahman or cosmic\nconsciousness. When there is the certain knowledge \u2018This is indeed Brahman\u2019,\navidya ceases.\u201d <b>Yoga Vashista<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.25\u2014</span><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadabhavat sanyogabhavo\nhanan taddrisheh&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">kaivalyam</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The destruction of\nignorance through right knowledge breaks the link binding the seer to the seen.\nThis is kaivalya or emancipation.<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By the removal of\nignorance, conjunction is removed. This is the absolute freedom of the seer.This\nsutra explains the effect of breaking down the link that binds the knower to\nthe known. At this point, the seen loses its hold and influence on the seer,\nmiseries terminate and the soul is heightened to experience perfect freedom. Yoga\nis specifically designed to help one avert the sort of slips and errors in\none's conduct which store up future sorrows, and it builds up one's strength,\nvitality and valour to deal with the inevitable problems of life. One is aware\nthat one's mind turns more gladly to the world's pleasures than to the vision\nof the soul. It is a bridge between the senses and the spirit; it is a secret\nenemy, and a deceitful friend, which can change one's conduct without giving\none time to consider. Patanjali advises the sadhaka to train the mind and\nencourage discrimination, so that objects and events are seen only for what\nthey are, then they cannot gain power over one. This is exceedingly difficult,\nbut an understanding of nature will help. Humans are matter (temporarily) and\nlive surrounded by matter. Interaction with matter or nature is the condition\nof one's life. Without discrimination one cannot break free, but with\nunderstanding and practice one can use this interaction to reach highest peace\nand bliss. One should exercise discrimination and thereby realise that\nattachment to sense objects which give instant gratification is the cause of\nbondage and non-attachment to sense objects leads to liberation. So it is\nmandatory that infatuation with sense objects is renounced. One should not\ndebase oneself clinging to the lower nature like the animals. Lord Krishna in\nBhagawad Gita emphasises the changing nature of the mind. Attachment to worldly\npleasures and hedonist values locks one to samsara or the endless cycle of\nbirth and death while contrarily detachment from the infatuation of worldly\npleasures frees one from samsara.</span> 6000 years ago, in the middle of the\nbattle field of Kurukshetra , <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lord Krishna reveals the method of\nescaping perpetual incarceration in the material existence. The mind has the\npropensity to be one's dearest friend so why not utilise it to uplift oneself\nout of material darkness and into spiritual light. A controlled mind can\naccomplish so many beneficial endeavours for one's wellbeing. Whereas an\nuncontrolled mind is one's worst enemy performing base and degrading activities\nleading to destruction.When the mind is freed from attachments one becomes\nlucid and clear and the mind is like one's best benefactor. When the mind is\ndisturbed by attachments it becomes distracted and distorted and the mind\nbecomes one's worst malefactor.If one wants to experience heaven on earth, one\nhas to grasp the qualities of nature, the gunas, i.e., the polarity of rajas\nand tamos, the eternal pulse of nature between movement and stillness, and the\nhigher balancing state of sattva. Nature has degrees of subtlety. Sometimes it\nis more densely or unmistakably manifest than at others, and Patanjali analyses\nas follows. The four parts are - distinguishable (visesa), unspecified or\nuniversal (avisesa), phenomenal (lihga) and, beyond this, noumenal (alihga).\nThe five energetic qualities of nature, the elements, are, with the senses of\nperception and organs of action, distinguishable; while the five counterparts\nof the elements, sound, touch, taste, sight and smell are without specific\nsigns (alihga); so also is the ego (asmita). All these are subject to the\ngunas, which intermingle the behavioural patterns of an individual. If one\nunderstands the flow of these forces, one can reach balance, and from balance\ngo on to true freedom. If not, one is swayed from one extreme to another,\nbetween pleasure and another pain. Yoga, says Patanjali, is the way to\nharmonise oneself at every level with the natural order of the universe, from\nthe physical to the most subtle, to reach the total state of health which\nbrings stability, to cultivate the mind with real understanding, and to reach\nout ultimately to undifferentiated infinity. The seer is an absolute knower -\nawareness personified. Though pure, it becomes entangled in the illusions of\nthe mind, which are part of nature. Yet the vehicles of nature are all there to\nhelp the seer to experience serene, pristine, divine purity. Then, the elements\nof nature and their counterparts ebb and unite in the root of nature,\nmula-prakrti.Perfection is attained when the intellect becomes as pure as the\nAtman itself. When the soul realises that it is absolutely independent and it\ndoes not depend on anything else in this world, this highest knowledge,\nKaivalya, Isolation or perfect independence comes inhe soul feels that it is\never free, unchanging, immortal, beginningless, endless, infinite, beyond time,\nspace and causation, full of bliss, peace and knowledge.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nPurusha is an embodiment of intelligence. He is ever pure and eternally free. He\nis always the silent witness of the play of Prakriti. Through intellect, the\nPurusha appears as if seeing, although really he never sees or does anything. The\nqualities of intellect are superimposed on the Purusha. &nbsp;Just as the real colour of the flower appears\non the transparent crystal, so also the qualities of Buddhi appear on the\nPurusha. Hence, the Purusha appears to be happy or miserable.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nPurusha unites with the Buddhi and enjoys the different objects. This is the\ncause for human sufferings. Ignorance is the cause for this conjunction. This\nPrakriti and Purusha are united from time immemorial. If this union is\nseparated, the Purusha recognises his original, divine glory. The original\nconjunction is the union of Purusha with the Buddhi. Through Buddhi, he is\nunited with body. He mistakes this perishable body for the real Purusha.\nThrough this body, he gets united with wife, children, relatives and friends.\nThe whole Samsara has started now. Disconnect yourself from the Prakriti and\nbecome a Mukta Purusha. This is the essential teaching of Raja Yoga.<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Spiritual detachment is\nisolation from transient desires and discarding shackles binding our body and\nmind to the world. When we approach the Divine, we escape the gravitational\npull of worldly desires, and leap into an infinite dimension, free from\nmaterial cravings and illusion of self-love. He who would be serene and pure\nneeds but one thing, detachment.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">With detachment comes\nfreedom of the mind from the material world, but at the same time, attachment\nto the Divine becomes even more essential. This is not the FAKE Bhakti Yoga\nthingy where singers keep wandering around singing praises of god and doing\nnothing else. Laws of Karma rule, they is no moksha without making the karmic\nbaggage zero.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.26\u2014 vivekakhyatiraviplava\nhanopayah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The ceaseless flow of\ndiscriminative knowledge in thought, word and deed destroys ignorance, the\nsource of pain.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One must continually\nseparate truth from untruth.&nbsp;&nbsp; The means\nto liberation is uninterrupted discriminative discernment.&nbsp;&nbsp; The steady flow of deep, discriminating\nawareness unravels the avidya (illusion) and leads to the liberation of purusa.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nroot word viveka means discrimination, meaning this deeper, discriminating\nawareness (vivekakhyatih) is the kind of knowledge that is beyond the senses.\nThis knowledge is also beyond our intellect, and even our highest perception.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once\nwe lift the veil of maya, our knowledge becomes even clearer, and we experience\nkaivalya, or liberation. Un-fluctuating sound judgement with unremitting\nawareness is the essence of true knowledge, the only means to eliminate\nignorance and free the seer from the seen. It should always be kept in the\nhighest state of awareness and attentiveness, known as vivekakhyati, the crown\nof wisdom. &nbsp;The seeds of false knowledge\nneed to be burnt up through unremitting yogic practices to maintain an unbroken\nflow of discriminative intelligence. Viveka is uninterrupted discrimination.&nbsp; Adi Shankaracharya defines Viveka as\ndiscrimination; wisdom or Buddhi made active. In this seventh chapter, Sri Krishna\nemphasizes the need to translate knowledge into a living reality by practising\nit, i.e., the knowledge acquired through the higher mind has to be realized. In\nViveka Chudamani, Adi Shankaracharya &nbsp;says that foolish is the man who does not\nstrive after freedom from bondage\u2014after obtaining, at last, a human birth. &nbsp;\u201cTherefore let the wise one strive after\nFreedom, giving up all longing for sensual self-indulgence; approaching the\ngood, great Teacher (the Higher Self) with soul intent on the object of the\nteaching\u201d. (Verse 8).&nbsp; Viveka is the\ndiscrimination between the real and the unreal, the permanent and the\nnon-permanent, Atman and Anatma.&nbsp; In Kaivalyopanishad,\nBrahma tells Ashwalayana, who wanted to acquire knowledge of the ultimate\ntruth, \"By faith, devotion and meditation you can understand the ultimate\ntruth.\"&nbsp; You must first develop\nViveka or discrimination between the real and the unreal and Vairagya (dispassion)\n&nbsp;for the enjoyment of objects herein and\nhereafter/ Vairagya born of Viveka only will be of a lasting nature. Such a Vairagya\nonly will be helpful to you in your spiritual practices.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.27\u2014 &nbsp;tasya saptadhaa prantabhoomih prajna</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Through this unbroken\nflow of discriminative awareness, one gains perfect knowledge which is composed\nof seven spheres.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Patanjali,\nthe seven states of conscious awareness are - emerging consciousness (vyutthana\ncitta), restraining consciousness (nirodha cittta), sprouted or individualised\nconsciousness (nirmana cittta), tranquil consciousness (prasanta citta),\nattentive consciousness (ekagrata citta), fissured or rent consciousness\n(chidra citta) and ripe or pure consciousness (paripakva or divya citta).&nbsp; Samyama means &nbsp;integration. &nbsp;Dharana, dhyana (the seventh limb), and\nsamadhi (the eighth limb) taken together compose samyama. By the practice of\nSamyama, the Yogi gets knowledge and powers. Patanjali says that samadhi\nappears when we are able to let go of our mental machinations, samskaras (past\npsychic imprints), klesha (afflictive emotions), karma (programming), vasana\n(habitual tendencies), and similar habitual impositions of conditioning and\nconditioned belief systems, which support the citta-vrtti (spinning or\nslant/tilt of the mindfield). Since samadhi is essentially nirvikalpa (beyond\nconcepts), and since concepts are built upon words, then obviously the words\nhave to be let go. Dhyana (meditation) brings forth the dawning of an\nextraordinary transpersonal (more rarefied than the most subtle) consciousness\nwhich can not be brought about without the complete stilling (nirodha) of the\nordinary mind which is constantly being modified, colored, and disturbed\n(yogash citta-vrtti-nirodah). The profound and sacred trans-rational\n(nirvikalpa), trans-cognitive (asamprajnata) and all encompassing non-dual\ntruth of Reality-As-It-Is is self revealing once the doors of perception are\nopined -- once the practitioner gets in touch with the intrinsic light of\nwisdom within and the veil is lifted. various applications of samyama can lead\nto the siddhis (accomplishments, abilities, masteries, and powers), but they\nare not to be seen as attainments because no ego attains or possess it. &nbsp;The yogi\u2019s true insight has seven ultimate\nstages. There are seven frontiers to be integrated between the seen (prakrti)\nand the seer (purusa). They comprise - integration of the body (safira\nsamyama), the senses (indriya samyama), energy (prana samyama), mind (mano\nsamyama), intellect (buddhi samyama), consciousness (citta samyama) and soul\n(atma samyama), each realising its own individual identity. Expertise in yoga\nwill bring this sevenfold knowledge.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.28\u2014 &nbsp;yogangganushthanad ashuddhikshaye jnanadiptira\nvivekakhyateh</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">By dedicated practice\nof the various aspects of yoga, impurities are destroyed - the vision of wisdom\nradiates in glory.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali summarises\nthe effects of yoga in this one sutra. He says that by habitual and dedicated\npractice, impurities of the sadhaka's body and mind are consumed, the causes of\nadversaries removed and the crown of wisdom is acquired. This wisdom and\naccomplishment keeps the sadhaka guiltless and free of conceit. Here, instead\nof the usual word abhyasa (repeated practice), anusthana is used. It is a\nvenerable and noble word with a spiritual significance, implying practice with\ndedication or religious commitment. The former brings stability; the latter\ndevelops maturity of intelligence. Yoga can cure or diminish one's physical,\nmental, moral and spiritual woes. Perfection and success are certain only if\none practises with love and whole-hearted dedication. Upon the destruction of\nimpurities as a result of the practice of yoga, the lamp of knowledge arises.\nThis culminates in discriminative discernment. By the practice of yoga,\nimpurities are destroyed. These impurities, &nbsp;are nothing but the five kleshas \u2013 avidya\n(ignorance), asmita (egoism), raga (likes), dvesha (dislikes), and abhinivesha\n(fear of death) \u2013 discussed earlier. When impurities are removed, the light of\nfull knowledge (jnana-dipti) shines through. Starting with this sutra,\nPatanjali shifts the focus from the highly theoretical discussion to a\npractical approach for the attainment of the goals and objectives of yoga.\nBecause of the wide acceptance of these eight limbs of yoga, Patanjali\u2019s yoga\nis often referred to as \"Ashtanga Yoga\" or the \"eight limbs of\nyoga\".&nbsp; In Sutra 2.26 Patanjali\nstated that the state of \"viveka khyati\" (discriminative wisdom) is\nthe cause for the elimination of ignorance which leads to the apparent union\nbetween Purusha and Prakriti. In the current sutra, he lays out the means to\nget to that state of viveka khyati. Patanjali uses the term khyati&nbsp; to mean&nbsp;\nexpound, so clearly that no ambiguity remains.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">khyati refers to\nthe aspect of knowledge that clearly describes the defining characteristics of\nits object. By using this term,Patanjali is telling us that avidya-driven union\ncomes to an end when our knowledge regarding the union of purusha and prakriti\nis crystal clear. Merely knowing that prakriti is the material cause of the\nuniverse and purusha is pure consciousness does not free us from misery. Such\nknowledge is purely intellectual, vague, and devoid of any practical substance.\nKhyati is totally different. It sheds such a powerful light on both purusha and\nprakriti that we realize instantly what we are. In the light of khyati, we know\nourselves. We also know precisely what purusha and prakriti are, what caused\nthem to embrace each other blindly and seemingly aimlessly, and what holds them\ntogether.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At\nthe dawn of this knowledge (khyati), we regain our faith and trust in\nourselves. This gives us the strength to distinguish the real from the unreal,\nlasting happiness from short-lived pleasure, and true freedom from mere\nescape.This strength is called viveka shakti, the power of discrimination. This\nextraordinary knowledge (khyati), accompanied by the power of discrimination\n(viveka), here is termed viveka-khyati, the purest means of bringing this\navidya-driven union to an end.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali\nreminds us that this discerning knowledge (viveka-khyati) has to be strong and\nmature enough to withstand the test of time. We attain discerning knowledge\nwith the help of meditation, self-examination, self-inquiry, and divine grace.\nAfter attaining this knowledge, we must make it firm with practice. We must not\nbecome careless. We must never forget how deceptive and powerful the veils of\nmaya are; how undetectable her ways are of influencing our mind; and how\nimportant it is to safeguard and further nourish our newly discovered\ndiscerning knowledge.. Practice of these eight limbs of yoga serves as the\ncause in two categories \u2013 elimination of impurities and attainment of\ndiscriminative wisdom. Nine types of causes that are mentioned in the\nscriptures are:--Utpatti: production, Sthiti: maintenance, Abhivyakti:\nmanifestation, expression, Vik\u0101ra: transmutation, modification, Pratyaya:\ncognition, \u0100pti: attainment, Viyoga: separation, Anyatva: otherness,\ndifferentiation, Dh\u1e5bti : sustenance ..Practice of the limbs of yoga is applicable\nas a cause for viyoga (separation of impurities) and apti (attainment of\ndiscriminative wisdom).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Viveka-khyati\nis the complete opposite of avidya and is even more active.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Discerning\nknowledge destroys our unwillingness to see the truth. It provides the courage\nto see the truth and gives us the strength and insight to see our deeply rooted\nhabits (samskaras) and replace them with the samskaras of selfrealization\n(purusha-khyati/ atma-khyati).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Discerning\nknowledge metamorphoses into an intense and irresistible desire (tiara samvega)\nto see and experience the absolute independence of consciousness (kaivalyam).\nThe samskara created by this desire blocks all other desires.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It grants us\ncomplete mastery over the mind and the subtle impressions deposited in the\nmind\u2014as well as the binding and releasing forces of the mind that cause us to\nlive in the world either miserably or happily. In other words, this knowledge\ncontains an unprecedented level of revelation. When it dawns fully, the whole\nrange of truth is available in its purity and perfection<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.29\u2014 yamaniyamasanapranayamapratyaharadharanadhy\nanasamadhayo-a-shtava anggani</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Moral injunctions\n(yama), fixed observances (niyama), posture (asana), regulation of breath\n(pranayama), internalisation of the senses towards their source (pratyahara),\nconcentration (dharana), meditation (dhyana) and absorption of consciousness in\nthe self (samadhi), are the eight constituents of yoga. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This sutra sets out the\neightfold path of yoga (astahgayoga), which Patanjali continues to describe in\ndetail in the remaining sutras of sadhana pada. Restraints and observances that\nare bound by tradition and lineage follow uninterruptedly in the practice of\nyoga. Although asana, pranayama and pratyahara are separate entities, they\ndepend on one another for expressing the hidden aspects of yoga. These stages,\nwhich enable the seeker to heighten in the art of yoga, are called progressive\nsadhana. Through them one achieves a higher and even more higher state. The\nfirst five aspects of yoga are individual efforts for the evolution of the\nconsciousness, while dharana, dhyana and samadhi are the universal\nmanifestation or the natural states of yoga (yoga svaritpa). The practice of\nyoga is an art and science dedicated to creating union between body, mind and\nspirit. Its objective is to assist the practitioner in using the breath and\nbody to foster an awareness of ourselves as individualized beings intimately\nconnected to the unified whole of creation. In short it is about making balance\nand creating equanimity so as to live in peace, good health and harmony with\nthe greater whole. It is important to perform all the eight limbs successfully\nto attain the objective of yoga.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.30\u2014</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">ahinsasatyasteyabrahmacharyaparigraha\nyamah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Non-violence, truth,\nabstention from stealing, continence, and absence of greed for possessions\nbeyond one's need are the five pillars of yama. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The principle of yama\ninvolves wishing no harm in word, thought or deed; being sincere, truthful and\nhonest; not stealing or misappropriating another's wealth or possessions;\ncelibacy; and not accepting gifts or possessing only what one needs, without\nbeing avaricious. These rules and restraints are laid down clearly for one to\nlive in society while remaining a yoga practitioner. The Yamas are nonviolence,\ntruthfulness, refrainment from stealing, celibacy, and renunciation of (\nunnecessary and superfluous ) &nbsp;possessions. The first two limbs that\nPatanjali describes are the fundamental ethical precepts called yamas, and the\nniyamas. &nbsp;&nbsp;These can also be looked at as\nuniversal morality and personal observances. Yamas and niyamas are the\nsuggestions given on how we should deal with people around us and our attitude\ntoward ourselves. The attitude we have toward things and people outside\nourselves is yama, how we relate to ourselves inwardly is niyama. Both are\nmostly concerned with how we use our energy in relationship to others and to\nourselves. The yamas are broken down into five \"wise\ncharacteristics.\" Rather than a list of dos and don\u2019ts, &nbsp;they tell us that our fundamental nature is\ncompassionate, generous, honest and peaceful. Being the first limb of yoga, the\nfive yamas are the foundation of spiritual life on which the super-structure of\nsamadhi is built. Following the yamas means sticking to ideals and principles.\nIt is about development of positive traits that will transform the human nature\ninto a divine nature and annihilate cravings and negative qualities. When the\nyamas are truly practised, the heart is filled with cosmic love, goodness and\nlight. There is a deliberate order in the five yamas. Ahimsa (non-violence)\ncomes first because one must remove one\u2019s brutal nature first. One must become\nnon-violent and develop cosmic love. Only then does one become fit for the\npractice of yoga. Then comes satya or truthfulness. The whole phenomenon of\nmaya or illusion is asat or unreal and the aspirant should be aware of this\nfact. He should ever remember the truth or Brahman. Next comes asteya or\nnon-stealing. As one must develop moral consciousness, one must know right from\nwrong, righteousness from unrighteousness, and one must know that all is one.\nBrahmacharya or continence ( it has nothing to do with sex ) , which is the\nfourth yama, is a divine attribute. The aspirant is now becoming superhuman\nthrough its practice. The fifth is aparigraha, non-covetousness. The yogic\nstudent is now free from cravings, unnecessary wants, the desire to possess and\nenjoy, and his heart has expanded manifold.Yamas ( universal morality) &nbsp;are as follows:-- 1. AHIMSA\u2013 Compassion for\nall living things. Ahimsa means you also do NOT approve of a evil man\u2019s cruel\nactions of himsa and watch injustice as a coward and a impotent man\u2014this is\npart of&nbsp; ahimsa in its purest form. Ahimsa\nis not causing pain, not non-killing.. Himsa means to cause pain. Causing pain\nthrough words or thoughts can be even more harmful than killing. Ahimsa was the\nmain theme of Gandhi\u2019s non-cooperation movement in bringing freedom to India\nfrom the British. And he made sure that Jew Rotshchild robbed Bharatmata blind,\nwhile we ghumaaoed the charkha like napunksaks . Ahimsa as not injuring any\nliving creature anywhere at any time within the perimeters of&nbsp; dharma.&nbsp;\nOne must continue to perform one\u2019s dharma even though it might mean killing\n, harmful enemies. Yogis should abstain from eating meat which involves\nnourishing one\u2019s body by eating the flesh of other living beings.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Being\na vegetarian is an absolute requirement for an aspiring yogi. Ahimsa also\nencompasses giving up thoughts of malice and hatred as these produce tendency\nto hurt others through words or actions. The word ahimsa literally mean not to\ninjure or show cruelty to any creature or any person in any way whatsoever.\nAhimsa is, however, more than just lack of violence as adapted in yoga. It\nmeans kindness, friendliness, and thoughtful consideration of other people and\nthings. It also has to do with our duties and responsibilities too. Ahimsa\nimplies that in every situation we should adopt a considerate attitude . On the\nspiritual path, the first step is to eliminate the beastly nature. The\npredominant trait in beasts is cruelty; therefore, the wise sages prescribed\nahimsa as the first yama. Ahimsa is positive love. It is to abstain from the\nslightest thought of harm to any living creature. The practitioner must abandon\neven unkind looks and scowls. There is no excuse or exception to the above\nrule. Harsh words to vulnerable people and &nbsp;inferiors is himsa (cruelty). To fail to\nrelieve pain or trouble in another is negative himsa. To approve of another\u2019s\nharsh actions is also against ahimsa. So practise ahimsa in its purest form.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">2. SATYA \u2013 Commitment\nto truthfulness . Speech should not be deceitful, misleading or devoid of\nvalue. It should benefit&nbsp; and not harm\nanybody. As Manu says in his Manusmriti, \"Let him not speak what is true\nbut unkind; let him not speak what is kind but untrue\". A common example\nquoted is the one from Mahabharata where when Drona asks of Yudhishthira\n(righteous son of dharma, known to speak the truth always) if his son,\nAshwatthama was dead, Yudhishthira simply replied \"yes, Ashwatthama is\ndead\". This was truthful to the extent that the elephant by that name had\ndied. However, the meaning conveyed to Drona was that his son had died. This is\nconsidered as misleading as it lead to great harm to Drona and his downfall. Satya\nmeans \"to speak the truth,\" yet it is not always desirable to speak\nthe truth on all occasions, for it could harm someone unnecessarily. We have to\nconsider what we say, how we say it, and in what way it could affect others. If\nspeaking the truth has negative consequences for another, then it is better to\nsay nothing. &nbsp;It is no use telling your wellwisher\nthat you saw his mother in a whorehouse around the time he was conceived. &nbsp;Satya should never come into conflict with our\nefforts to behave with ahimsa. This precept is based on the understanding that\nhonest communication and action form the bedrock of any healthy relationship,\ncommunity, or government, and that deliberate deception, exaggerations, and\nmistruths harm others.&nbsp;&nbsp; Thought must\nagree with word and word with action. This is truthfulness. There is no room for\nhypocrisy. To think of one thing, say another and do another is nothing but\ncrookedness. By telling lies you pollute your conscience and infect your\nsubconscious mind. Truth means the strength to abide by positive principles.\nSpeak the truth, but let it not be unpleasant and speak not any pleasing\nfalsehood \u2013 this is eternal religion. It is said that if you speak the truth\nfor twelve years, you will acquire vak siddhi, whatever you say will come to\npass. There will be great power in your speech, you will be able to influence\nthousands. If you are established in truth, all other virtues will cling to\nyou. Truth is like the brilliant sun, how long can you hide it ?&nbsp;&nbsp; 3. ASTEYA is not taking things belonging to\nothers and not even having a desire to do so. Having a desire may ultimately\nlead one to stealing. Even if you find a treasure trove of jewels it should not\nbe taken as it doesn\u2019t belong to you. Steya means \"to steal\"; asteya\nis the opposite-to take nothing that does not belong to us. This also means\nthat if we are in a situation where someone entrusts something to us or\nconfides in us, we do not take advantage of him or her. Non-stealing includes\nnot only taking what belongs to another without permission, but also using\nsomething for a different purpose to that intended, or beyond the time\npermitted by its owner.&nbsp;&nbsp; The practice of\nasteya implies not taking anything that has not been freely given. This\nincludes fostering a consciousness of how we ask for others\u2019 time for\ninconsiderate behavior demanding another\u2019s attention when not freely given is,\nin effect, stealing. Asteya is another form of self-restraint. Why does a\nperson steal? He wants something. When he cannot get it by legitimate means, he\nsteals it. Desire, thirst or trishna is the root cause of stealing. You remove\na thing secretly without the knowledge of the owner and you do not want others\nto know of this act. This is stealing. Taking paper, pencil, etc. from the\noffice is stealing. Hoarding too much money, eating too much, adding to your\ncravings are all forms of stealing. A yogic student must be free from all these\nforms of theft. Even a sensitive mind becomes blunt by continuous stealing.\nEven a little dirt, a little theft affects the mind of a yogic student\nseriously. He will have to be very careful. Then alone will he have success in\nyoga. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">4. <b>BRAHMACHARYA</b> is sense\ncontrol and sexual responsibility . It has nothing to do with abstaining from sex or a ridiculous withholding\ndischarge of semen even when sexually aroused &nbsp;( like what Gandhi did , sleeping under the\nsame blanket with naked underage girls). , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Veerya (Sanskrit </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u0940\u0930\u094d\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Veerya is PSYCHOLOGIAL\nSPERM \u2013not the drops of white gooey liquid which came out of Vivekananda's &nbsp;prick.&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Mind, Prana and Veerya\nare under the one Sambandha or connection or circuit. If the mind is\ncontrolled, Prana and Veerya are controlled automatically. He who suspends or\nrestrains Prana restrains also the working of the mind and the movement of the\nVeerya. &nbsp;Again, if the Veerya is\ncontrolled, and if it is made to flow upwards into the brain by pure thoughts\nand the practice of Viparita Karani Mudras such as Sarvangasana and Sirshasana\nand Pranayama, the mind and the Prana are automatically controlled.</i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>The\nsimplest way to increase veerya is by Pranayama . It has a direct effect on our\nsex energy by freeing it from excitement and increasing its psychic potency.<o:p></o:p></i></span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>According to Ayurveda,\nOjas is the subtle essence that is responsible for life, radiant health, strong\nimmunity, vigor, longevity and overall well being of an individual.&nbsp; The subtle essence called ojas that is\nextracted from the proper digestion and efficient metabolism of food nourishes\nthe bodily tissues of blood, plasma and lymph, muscle, fat, bones, bone marrow,\nsemen and ojas.&nbsp; Ojas also forms the\nbasic material of the five sense organs, ligaments and lubricating fluids .&nbsp;</i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><i style=\"background-color: lime;\">The\nbull given by Vivekananda that by not ejaculating you preserve Ojas remains\nbull. &nbsp; Vivekananda died at a very early age , and he had 31 major ailments in 38\nyears of his life--obviously I cant congratulate him.&nbsp; If he says that he\ngot HAJAAAAAR Ojas , by not ejaculating for 12 years , he must think again.&nbsp;</i></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Signs of healthy Ojas:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Ojas is diminished by\nunder eating, overeating, eating when previous food has not yet been digested,\nconsumption of poor quality food that results in the blocking of the channels,\nconsumption of stale foods, canned foods, fermented foods like cheese, meat,\nirregular diet, excessive exercise, fasting, negative emotional stressors such\nas anxiety, anger, sadness, grief, hatred, jealousy, long held resentment,\nfear, grief, consumption of alcohol, smoking,&nbsp;\nlack of sleep, excessive discharge of mucus, blood, semen and other\nexcreta, with age and injury by other organisms, undue exposure to wind and\nsun, excessive sexual activity. Since Ojas is the result of the quality of food\nwe eat, its proper digestion and efficient metabolism and the sensory\nimpressions we imbibe in our daily life, in order to protect ojas it is vital\nto protect the mind and heart from emotional strain and stress and to adopt a\nhealthy balanced diet.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Nourish your physical\nhealth by eating meals in a pleasant environment in the company of people that\nyou enjoy.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Eat at a moderate pace.\nDon\u2019t eat in a hurry, while walking or driving.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Don\u2019t eat when you are\nemotional, angry, upset etc.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Don\u2019t eat if the\nprevious meal still hasn\u2019t been digested as that will lead to the production of\nama/toxins. The accumulation&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; of ama\nin the bodily tissues leads to disease.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Eat a balance\nmeal.&nbsp; In Ayurveda, a balanced meal\nconsists of&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; all the 6 major tastes\nin moderation: sweet, salty, sour, bitter,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;\nastringent, and pungent.&nbsp; People\nof&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; pitta constitutions should\nminimize or avoid hot, pungent, spicy foods as&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; that will further aggravate the pitta\n(internal fire) which could further&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;\nburn out the ojas.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Nourish your mind\nthrough regular meditation<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Positive thinking<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><br /></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>What is Tejas?<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Tejas is responsible\nfor inner radiance, glow or aura, luster in one\u2019s eyes, clarity, fearlessness,\ncourage, intelligence, and understanding and comprehension at the cellular\nlevel.&nbsp; It is the subtle and positive essence\nor counterpart of pitta or fire element in the body and is responsible for the\ndigestion and metabolism of everything we take in. Tejas can be compared to\nhormones and amino acids that regulate cellular metabolism.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Hence tejas is needed\nfor metabolism.&nbsp; If tejas in a person is\ntoo high it burns out the ojas (just as fire evaporates water), as in the case\nwith multiple sclerosis.&nbsp; The myelin\nsheaths which are composed of ojas (water element) are burned by high tejas (fire\nelement).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Negative thinking\ndamages ojas, tejas, prana, immune system, the spleen, the function of the\nlymphatic system.&nbsp; The thymus gland is\nlocated very close to the heart which is the seat of emotions.&nbsp; Hence any negative emotional disturbance will\naffect the thymus. Gently tapping the sternum stimulates the thymus gland which\nin turn stimulates the immune system.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; immune system and good health.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Self-control is not\nrepression \u2013 it is balance and moderation, or the avoidance of excess. Regular\nand devoted spiritual practice quickly bestows great power, or Ojas Shakti\n(Sanskrit: vigor and energy), on the yogi. His aura increases. font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Check out how Jew\nRothschild tried to make monkeys out of Hindus<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Let me quote Wikipedia-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE:&nbsp; The sage Narada praised Anusuya in his hymns\nand verses, making the wives of Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva jealous. They\nrequested their husbands go and tempt her away from her husband, breaking her\npativrata. The Divine Trinity went to Anusuya as guests when Atri was not at\nhome, and asked her to <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">serve them lunch in the nude</span>. She agreed, but first\nsplashed them each with enchanted water, turning them into small children. The\nthree goddesses waited for their husbands to return, and when they didn\u2019t,\ntraveled to Anusuya\u2019s cottage to find them transformed. The goddesses repented,\nand at the request of Anusuya, the three Gods agreed to be born as her sons.\nAccording to one version, the gods merged turning into Anasuya's three headed\nson Dattatreya.UNQUOTE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>BRRRAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYY\n!</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anasuya\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anasuya</a><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-oTaH_k4KvIw/V5UCwAPR17I/AAAAAAABLIM/62SUuxn_RtQpshtnyy-bewcZTV56G1HSACLcB/s1600/nCdw.gif\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-oTaH_k4KvIw/V5UCwAPR17I/AAAAAAABLIM/62SUuxn_RtQpshtnyy-bewcZTV56G1HSACLcB/s400/nCdw.gif\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the sexual energy is\ntransmuted into &nbsp;spiritual energy by pure\nthoughts, it is called sex sublimation . Sublimation is not a matter of\nsuppression or repression, but a positive, dynamic, conversion process. It is\nthe process of controlling the sex energy, conserving it, then diverting it\ninto higher channels, and finally, converting it into spiritual energy or Ojas\nSakti. By entertaining sublime, soul-elevating thoughts of the Self or Atman,\nby meditation, Japa, worship and Pranayama, the sexual energy can be transmuted\ninto Ojas Sakti and stored up in the brain. Yogis can even control thirst and\nhunger \u2013leave alone lustful sexual thoughts. According to Yogic science, prostaglandins\nexists in a subtle form throughout the whole body. The Yogi penetrates into the\nsubtle hidden nature of things through Yogic Chakshu or the inner vision of\nwisdom. The Yogi gets control over the astral nature of semen and thereby\nprevents the formation of the very fluid itself. The body of a man who is truly\nan Oordhvaretas has the scent of a lotus. The process of sex sublimation is\nextremely difficult. It demands constant and protracted Sadhana and perfect\ndiscipline. That Yogi who has achieved perfect sublimation has perfect control\nover lust. Complete sublimation is achieved through ceaseless meditation on\nAtman and Self-realization. That Yogi or Jnani who has attained the highest\nNirvikalpa Samadhi, in whom the seeds of Samskaras are fried in toto, can claim\nto be a perfect Oordhvaretas or one who has complete sex sublimation. There is\nno fear of his downfall. He is perfectly safe. He will be absolutely free from\nimpurity. This stage is a very high stage. A microscopic minority only have\nattained this sublime exalted state.<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">An example of a full\nOordhvareta Yogi is Adi Shankaracharya--his body had the fragrance of a lotus flower .</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
