Ajit Vadakayil<br />\nJuly 25, 2016 at 10:29 AM<br />\n<br />\nI HAD FOOLED A GIRL IN MY GYM MANY YEARS AGO SAME WAY<br />\n<br />\nSRI SRI RAVISHANKAR FOOLED THE WHOLE OF IIT WITH HIS FAKE SHAKTI OIL -- THIS IS WHAT IITs ARE WORTH , THEY GET FOOLED BY ROGUES .<br />\n<br />\nTriple Sri called for a volunteer to come up on stage for a \u201cpatented\u201d magic oil surprise demonstration.<br />\n<br />\nOne of the students from the back rows of the auditorium was chosen to share the dais.<br />\n<br />\nThe chosen volunteer, a male student wearing a black t-shirt with horizontal white stripes, was asked to extend his arm parallel to the floor, clinch his fist and resist the pulling down of his arm.<br />\n<br />\nTriple Sri gripping the volunteer\u2019s arm near the wrist, was able to pull down his arm easily over and over again, much to the amusement of the na\u00efve audience.<br />\n<br />\nHe then produced from his pocket a small vial containing some oil.<br />\n<br />\nThe volunteer was then asked to rub and spread this oil over his arm. After the volunteer took a step back and a deep breath to relax, the whole exercise was repeated again \u2013 except this time Triple Sri with his gargantuan paunch struggled quite hard to pull down the volunteer\u2019s arm, amazing the vast audience.<br />\n<br />\nThe volunteer, visibly impressed and believing that he had in fact become stronger in a matter of seconds after the application of the oil, went onto fall at the feet (cultural practice of surrender) of the extraordinary messiah Triple Sri.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nFollowing the thundering applause from his gullible audience, Mr. Ravishankar went on to urge stronger volunteers to come forth.<br />\n<br />\nThe next male volunteer also went on to fall at the feet of Mr. Ravishankar after his new found strength.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nThe frenzy in the arena attracted a male \"skeptic\" from the audience to volunteer.<br />\n<br />\nHe was visibly unimpressed by the arm pull down test and the claim of instantaneous improvement of strength and vigor following the application of a few drops of oil.<br />\n<br />\nThe skeptic boldly asked for permission to perform the same test on his own test subject on the dais.<br />\n<br />\nWhile the skeptic readied his subjects, Triple Sri changed his track and launched into a astounding theory for his precious oil.<br />\n<br />\nHe spAke \u201cone drop of poison can destroy the body. Can it not destroy? One drop of poison can destroy the immune system. No? HOOO ? No ? The reverse can also happen \u2013 one drop of nectar can also strengthen your body.\u201d<br />\n<br />\nThe stupefied audience gaped in awe.<br />\n<br />\nWhat happened afterwards was most hilarious . The \u201ctest subjects\u201d chosen by the \u201cskeptic\u201d gave testimonies to the audience that they felt \u201csomething different,\u201d and the skeptic had to agree, on the microphone, that he was convinced of the power of the messiah and his great oil.<br />\n<br />\nThe gullible IIT Kanpur audience could NOT stop clapping. These are the same folks AAP\u2019s Kumar Vishwas recites mindless non-veg Hindi poetry ( CHOO LAA is this poetry, is he a poet ? ) and gets these rustic North Indians in raptures.<br />\n<br />\nSome Shakthi Drops, are sold for 25 Euros in 30ml vials on Art of Living\u2019s EU website.<br />\n<br />\nTriple Sri uses the reaction principle to trick all. Push , relax a muscle and then pull.<br />\n<br />\nTriple Sri\u2019s oil which gives rocket boost in immunity and muscle strength is not even pseudo science \u2013 it is sheer fraud.<br />\n<br />\nTHE PHOTOS ARE IN THE POST BELOW-<br />\n<br />\nSEE THE IIT STUDENT WITH BLACK T SHIRT WITH WHITE HORIZONTAL STRIPES ..<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/12/ipc-section-377-love-lust-perversion.html</span><br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c2021671904743459113\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_34M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/04866063493849159930\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Unknown</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_41.html?showComment=1469416401560#c2021671904743459113\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 25, 2016 at 8:43 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_34MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nDear Captain,<br />\n<br />\nAs usual, excellent write up. Thus we have heard from the wise men who taught this.<br />\n<br />\nXI: He who knows at the same time both Vidya and Avidya, crosses over death by Avidya and attains immortality through Vidya.<br />\n<br />\nMy question is -How Avidya helps in crossing over death and how Vidya helps in getting immortality whereas in previous lines perils of following Avidya and Vidya has been highlighted ?<br />\n<br />\nI could not understand the concept. />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_34b+seedd1YD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_34b+seedd1YD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">5. APARIGRAHA is renunciation\nof unnecessary possessions.Aparigraha is the ability to see the problems caused\nby acquisition, preservation, and destruction of things, since these provoke\nattachment and injury. Possessions produce samskaras which activate in the\nfuture to cause distress if we can\u2019t acquire items desired by us or losing the\nitems that we possess. Yogis are advised to acquire only what is required for\nbasic maintenance and give up all else. Parigraha is covetousness or greed.\nAparigraha is a mental state in which the sensual craving is dead. Parigraha\nleads to anxiety to preserve, fear of loss, hatred, anger, untruthfulness,\nstealing, etc. Aparigraha puts an end to all these and bestows peace and\ncontentment. It removes at one stroke fear, attachment, disappointment,\nanxiety, jealousy, anger, lust and depression. Aparigraha is indeed an aid to\nthe practice of ahimsa, satya and asteya. When the craving is not satisfied you\nbecome angry, you hate the person who stands in your way of attaining things.\nYou harm him in different ways, speak untruth and begin to steal things.\nAparigraha removes all these. It is the foundation of all yogas, just as dhyana\nor meditation is the meeting point of all yogas. Neutralizing the desire to\nacquire and hoard wealth . The yamas are the moral virtues which, if attended\nto, purify human nature and contribute to health and happiness of society. Yoga\nis rooted in the notion of developing a positive personality. Therefore ethical\ndiscipline or the practice of correct conduct is necessary for success in yoga.\nThis is the basis of yama and niyama, the two moral backbones of yoga. They\ndefine the attributes to be practised in everyday life by a spiritual aspirant.\nYama is the first limb of Patanjali\u2019s ashtanga yoga and means \u2018taking a vow\u2019\nwhile niyama is the second limb and means \u2018rule of conduct\u2019. Yama and niyama\nare inter-dependent. Niyama strengthens and safeguards yama. For example, if\none is contented, one will not steal, hurt others or tell lies and will find it\neasy to practise non-covetousness.&nbsp; When\none is sufficiently advanced in the practices of yamas and niyamas, one can\nface every temptation by calling in the aid of pure and restraining thoughts.\nWhen the mind becomes pure it attains the state of steadiness and becomes\none-pointed. If these positive qualities are not cultivated, the mind cannot be\nled to steadiness. One needs to be well established in yama-niyama to attain\nperfection in yoga. When one is perfectly established in them, samadhi will\ncome by itself.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.31\u2014 jatideshakalasamayanavachchhinnah\nsarvabhauma mahavratam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Yamas are the great,\nmighty, universal vows, unconditioned by place, time and class. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In this sutra Patanjali\nemphasizes&nbsp; that the five yamas are\nabsolute, non-negotiable and universal for yogis and cannot be exempted under\nany circumstance such as class, place, time, or circumstance. The five\ncomponents of yama are called 'mighty universal vows', because they are not\ntrammeled to class, place, time or notion of duty. They must be followed\nunconditionally by everyone, and by students of yoga particularly, irrespective\nof origin and situation, with a reservation concerning cultural phenomena like\nreligious ceremonies, vows and vocations of certain people. They form the\nskeleton of rules on which society is grounded. It is however of the belief\nthat this universal approach should be applied to all the other component\nstages of yoga, without discrimination of time, place or circumstances, to lay\ndown the principles of a universal culture. For full-time, dedicated yogis,\nthese vows (of yamas) are not be broken under any circumstance limited by time,\nplace, purpose, social or caste rules, winter, summer, morning, evening etc.\nFor yogis not committed to their yogic goals, these vows can be modified\naccording to their position in life. There are exceptions to yamas.&nbsp; A fisherman due to his occupation needs to\ninflict violence only on fish but nowhere else. Kshatriyas, the warrior class, &nbsp;are allowed violence for protecting the watan\nfrom evil invaders who want to loot, rape women and make people slaves.&nbsp; We Indians were slaves for 800 years , first\nto invading Muslims and then to the white Christian.&nbsp; Jew Rothschild had his agent Gandhi telling\nus to ghumao charka while the white invader robbed Bharatmata blind and\nconverted India from the riches &nbsp;to the\npoorest in 250 years flat.. Gandhi cheated Bharatmata. &nbsp;As per Patanjali, if a Kshatriya wishes to be\na yogi, he must abandon violence altogether even though it may be condoned\nbased on some sacred scriptures. In the Karma-yoga section of Bhagavad Gita,\nKrishna exhorts Arjuna to do his duty as a Kshatriya and engage in violent\nwarfare and kill his near and dear . This may be acceptable in a socio-civic\ncontext, but must be renounced in an ascetic path of yoga. It may be argued\nthat once avidya (ignorance) has been removed, one can act from a position of\nenlightenment and may engage in violence in certain circumstances (war, for\nexample); however, Patanjali makes it clear that no such exception can be made\nfor one on the path to enlightenment. Patanjali would like to make it clear\nthat even though one\u2019s dharma may dictate violating one or more of these yamas,\nfor a yogi they must be treated as great vows, never to be violated. Yamas, and\nits complement, Niyamas, represent a series of \"right living\" or\nethical rules.&nbsp; They are a form of moral\nimperatives, commandments, rules or goals. The Yamas are the \"don't do\nthese\" list of self-restraints, typically representing commitments that\naffect one's relations with others and self. The complementary Niyamas\nrepresent the \"do these\" list of observances, and together Yamas and\nNiyamas are personal obligations to live well. The earliest mention of the word\nYamas is in the 7000 year old Rigveda. The Yamas apply broadly and include\nself-restraints in one's actions, words and thoughts. Yama is the very\nfoundation of Yoga, without which the superstructure of Yoga cannot be built.\nPractice of Yama is really the practice of Sadachara (right conduct). Manu\nsays: Ahimsa satyasteyam sauchamindriya nigraha - harmlessness, truth speaking,\nrefraining from theft, control of senses; this is the essence of Dharma. Great\nemphasis is given in every chapter of the Gita on the practice of Yama. The ten\nyamas listed by \u015a\u0101\u1e47\u1e0dilya Upanishad, are:--Ahi\u1e43s\u0101 (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0939\u093f\u0902\u0938\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">):\nNonviolence,Satya (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0924\u094d\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">): truthfulness,Asteya\n(</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0938\u094d\u0924\u0947\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">):\nnot stealing,Brahmacharya (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092c\u094d\u0930\u0939\u094d\u092e\u091a\u0930\u094d\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">): chastity,marital\nfidelity or sexual restraint,K\u1e63am\u0101 (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0915\u094d\u0937\u092e\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">):\nforgiveness,Dh\u1e5bti (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0927\u0943\u0924\u093f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">): fortitude, Day\u0101 (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0926\u092f\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">):\ncompassion,\u0100rjava (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0906\u0930\u094d\u091c\u0935</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">): non-hypocrisy,\nsincerity,Mit\u0101h\u0101ra (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092e\u093f\u0924\u0939\u093e\u0930</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">): measured diet, \u015aauca\n(</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0936\u094c\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">):\npurity, cleanliness<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.32--- shauchasantoshatapahsvadhyayeshvarapranidhanani\nniyamah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Cleanliness,\ncontentment, religious zeal, self-study and surrender of the self to the\nsupreme Self or God are the niyamas. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Niyama evolves from\nindividual practices, necessary to build up the sadhaka's own character. These\nfive observations harmonise with the five sheaths of man and the elements of\nnature - the anatomical (earth), physiological (water), psychological (fire),\nintellectual (air) and spiritual (ether) layers. &nbsp;&nbsp;As ether (mahat akasa) is considered as an\nempty space outside, therefore the soul is an empty space within and is called\ncit-akasa. &nbsp;In reality this empty space\nis a zero point field , a PLENUM, a cauldron &nbsp;of brimming energy .The principles of niyama\nthat are comprehended by kriyayoga accentuate the importance of self-discipline.\nMastery of yoga would be unattainable without the observance of the ethical\nprinciples of yama and niyama. Cleanliness or purification is of two kinds -\nexternal and internal. Both are necessary. Taking a bath is external\npurification; performing asanas and pranayama is internal cleanliness. Observance\nof niyama develops friendliness, compassion and indifference, and is a further\naid in purging the body, mind and intelligence. Svadhyaya is checking oneself\nto see if the principles of yoga are being followed. In order to follow these\nprinciples one has first to decide whether one's own pattern of behaviour is\ncoordinated with them or not. If not, one has to prepare one's thoughts and\nactions in conformity with them, and remove those faults which hinder one's\nsadhana. Owing to desires, anger, avarice, infatuation, haughtiness and envy,\nthe mind is immersed in pain. Misguided by these emotions, the sadhaka loses\nhis balance of mind and behaves immorally. Re-examination of his thoughts\nreduces the inclination to be wrong. The ethical discipline of yama and niyama\ntransform the sadhaka's alloyed or corrupted mind and enables his consciousness\nto radiate in its own unalloyed pureness. Hence, yoga stresses that discipline\nis religion .It is a method knowingly designed to elevate each individual's\nawareness so that he may experience the vision of the core of his being - atma\ndarsana. religion is the means to Self-Realisation. Whereas yamas are concerned\nwith how the yogi interacts with others by desisting from certain activities,\nniyamas focus on personal discipline and practice by engaging in certain\nactivities.<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1)SHAUCHA is both\ninternal and external cleanliness. External cleanliness consists in hygiene .\nInternal cleanliness consists of purifying the mind of contaminations like\nanger, hatred, jealousy, pride, vanity, attachments etc. An attitude of\nfriendliness and compassion toward all will help internal purity.&nbsp; For external cleansing yogis recommend the\npractice of the Shatkarma (six cleansing routines) mentioned in the Hatha Yoga\nPradipika: Dhauti (internal cleansing), Basti (yogic enema),Neti (nasal\ncleansing),Trataka (concentrated gazing), Nauli (abdominal\nchurning), Kapalabhati ( forehead glow).In sutra 1.33. Six \"mental\nimpurities\" are commonly mentioned \u2013 kama (lust/craving), krodha (anger),\nlobha (greed), moha (delusion), mada&nbsp;\n(arrogance), and matsarya (jealousy). The ultimate internal cleansing\ninvolves removing all the five kleshas by the attainment of \"viveka\nkhyati\" (discriminative discernment). Saucha is&nbsp; purity, clearness of mind, speech and\nbody.The practices of asana, pranayama and meditation cleanse and purify the\nbody and mind, as well as strengthening their capacity to maintain a pure state\nof being. We must also consciously work at surrounding ourselves with a pure\nenvironment . Shaucha is the doorway to deeper and more tranquil states of\nmeditation. As the body becomes purified you will experience radiant health; as\nthe mind becomes purified you will feel increasingly clear, friendly, and\ncheerful. The first Niyama is about nourishing ourselves through the five\nsenses of taste, touch, sight, sound, and smell. Everything we take in from the\nenvironment flows through these channels and is then perceived as our\nexperience. Here, we are encouraged to reduce or eliminate anything we may\ndistinguish as being toxic, and increase things that provide more nourishment\nfor our body, mind, and soul. Consider the foods you're eating, your habits,\nthe environment you spend most of your time in, and the relationships you have\nwith others. Weed out the habits that don\u2019t support a life of purity.<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; 2)</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">SANTOSHA or contentment\nis a great wealth. When the mind is happy because of the light of sattva guna,\nthat is santosha. You count your blessings, not your sorrows. Santosha\nrepresents disinterest in accumulating more than one\u2019s immediate needs of life.\nThe Bhagavad Gita makes a strong statement against desires that can never be\nsatisfied. To avoid injury to the foot from thorns, one only needs to wear a\npair of shoes \u2013 there should be no need to cover the entire earth with\ncarpets.When the mind is happy because of the light of sattva guna, that is contentment.\nIt is about unbound optimism in life , acceptance of others and of one's\ncircumstances as they are.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dont be so\nfocused on things you want that you miss things you need. Human tendency is to\nwant more and more things that you really don\u2019t need.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Never allow things you want to obscure things\nyou have. Never let things that matter the most be at the mercy of things that\nmatter the least. Stop chasing useless things you want and your soul will get\nwhat it needs . Santosha is not craving for what we do not have as well as not\ncoveting the possessions of others. The yogis tell us that when we are\nperfectly content with all that life gives us, then we attain true joy and\nhappiness. It is easy for the mind to become fooled into thinking that we can\nattain lasting happiness through the possession of objects and goods, but both\nour personal experience and the teachings of the sages prove that the happiness\ngained through materialism and hedonism is only temporary. Practicing\ncontentment frees us from the unnecessary suffering of always wanting things to\nbe different, and instead fills us with gratitude and joy for all of life\u2019s\nblessings.When we are content, we are happy. This second Niyama invites us to\nrelinquish patterns of trying to control other people and outcomes, and to\nsettle, instead, into a place of centered awareness. Yoga is the progressive\nquieting of the fluctuations of the mind. When you settle into periods of\nquieting the mind, you will experience a state of contentment that reflects\nyour ability to remain at peace regardless of what is going on in your external\nenvironment., you will be filled with contentment and gratitude for the beauty\nand gifts that are abundant in your life. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">3)TAPAS \u2013 Tapas is\ndoing something you do not want to do that will have a positive effect on your\nlife. When our will conflicts with the desire of our mind an internal \u201cfire\u201d is\ncreated which illuminates and burns up our mental and physical impurities. This\ninner fire can also be used as a source of spiritual energy;. Tapas transforms\nand purifies us as well as enables the conscious awareness and control over our\nunconscious impulses and poor behavior. Tapas builds the will power and\npersonal strength to help us become more dedicated to our practice of yoga .\nTapas (discipline) is the third Niyama, and it\u2019s often incorrectly perceived as\nhaving to refrain from life's pleasures. As human beings, we are meant to\nexperience all aspects of our humanity, including from the physical, material,\nmental, emotional, spiritual, and ethereal. This Niyama is about creating a\nstrong and balanced foundation from which the other Niyamas may flourish. Yoga\ninvolves enduring hardships and remain undisturbed by the lack of material\ncomforts. Tapas does not mean inflicting undue and damaging hardship on the\nbody. Just like gold is purified by putting it through intense heat, the same\nway our body and mind are purified by practicing tapas., making a determination\nto give up your normal comforts for a certain amount of time is a part of\ntapas. The practice of asanas is a form of tapas for the body; meditation is a\ntapas that purifies and focuses the mind. Self-surrender is not a process of\ndefeat or of mindlessly submitting to another\u2019s will. It is the act of giving\nourselves to a higher purpose. Eating healthy, organic foods; committing to\ndaily movement or exercise; getting to sleep by 10 p.m. and waking at sunrise;\nand committing to silence and self-reflective practices are some of the\ndisciplined daily practices that establish a solid foundation for personal\ncare.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">4)</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">SVADHYAYA is study of self, self-reflection,\nintrospection of self's thoughts, speeches and actions. Svadhyaya means,\nliterally, \u201cto recollect (to remember, to contemplate, to meditate on) the\nSelf.\u201d It is the effort to know the Self that shines as the innermost core of\nyour being.By the practice of Svadhyay, desire for worldly objects diminishes\nand taste for spirituality increases. Chanting of mantra as a form of Swadhyay.\nSvadhyaya (self-study) is the ability to see our true divine nature through the\ncontemplation of our life\u2019s lessons and through the meditation on the truths\nrevealed by seers and sages. Life presents an endless opportunity to learn\nabout ourselves; our flaws and weaknesses give us the opportunity to grow and\nour mistakes allow us to learn. Examining our actions becomes a mirror to see\nour conscious and unconscious motives, thoughts, and desires more clearly. The\nyogic practice of Svadhyaya also involves the study of sacred and spiritual\ntexts as a guide to our interior world where our true self resides. Self-study\nrequires both seeing who we are in the moment and seeing beyond our current\nstate to realize our connection with the divine. Reading spiritual literature (\nlike Bhagawad Gita ) will give you some level of intellectual knowledge. It\u2019s\njust as important to develop spiritual awareness through self-study, which will\nprovide you with an experiential understanding of the knowledge you've acquired\nintellectually. When knowledge and experience come together, wisdom is born.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">5) ISHVARA PRANIDHANA -\nIshvara refers to all-pervading consciousness; pranidhana means \u201cto surrender.\u201d\nSelf-surrender is not a process of defeat or of mindlessly submitting to\nanother\u2019s will. It is the act of giving ourselves to a higher purpose.&nbsp; Ishvara Pranidhana is contemplation of the\nIshvara ( Brahman, True Self ).&nbsp; .\nThrough this simple act of dedication we become reminded of our connection to\nour higher power, and our yoga practice becomes sacred and filled with grace,\ninner peace, and abounding love. Embracing uncertainty is one of the most\nchallenging practices and yet, the paradox of surrendering to uncertainty is\nprecisely what sets us free from limitless constrictions of the mind. Practice\naccepting the outcome of events and situations\u2014even when they don't unfold in\nthe way you had hoped.&nbsp; Ishvara\nPranidhana is a mindset , an attitude to calm the mind.-------</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The five niyamas are\nconstructive tools for cultivating happiness and self-confidence; the\nopportunities to practice them arise every day&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Niyama literally means\npositive duties or observances\u2014it includes virtuous habits, behaviors and\nobservances (the \"dos\").</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The second limb of\nPatanjali\u2019s eight-limbed yoga system contains the five internal practices of\nNiyama (observance). These practices extend the ethical codes of conduct\nprovided in his first limb, the yamas, to the practicing yogi\u2019s internal\nenvironment of body, mind and spirit. The practice of Niyama helps us maintain\na positive environment in which to grow, and gives us the self-discipline and\ninner-strength necessary to progress along the path of yoga.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When you pick one petal\nfrom the garland of yamas and niyamas, the entire garland will follow.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word\n\"yoga\" means to unite the three layers of our existence: body, mind,\nand spirit. The practice of cultivating higher levels of personal conduct\nbegins with self-awareness. Niyamas will emerge naturally when you live a\nbalanced life on spiritual, mental, emotion, and physical levels.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Niyamas are about your individual\npersonal behavior and they serve as a guide for recognizing and improving how\nyou're living\u2014and loving\u2014when no one is looking.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Niyamas invite us\nto consider how we live our lives when no one else is paying attention. This is\nway different from Sadguru Jaggi Vasudev telling Barkha Dutt on TV , that as\nlong as homosexuality is done behind closed doors \u2013all is OK.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This rogue does NOT want to lose his\nFreemason sponsorship . Karma catches up behind closed doors too.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c8300604368604782198\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_67M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. This has nothing to do with withholding semen .<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">QUOTE:&nbsp; If, indeed, thou hast a craving for\nliberation, shun sense-objects from a good distance as thou wouldst do poison,\nand always cultivate carefully the nectar-like virtues of contentment,\ncompassion, forgiveness, straight-forwardness, calmness and self-control. One\nshould become aware of oneself, indivisible and perfect like Space itself, when\nfree from identification with such things as one's body, senses, functions,\nmind and sense of doership, which are all the products of one's own ignorance. Only\nhe who is free from the terrible hankering after the senses which is so hard to\novercome is fit for liberation, and no-one else, not even if he is an expert in\nthe six branches of scripture. The pleasures and riches of worldly life are\ndeceptive appearances. Understanding that they are all but a passing-show, be\ndetached and dispassionate, cultivate renunciation and seek Brahman. The first\nstep to Liberation is the extreme aversion to all perishable things, then\nfollow calmness, self-control, forbearance, and the utter relinquishment of all\nwork enjoined in the Scriptures. Sense-objects are even more virulent in their\nevil effects than the poison of the cobra. Poison kills one who takes it, but those\nothers kill one who even looks at them through the eyes. He who has killed the\nshark known as sense-object with the sword of mature dispassion, crosses the\nocean of Samsara, free from all obstacles. So for a seeker after Liberation the\ninfatuation over things like the body is a dire death. He who has thoroughly\nconquered this deserves the state of Freedom. Blessed indeed are those virtuous\npersons who at first have this consciousness of Brahman and then develop it\nmore and more. They are respected everywhere. Recognise that the pleasures of\nsense-objects (samsara) are riddled with pain.Seek the Self with consistent\nendeavour. :UNQUOTE</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><b><span style=\"font-size: large;\">THERE WAS THIS UNMARRIED OLD BRAHMACHARI WHO WAS TOLD TO FILL UP A FORM IN CAPITAL\n( UPPER CASE). &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-size: x-large;\">&nbsp;</span></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14213920354602443082\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Vipul Rishi</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_21.html?showComment=1469216071501#c2881786327037262452\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 23, 2016 at 1:04 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_77MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nRespected Ajit Sir,<br />\n<br />\nI would like to thank and express my gratitude to you for the work you have been doing for last 6-7 yrs.<br />\nI was introduced to your blogs by one of my friends and I am very much thankful to that guy as well.<br />\nI find your blogs very informative. Sometimes I also wonder about your source of great level of information and knowledge. But then I think it must be your 4 decades of experience at sea which is paying you off(I might be wrong in this judgement).<br />\nThe great thing about your blogs is that while reading them my inner conscience asks me to believe their content.<br />\nHence, whatever I am writing below is the voice of my inner conscience.<br />\n<br />\nSince my childhood, I have been a staunch believer of Hinduism. I have read your blogs on Sanatana Dharama. Your blog series on Sanatana Dharam is truly a masterpiece of your writings.<br />\nSir, I try to understand them deeply but somehow can get merely 2%-3% of what you write.<br />\nThis must be due to my pea-brained level of understanding and the magnificence of this ultimate and the great concept which we know by the name of Sanatana.<br />\nBut only 2%-3% of this understanding has developed in me an amazing feeling of great pride in being a Hindu and an Indian.<br />\nAnd this feeling is so strong that it would never ever fade away. I am VERY GRATEFUL to you for this.<br />\nI am proud to be born in a country whose culture is the greatest and richest on this planet. All our maharishis and sages were great scientists and masters of meditation. Their contribution to this country and society can never be matched.<br />\nMy endeavour is to take my understanding of Sanatana Dharam to a much higher level. I would be very thankful if you can guide me with few ways in which I can do that.<br />\n<br />\nThanks...</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_77BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; text-decoration: none;\">July 23, 2016 at 1:26 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_76MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nWHAT I WRITE IS THE REAL SANATANA DHARMA<br />\n<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS WRITTEN BY WHITE INDOPHILES-THE WOLVES IN SHEEPs CLOTHING<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS DISCUSSED IN DESH DROHI LITERARY FESTS<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS COOKED UP BY DROHI COMMIE PROFESSSORS OF JNU<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS WRITTEN IN THE LYING SPIRITUALITY COLUMN OF TOILET PAPER OF INDIA,<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS PREACHED BY FAKE GURUS FOR WHOM ROTHSCHILD HAS OPENED HUNDREDS OF BRANCHES WORLD WIDE ,<br />\n--NOT WHAT IS PREACHED BY THE FAKE GURUS WHO PREACH AT INTERNATIONAL FREEMASON SEMINARS,<br />\n--NOT THE THE BULL OF DEVDUTT PATTANAIK ON TV,<br />\n--NOT THE NONSENSE OF AMISH TRIPATI WHO HAS CONVERTED COSMIC FORCES ( GODS ) INTO MORTALS --<br />\n<br />\nREMEMBER WE WROTE DOWN THESE THINGS 7000 YEARS AGO, WHEN THE REST OF THE PLANET DID GRUNT GRUNT FOR LANGUAGE<br />\n<br />\nIMAGINE THESE WHITE SKINNED PEOPLE CALLED US INDIANS HEATHEN SAVAGES , PRACTICING A PAGAN RELIGION FULL OF EVIL AND SUPERSTITION-- YET THEY LEARNT OUR LANGUAGES<br />\n<br />\nTODAY NR NARAYANA MURTHY WANTS SHELDON POLLOCK TO TEACH HINDUS HINDUISM<br />\n<br />\nWIKIPEDIA QUOTES WENDY DONIGER ,THE INDOPHILES AND THE DESH DROHI INDIAN BASTARDS WHO COME IN TIME TOP 100 (FOR DENIGRATING ANCIENT INDIA AND SANATANA DHARMA ).<br />\n<br />\nOUR OWN PM APCO MODI, HAS A KNACK OF PRAYING TO ALL FAKE AND BACKDATED CREATIONS OF JEW ROTHSCHILD<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_77b+seedOIhdD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_77b+seedOIhdD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sahasra Sirasam Svetam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pranamami Patanjalim<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Translation<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">OM<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I bow to the lotus feet\nof the Supreme Guru<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">which awaken insight\ninto the happiness of pure Being,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">which are the refuge,\nthe jungle physician,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">which eliminate the\ndelusion caused by the poisonous herb of Samsara (conditioned existence).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I prostrate before the\nsage Patanjali<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">who has thousands of\nradiant, white heads (as the divine serpent, Ananta)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">and who has, as far as\nhis arms, assumed the form of a man<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">holding a conch shell\n(divine sound), a wheel (discus of light or infinite time) and a sword\n(discrimination).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CLOSING &nbsp;MANTRA<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">OM<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svasthi Praja Bhyaha\nPari Pala Yantam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nya Yena Margena Mahim Mahishaha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Go Brahmanebhyaha Shubamastu Nityam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lokah Samastah Sukhino Bhavantu<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Om Shanti Shanti Shantihi<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Translation<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">May the rulers of the\nearth keep to the path of virtue<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For protecting the\nwelfare of all generations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">May the religious, and\nall peoples be forever blessed,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">May all beings\neverywhere be happy and free<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">OM peace, peace, &nbsp;peace<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/izkwqbHBf7c/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/izkwqbHBf7c?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.16 \u2014&nbsp; heyan duhkham anagatam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The grief which has not\nyet come may be avoided.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Past pain is over. &nbsp;The pain being &nbsp;experienced in the present cannot be avoided,\nbut can be minimised to some extent by yogic practice and discriminative\nknowledge. Unknown future pains can be forestalled by cohering to yogic\ndiscipline now. Man is the only living creature who can control or change his\nlife. He is not a slave to his surroundings or at the mercy of nature. There is\nnothing that wastes the body and mind like worry. Worries are more about\nyesterday and tomorrow. Don\u2019t take tomorrow to bed with you.&nbsp; There is a difference between planning and\nworrying. Planning is constructive, worry is destructive. The best time to\nsolve a problem is as soon at it happens.Man has 3 sides to his nature \u2013body,\nmind and spirit . A proper balance between the 3 is desired. If any of the 3 is\nundeveloped he will suffer in life. Without spiritual development , man is\nwithout love or positive emotions ( affection, care, respect, sympathy ) .&nbsp; Without positive emotions man cant be happy. A\nwise man can live in peace with things he cannot change. Never try to do things\nyou cant. What is the point in teaching a donkey to sing. It is a sheer waste\nof time and effort. Nature follows the law, use it or lose it. Make most of the\nbest and least of the worst. Man alone is the architect of his destiny.&nbsp; Inaction is worse than no action at all.Patanjali\nsays that yoga is a preventive healing art, science and philosophy, by which\none builds up robust healthy conditions in body and mind and constructs a\nprotective strength with which to ward off or counteract afflictions that are\nas yet unperceived afflictions. Moreover, strong health and a stable mind will\nfacilitate one to face the wonder of wonders - the spiritual bliss - if and\nwhen, thanks to the good actions in former lives, the spiritual gate is set\nopen. According to the yogis, death doesn\u2019t solve your problem any more than\nnight fall solves your financial problems. Yogis claim that knowledge, bliss\nand Enlightenment can be attained here and now while still in this physical\nbody. &nbsp;This is attained by following a\ndefinite scientific approach which has been verified by the experience of\ninnumerable yogis, saints and sages through the ages. Future suffering has its\nseeds in the present and the past. It is only through liberation that future\nsuffering can be fully eliminated. Avidya (ignorance) which is at the root of\nall the kleshas that cause suffering. So, our objective in eliminating future\nsuffering would be to uproot Avidya. &nbsp;Faith\nand trust are the seeds which bring the sweet fruits of success. Faith is about\n\u201c can do\u201d&nbsp; think \u201c it is possible\u201d&nbsp; it gives you new energy. Will power is the\ndecision to carry on the fight. Self esteem is required to make a person\nmentally healthy. &nbsp;Faith is the bird\nwhich sings when the dawn is still dark. A mentally healthy person learns to\nevaluate himself , his own performance and behaviour. To be successful you must\nbe exited about life. Life is a festival only to those who live with\nenthusiasm. &nbsp;&nbsp;If you want peace you must\nbe prepared for war\u2014NOT sit like an idiot and spin the charkha .&nbsp; Only a moron will&nbsp; start digging a well, when he gets thirsty. It\nis not enough to aim, you must hit. Failure to hit the bulls eye is never the\nfault of the target. You have to choose your own goal, at the same time follow\nsocial norms. Belief in predetermined destiny is the only refuge of weak minds.\nTake responsibility for your failures. Laughter is the cheapest luxury, it\nelectrifies the nerves and cleanses the system. Prayer renews our internal\nstrength during rough weather. A prayer is to the soul what air is to the\nlungs. Yoga helps you to &nbsp;forget useless\nthings. To remember everything is to make your mind a dustbin.&nbsp; There is NO medicine for jealousy except\nyoga. Jealousy is poison for the soul. &nbsp;&nbsp;Yoga teached you that the greatest wealth is\ncontentment with little. It consists in simple wants. Too much glamour is like\ntoo much spices. It harms. The blatant display of status symbols&nbsp; is the result of low self esteem. The self\nconfident person can afford to project a modest image. The purpose of life is\nnot only to be happy, but also to be creative , productive and useful\u2014to make a\ndifference that you lived at all on this planet.&nbsp; There is no experience better for the heart\nthan to reach down and lift people. Only people with inferiority complex wants\nto impress others. Do not go around copying others signatures .There is no need\nto keep up with the Joneses. . All imitations are plastic. There is great joy\nin being ordinary. &nbsp;Yoga helps you to eliminate\nthe needless wants of life. As you can see yoga is NOT a physical exercise. You\nhave succeeded in life when all you really want is only what you really need. &nbsp;Never fall into the same hole twice. The first\nfall can be deemed as experience. Only what you experience is yours. If you\nhave to look into the rear view mirror of life, just make it a darting glance.\nDo NOT dwell on it. &nbsp;Yoga teaches that truth\nblossoms only in individual freedom. It can never happen to a crowd. If you\nsurrender your freedom and individuality big brother and the society will give\nyou great posts and respectability. Dare to be who you are. No order is higher\nthan your own intelligence. You must allow life its freedom. All perfectionism\nis a deep ego trip. Most of your pain is self chosen. Creating guilt in you is\nthe oldest trick of all religions.&nbsp; Sanatana\nDharma offers hope, not guilt\u2014unlike the single holy book religions..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.17 \u2014&nbsp; drashtridrishyayoh sanyogo heyahetuh</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The cause of pain is\nthe association or identification of the seer (atmi) with the seen (prakrti)\nand the remedy lies in their dissociation.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A prudent person\nnotices that inner harmony is interrupted when the mind lets itself be lured\ninto indiscriminately sampling the world of phenomena. &nbsp;He tries to remain free by avoiding material\nattachment, in which objects attract the intelligence like a magnet and the\nself is tempted into an illusory relationship with the external, seen world,\nprovoking pleasures and pains. The intelligence is the vehicle closest to the\nsoul, which must be cautious of its influence if the seer is to stay free. Or\nelse, intelligence entangles the seer into a painful relationship with external\nobjects. As long as intelligence is indiscriminating, there is suffering. The\nmoment it develops discriminative power, it realises its source, and unites\nwith the seer. Then there is transparency between the seer and seen, allowing\nfree, uncontaminated passage between them. The seat of the ego or small self is\nthe seat of the brain, and the seat of the great Self is within the spiritual\nheart. Though intelligence links the head and the heart, it vacillates between\nthe two. This vacillation stops through right knowledge and understanding.\nIntelligence is then transformed - free from polarity, pure and unbiased. This\nis true meditation, in which ego dissolves, allowing the great Self (purusa) to\nglimmer in its own glory.To uproot anything, we must get down to the root cause\nand eliminate that cause. This problem is linked to the origin of the universe\nwherein the consciousness, male purusha got entangled with elements of female Prakriti.\nThis problem cannot be understood or analyzed by our limited intellect. It can\nand will be solved only through the transcendent knowledge that can be gained\nthrough enlightenment. &nbsp;The key concept\nto remember is that the yoking of Purusha with Prakriti has taken place giving\nrise to bondage. Now we need to reach the state of liberation before fully\neliminating all bondage, thus eradicating all suffering. The seer is Purusha\nwho is the reflector of buddhi (the pure I-sense). The objects that are\nexperienced by the buddhi are the knowable. The buddhi and the knowable, due to\ntheir proximity to Purusha, become an attribute of Purusha. Buddhi becoming the\nobject of experience is revealed as the Purusha itself. This beginningless\nalliance between Purusha and the object of awareness (Prakriti represented by\nbuddhi) is the cause of suffering which is avoidable. In the case of the union\nbetween Purusha and buddhi, it cannot be in space or time. Union in space is\nbetween two physical objects; union in time happens when two activities take\nplace at the same time. The union between Purusha and buddhi is beginningless\nand is thus beyond time. The contact between the two is a peculiar union which\ncannot be distinguished by the senses. The union seems to occur only due to the\nI-sense (ahamkara) and can only be the result of ignorance since in reality\nthese two are separate. Liberation from sorrow can only happen as a result of\nknowledge. The object or the knowable remains unmanifest unless seen by the\nobserver. But it goes on mutating due to its inherent nature. As it is seen by\nthe seer, it becomes the seer\u2019s object and is thus dependent on the seer. Similarly\nto remove suffering we need to remove Purusha from its association with\nPrakriti. This sutra and several of the subsequent sutras constitute the\nessence of the Samkhya philosophy. These sutras clearly tell us that Samkhya\nand Yoga are essentially dualistic philosophies where Purusha and Prakriti are\nprojected as two independent entities. Most people are aware that \u2018yoga\u2019 is\nderived from the root word \u2018yuj\u2019. The most commonly given meaning of \u2018yuj\u2019 is\nto join, unite or yoke etc. In that sense, most people tend to say that yoga is\nthe \u2018union of body, mind and soul\u2019, without really understanding its true\nmeaning. What we need to understand is that another meaning of \u2018yuj\u2019 (as per\ndhatupatha which is the source book of all root words in Sanskrit) is\n\u2018samadhau\u2019 (in samadhi) or \u2018to concentrate the mind\u2019. &nbsp;In light of the sutra 2.17 which we are\ndiscussing here, it is clear that, in fact, the union between Purusha (soul)\nand Prakriti (mind-body complex) is indeed the cause of suffering and the cycle\nof birth and re-birth. It is only through un-uniting the two, that is,\nunderstanding the separation between Purusha (the seer) and Prakriti (the seen)\nthat one can attain liberation. \u2026<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;
