, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u094d\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0926\u0938\u0926\u094d\u092f\u094a\u0928\u093f\u091c\u0928\u094d\u092e\u0938\u0941</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0965</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n21 </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0965</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhagavad Gita (13.21)\n4000 BC<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">puru\u1e63a\u1e25 prak\u1e5btistho hi\nbhu\u1e45kte prak\u1e5btij\u0101n gu\u1e47\u0101n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">k\u0101ra\u1e47a\u1e43 gu\u1e47asa\u1e45gosya\nsadasadyonijanmasu 13.2</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Since the soul is\nseated in Nature, therefore it experiences the qualities born of Nature.\nContact with the qualities is the cause of its births in good and evil\nwombs.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We keep Bhagawad Gita\nat the level of the lowest common denominator , the layman with average intellect.\nThe REAL wisdom of Bhagawad Gita can be understood only by the\nsuper-intelligent. Understand Samkhya Vedanta , creation of cosmos, on a macro\nscale &nbsp;below. This is the third template\nof Sanatana Dharma.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In\nHindusim we call the MALE- purusha and FEMALE- pragati. Sometimes for purposes\nof the Kundalini raise MALE is SHIVA and FEMALE is Shakti ( Parvati ).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4000 years ago Adi\nShankaracharya wrote \u2013<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shivah Shakthyaa Yuktho\nYadi Bhavathi Shakthaha Prabhavithum<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Na Chedevam Devo Na\nKhalu Kushalaha Sphandithumapi<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Translation Verse No 1\n: Shiva becomes capable of creating the Universe, only when united with Shakthi\n, but otherwise , He is incapable of even a stir.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tanta is NOT perverse\nsex. In the Tantric cosmology, the whole universe is perceived as being\ncreated, penetrated and sustained by two fundamental forces, which are\npermanently in a perfect, indestructible UNION. These forces or universal\naspects are called Shiva and Shakti. Tantric art has captured the images of the\nPurusha and his consort, Pragati, in ecstatic union.&nbsp; This is NOT perverted sex.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purusha and\nPragati is expressed as Shiva and Shakti in the same body 50:50 \u2013 this is NOT a\nshe boy or a transgender .&nbsp; It is a\nmindboggling,&nbsp; intelligent concept. In\nHinduism we have placed the female on a pedestal . No man can do a yagam if he\nis a bachelor or a widower.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purusha\nis the embodiment of pure consciousness, and Pragati as the embodiment of pure\nenergy. &nbsp;Both Shiva and Shakti are\nConsciousness---- Shiva is the changeless static aspect of Consciousness, and\nShakti is the kinetic, active aspect of the same Consciousness. Through uniting\nwith Purusha , Pragati gave form to his spirit and created the universe.(we are\ntalking about CREATION OF THE COSMOS here- not street side sex&nbsp; as figured out by small minds).When the\ninsentient Prakriti comes in contact with the sentient Purusha , the universe\nevolves. Purusha symbolizes consciousness, the masculine principle. Pragati\nsymbolizes the feminine principle, the activating energy.&nbsp; The cosmos in all its manifestations, as an\nact of love.&nbsp; The relationship between\nsay- Shakti and Shiva is the dance of consciousness and energy experienced\nwithin each of us, regardless of gender. Shiva resides in the highest Sahasr\u0101ra\nChakra and Shakti in the lowest M\u016bl\u0101dh\u0101ra Chakra. When Prakriti and Purusha\nunite in the Sahasr\u0101ra Chakra ( raising of Kundalini ) , knowledge, knower and\nthe object of knowledge become one.&nbsp; Sankhya\nthus is a theory of evolution and understanding the universe. Prakriti cannot\nbe perceived, not because of its non-existence, but because of its subtlety. It\nis perceived in its effects. The eternal and indestructible union between Shiva\nand Shakti gives birth to the whole Macrocosm, in its stable, static aspect as\nwell as in its dynamic one. Not only is Shakti responsible for creation, it is\nalso the agent of all change. Shakti is manifested by Shiva only during\ncreation and is withdrawn into himself at the end of creation. This is for the\nperceptive.&nbsp; Shallow western minds have\nnever understood this &nbsp;amazing truth.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Modern science\nrepeats from our Vedas that matter and energy are interchangeable.&nbsp; So does consciousness and energy .&nbsp; In the highest planes they are\ninterchangeable, which is why we see a great incongruence between our spiritual\nexperiences and the external reality. In the higher metaphysical realms and\nsubtle planes of our consciousness the physical laws of our universe lose their\nvalidity.&nbsp; Samkhya as you can see was a\nmasterpiece of modeling the ways of the inner universe.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tayor yad yamalam rupam\nsa samghatta iti smrtah---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ananda-saktih saivokta\nyato visvam visrjyati,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Na Sivah Saktirahito na\nSaktih Sivavarjita.&nbsp;\n---(Tantraloka-Ahnika, 3.)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"The coupled form\nof these two (Shiva-Shakti) is called junction.&nbsp;\nThat is called the blissful Shakti from which creation arises.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ADAM and EVE story is\njust lifted from our sanskrit upanishads -&nbsp;\nthis story is the basis of the Abrahamic religions Judaism/ Christianity\n/ Islam. All three religions draw upon this STOLEN story from MUNDAKA upanishad\nIII, 1, 1-3 ( Genesis of the Old Testament ).. This story and speaks of the\ntree of knowledge and God's commandment that its fruit shall not be eaten. Adam\nat first did not eat it but Eve did. After that Adam too ate the forbidden\nfruit. The upanishad ORIGINAL story is about two birds sitting on a peepal\ntree.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> &nbsp;&nbsp;T</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">he birds are PURUSHA\n(atman )and PRAKRITI ( jiva )-- with purusha being the witness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">HEY PRESTO--ATMAN\nbecomes ADAM.&nbsp; JIVA becomes EVE ( j is\nsilent in most areas ) --people call me AIT ( ayit ) instead of AJIT. The FIG\nwhich eve ate is the fruit of the peepal tree ( FICUS ) -- the true botanical\nname today is FICUS RELIGIOSA.&nbsp; The old\ntestament NEVER spoke of apple ( from a fig tree ) !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.18 --</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">prakashakriyasthitishilan\nbhootendriyatmakan bhogapavargarthan drishyam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Nature, its three\nqualities - sattva, rajas and tamas, and its evolutes, the elements, mind,\nsenses of perception and organs of action, exist eternally to serve the seer,\nfor enjoyment or emancipation.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The visible objective world\nconsists of elements of nature and senses of perception comprising three\nqualities or attributes (gunas), which are illumination, motion or action, and\ninertia or dormancy. All these exist perpetually to serve the seer (the\nsubject) for the purpose of experiencing the pleasures and infatuations\n(objects) of the world, or for emancipation. This sutra delineates the\ncharacteristics, actions and uses of nature (prakrti). The three attributes of\nnature are sattva, rajas and tamas.. According to Patanjali, sattva, rajas and\ntamas represent prakasa, kriya and sthiti. These attributes have their own\nvirtues, for instance, prakasa or brilliance or splendour is sattva; kriya or\nstudy, investigation and action is rajas; and the essence of the being resting\nas sthiti or dormancy is tamas. That which is knowable has the nature of\nillumination, activity, and inertia (sattva, rajas and tamas). It consists of\nthe senses and the elements, and exists for the purpose of (providing) either\nliberation or experience (to purusha). All these attributes and virtues are\nestablished in the elements of nature, senses, mind, intelligence and ego.\nTogether they function tunefully in the form of illumination, action and\ninertia, allowing the seer to enjoy the world's pleasures (bhoga); or by\ndivesting himself of them, to experience liberation. &nbsp;The seer is enclothed with five sheaths\n(kosas), by the elements of nature - earth, water, fire, air and ether. Earth\nrepresents the anatomical, water the physiological, fire the mental, air the\nintellectual and ether the spiritual sheaths. The organs of action and senses\nof perception assist the sadhaka in cleansing the anatomical and physiological\nsheaths through yama and niyama. Asana, pranayama and pratyahara divests the\nseer of the mental sheath; dharana and dhyana cleanse the intellectual sheath.\nSamadhi brings the seer out through the shackles of all the sheaths to\nexperience freedom and beatitude. The purpose of the whole of&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nature is for purusha\nto gain experience. &nbsp;At the beginning of\nevolution, Purusha comes in contact with Prakriti which disturbs the\nequilibrium state of the three gunas. The objective of yoga is to harmonize\nrajas and tamas back into sattva which needs to dominate before Purusha can\nrealize it own true nature. This is self-realization. When self-realization is\nattained through a dominant sattva, the other two gunas are not \u2018dead\u2019. They\nare just not active; however, they can be called upon into action if the sattva\nso desires. So, for a realized person, the gunas are under the control of\nsattva and come into play when the consciousness is projected outward. In\nDVAITA Vedanta ( second template ) Rajas and Tamas are two opposite poles mediated\nby Sattwa ( TRINITY ) .</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tamas and Rajas are opposing fields like\npositive and negative while Sattva is neutral.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Dvaita\nHinduism opposite poles Tamas and Rajas are conscious of each other. Tamas\ncreates Rajas, and Rajas activates/ excites Tamas. 7000 year old Vedas say that\nthe only constant in the cosmos is change, everything is in a state of flux,\nnothing is static-- everything is vibratory.&nbsp;\nThis is what guarantees growth and evolution.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\nis a cosmic spiraling dance of&nbsp; separate\nopposing forces, which sustains this universe. No life is possible on earth\nwithout this subtle tension . What has\na front has a back-- what has a beginning has an end. Brahma / Vishnu / Shiva\nwork in tandem and perfect harmony\u2014amazing cosmic allegories personalized as\nHindu Gods.&nbsp;&nbsp; One cannot exist without\nthe other and they are dependant .&nbsp; No\nphenomenon in this universe is completely devoid of its opposite.&nbsp; They consume each other yet support each\nother. Whatever is in excess gets reduces, whatever is deficient gets\nreplenished. You must ponder over each waxing-waning cycle to appreciate the\nabsolute truth . They keep each other in check, yet provide fuel to feed off\neach other.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is a perfect tango of dynamic balance where one\npolar opposite changes into another smoothly and constantly . &nbsp;If the restraining balance or equilibrium is\nlost by the mediator ( Vishnu ) , the universe will spiral out of control and\nend. This is why Lord Vishnu is called the PRESERVER god.&nbsp; As for the opposing forces TAMAS/ RAJAS (\nBrahma/ Shiva ) it really does NOT matter as who is who, like in AC\nelectricity-where you can plug into the socket both ways. This principle of\nDvaita Hinduism -- Tamas Rajas , which are rooted together , is present in\nevery phenomenon on earth.&nbsp; Vedanta has\nrecorded&nbsp; 7000 years ago, that energy\ntransforms from one to another\u2014it can neither be created or destroyed. These\ntwo opposing forces are natural and transform each other , in perfect\nharmony.&nbsp; Harmony can never be stagnant\n.&nbsp; Lessening of Tamas always results in\nincrease of Rajas and vice versa.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Balance can never be\npermanent\u2014 Tamas and Rajas continiously devour each other \u2013 and life flows on.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tamas\ninfluences Rajas not only from inside but also from outside.. they are rooted\ntogether.&nbsp; Tamas and Rajas are connected\nthrough consciousness.&nbsp; It is about the\nquantum possibility wave vibration between two poles.&nbsp; Ancient Vedic Indian rishis &nbsp;firmly believed that the invisible below the\nquantum screen gives rise to the visible.&nbsp;\nSo either Tamas or Rajas is visible \u2013 never both.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Together\nthe TRINITY&nbsp; - THE SECOND TEMPLATE\nexpress the supreme BRAHMAN&nbsp; - THE BASE\nTEMPLATE at absolute peace with itself.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This universe cannot\nexist without vibrations between two poles. To the spiritual eastern mind, the\nstory of SAMUDRA MANTHAN produces amazing acts of faith like the Kumbh Mela ,\nwhich has been going on for 6000 years. The Devas Asuras doing pull and push is\nrepresented by Samudra manthan, where mount Meru is used to churn the oceans\nfor Amrit&nbsp; ( Ambrosia ) in a to and fro\nmovement , representing vibrations- by 54 Asuras and 54 Devas making the number\ndivine Hindu number 108 rooted in Sri Yantra ( 54 triple intersections ) . The\npurpose of the phenomenal world is to provide an experience which helps in the\ngrowth and perfection of the individual centers of consciousness. The final\nrole of the phenomenal world is to provide liberation for the Purusha. It is\nonly through the experiences provided by the bhutas and indriyas that the\nevolution of consciousness can unfold until final liberation happens. Sattva is\nsentience \u2013 knowing (for a subject or organs of knowledge) or capable of being\nknown (for an object of Prakriti); rajas is mutability \u2013 all forms of movement\nand action; tamas is inertia \u2013 latencies and retention. Thus, all internal and\nexternal worlds are made up of the three gunas \u2013 sattva, rajas and tamas. A\nknowable or an object is that which needs association with Purusha for being\nrevealed. The elements (bhutas) and the organs (indriyas) constitute the\nentirety of the world of objects. For the Seer (Purusha), the seen (drishya)\nhas two purposes \u2013 that of providing experience of pleasure and pain, and of\nliberation. Liberation implies that the seer realizes that it is not an object\nor knowable but is separate from all knowables (drishya or Prakriti). Everything,\ninternal or external, is an aggregate of the three gunas. Pleasure and pain are\ncharacteristics of buddhi (intellect). Happiness etc are the objects of\nexperience by the Purusha. Pleasure and pain are a result of the reflected\nconsciousness of Purusha. Giving up both pleasure and pain leads to final\nliberation. Witnessing of and identification with the experience is called\nbondage whereas witnessing the buddhi in liberation is called freedom\n(kaivalya). Yoga enumerates these basic functions of the inner instruments\nwhich are the result of the joint action of the mind and the senses: reception,\nretention, recollection, elimination, conception, and determination. These six\nare present in all states of a fluctuating mind. When the fluctuations of the\nmind stop, these six also come to a stop. As long as the world is manifest, the\nthree gunas are always in flux. They assert themselves in various proportions,\ngiving rise to ever-changing world of manifest forms. The purpose of the gunas\nis to provide either experience of liberation for the purusha. Experience\nconsists in pursuing pleasure and avoiding pain while liberation entails\nrealization by purusha of its own true nature. Bondage is the false\nidentification of purusha with the buddhi. Liberation is the uncoupling of\npurusha from the buddhi. When the buddhi is impure due to the dust of rajas and\ndarkness of tamas, it does not discriminate between the seer and the seen. When\nthe buddhi is purified, the natural illumination of sattva shines through and\nthe distinction between purusha and buddhi becomes clear. Apavarga means a\nstate in which the empowerment of gunas can be abandoned and transmigration\ninto cycles of birth and rebirth etc can be terminated. Hence the word apavarga\nhas been used for \u2018liberation\u2019. Both bhoga (experience) and apavarga\n(liberation) are happening in the buddhi (intellect) since Purusha, in the true\nsense, is simply a witness. As mentioned above, they are attributed to Purusha\nonly because the buddhi functions based on reflected consciousness from the\nPurusha. Apavarga implies that all identification between the Purusha and what\nis happening in the buddhi is severed and Purusha remains as a pure witness.</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.19 -- visheshavisheshalinggamatralinggani\ngunnaparvani</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The gunas generate\ntheir characteristic divisions and energies in the seer. Their stages are\ndistinguishable and non-distinguishable, differentiable and non-differentiable.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This sutra analyses\nnature (prakrti) by distinguishing the progressive layers of its manifestation,\nfrom the most specific and definable, up through the non-specific and\nnon-distinguished and back to the undifferentiated or universal. The individual\ncounterpart of cosmic intelligence (mahat) is consciousness, or citta. Citta\nconsists of mind (manas), which reviews sensory and vibrational stimuli,\nintelligence (buddhi), which is the discriminative faculty and ego or small\nself (ahamkara) which is the individual 'I'. In addition, hidden deep within\nman's nature is a powerful hidden spiritual weapon - 'conscience' (antahkarana\nor dharmendriya) which personifies ethical and moral principles. Antahkarana\nobserves right and wrong in one's conduct and motives, helps to cultivate citta\nand directs it to perform only the righteous actions. There are also the five\nsenses of perception - ears, tongue, eyes, nose and skin, and five organs of\naction - legs, arms, speech, genital and excretory organs. These are the\nprinciples of prakrti. The five elements, intelligence, senses of perception\nand organs of action are distinguishable, i.e., physically manifest in concrete\nform. The other parts, the five subtle manifestations of the elements and the 'I'\nconsciousness (ahamkara, antahkarandand asmita) exist in a non-distinguishable\nor vibrational form, being non-primary and un-evolved matter. Yet, all these\nrevolve around the three gunas of nature - tamas, rajas and sattva. The\nprinciples (tativas) of distinguishable elements (visesa) give rise to changes\nwhich may be pleasant, unpleasant or dazed (a state of suspended or deadened\nsensibility). The unspecified principles (avisesa tattvas) are un-evolved\nmatter, and when such matter is transformed into a specified state, creation\ntakes place. This is called pravrttimarga. The reverse process, mvnti marga, is\nthe unifying of the specified in the unspecified, of the non-specified in and\nof nature into the universal spirit (purusa). The fusing of nature into spirit\nis a heavenly marriage, which becomes possible through the work of yoga.&nbsp; Human mind is a part of that cosmic\nintelligence. Tanmatras, cannot be sensed by ordinary men. If you practice\nYoga, however, says Patanjali, after a while your perception will become so\nfine that you will actually see the Tanmatras. &nbsp;Tanmatra means \u2013 rudimentary or subtle\nelement, merely that, mere essence, potential or only a trifle. There are five\nsense perceptions \u2013 hearing, touch, sight, taste and smell, and there are the\nfive tanmatras corresponding to the five sense perceptions and five\nsense-organs. The tanmatras combine and re-combine in different ways to produce\nthe gross elements \u2013 earth, water, fire, air and ether, which make up the gross\nuniverse perceived by the senses. The senses play their part by coming into contact\nwith the objects, and carry impressions of them to the manas which receives and\narranges them into a precept. The five substantial elements of the physical\nworld are \u2013 ether (Akasha), air (Vayu), fire (Agni or Taijasa), water (Ap) and\nearth (Prithvi) in the order of their development, these are the five Bhutas\nfrom whose unlimited combination everything results including the living bodies\nwhich are material forms living in space and time. According to the Vedic\ntheory of creation, the tanmatras are the basis of all corporeal existences\nbecause from them evolve the Bhutas, the building blocks of the perceptible\nuniverse. The tanmatras, the subtle matter, vibratory, impingent, radiant,\ninstinct with potential energy and collocations of original mass units with\nunequal distributions of original energy, evolve out of the Bhutadi which is\nonly an intermediate state. They have some mass and the energy and physical\ncharacteristics like penetrability, powers of impact, radiant heat and viscous\nattraction etc., and have effect on the sense after assuming the form of\nparamanus or atoms of the Bhutas (the created ones) which process is\nTattavantraparinama or primary evolution. In evolution the total energy always\nremains the same redistributed between causes and effects, the totality of\neffects exists in the totality of causes in the potential form. The\ncollocations and regroupings of the three Gunas (attribute or property) induce\nmore differentiated evolutes; they constitute the changes leading to evolutions\ni.e. from cause to effect, which process is based on Satkaryavada, the doctrine\nthe effect is existent in the cause even before the causal process has started\nto produce the effect operating in accordance with the two laws of conservation\nof matter and energy. According to Satkaryavada &nbsp;theory the effect is existent in the cause;\nthe original cause of everything that is perceived is Prakriti. Satkaryavada is\na hypothesis according to which the effect pre-exists in a potential state. The\ncausal process involves a modification of a stable underlying reality. The\neffect is not produced as a reality that is distinct from its underlying cause.\nIt is a specific rearrangement of that causal substrate. The Samkhya system is\nbased on the principle of Satkaryavada. The effect pre-exists in the cause\nhere. Cause and effect are seen as temporal aspects of the same thing. It is\nconsidered as theory of existent causes. The effect lies latent in the cause\nwhich in turn seeds the next effect. It maintains that effect is real. Before\nits manifestation it is present cause in a potential form. According to\nSatkaryavada principle the cause is hidden inside the effect. This effect\nexists due to several reasons- 1.what is nonexistent cannot be produced; 2.for\nproducing a specific material cause is resorted to; 3.everything cannot be\nproduced; 4.a specific material cause is capable of producing a specific\nproduct alone that effect; 5.there is a particular cause for a particular\neffect. Adi Sankaracharya found Satkaryavada as a useful tool against the\ndoctrine of Annica or momentariness. Two branches of Satkaryavada are\nvivartavada and parinamavada. The four stages of the gunas mentioned in this\nsutra correspond to the four stages of samadhi mentioned in sutra 1.17. Thus:Vishesha\n\u2013 Vitarka (Manomaya kosha) Avishesha \u2013 Vichara (Vijnananamaya Kosha) Linga \u2013\nAnanda (Anandamaya Kosha) Alinga \u2013 Asmita (Atma/soul).&nbsp; The visheshas (diversified) are the sixteen\nmutations \u2013 five bhutas (earth, water, fire, air and space)---five organs of\naction (arms, legs, tongue, organs of excretion, organs of reproduction)---five\norgans of sense perception (eyes, ears, skin, tongue, nose)---mind . Attributes\nlike blue, red, sweet, sour etc are vishesha (diversified). The vishesha can be\npleasant, unpleasant and stuporous. The avishesha (undiversified) are six in\nnumber:--the five tanmatras (sense of smell, taste, touch, sight, hearing) asmita\n(ego) which is the cause of the organs and tanmatras. Mahat (buddhi or\nintellect) is called \u2018linga-matra\u2019 (indicator only) which means that it is an\nindicator for Purusha and Prakriti. Prakriti, in the unmanifest state, is\n\u2018alinga\u2019, which is not the indicator of anything.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhoomiraapo\u2019nalo vaayuh\nkham mano buddhireva cha;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ahamkaara iteeyam me\nbhinnaa prakritirashtadhaa.--<b> Bhagavad Gita (7:4) 4000 BC</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cEarth, water, fire,\nair, ether, mind, reason and egoism \u2013 these constitute the eightfold division\nof My Nature\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ordinary water, earth\netc do not constitute the bhutas (elements). That whose feature is sound is\nAkasha (space). Similarly touch goes with Vayu (air), sight with Tejas (fire),\ntaste with Apa (water), and smell with Kshiti (earth). Akasha is the cause of Vayu,\nVayu is the cause of Tejas, Tejas is the cause of Apa, and water is the cause\nof Kshiti. Because of this cause and effect, an object of the sense of smell is\nthe receptacle of all five properties. An object of the sense of taste that of\nfour (except smell), sight that of three, touch that of two and hearing that of\none property only.Perception of smell comes from contact with particles of\nmatter (earth/kshiti). Taste arises from chemical action caused by a liquid\nsubstance (water/aap). From heat (fire/agni) comes perception of color\n(sight/vision). Feeling of touch results from contact with gaseous matter\n(air/vayu). With the sense of sound arises a sense of emptiness or void\n(space/akasha). The five bhutas (gross elements) like earth, fire etc are the\nVisheshas of the five tanmatras. Visheshas represent three characteristics:To\nindicate the diversities of the notes of the scales of sound; heat, cold,\nhardness etc (touch), blue, yellow etc (fire/light), sweet, sour etc (taste),\npleasant, pungent etc (smell). These diversities result in states of happiness,\nmisery or indifference. These bhutas are the lowest form of mutation and are\nnot the cause of any further modifications. The word \u2018tanmatra\u2019 means \u2018that\nalone\u2019 \u2013 sound alone, touch alone etc. That is, subtle sound, without any\nvariation or diversity is the sound tanmatra. Same is the case with other\ntanmatras. When meditated upon, the subtle perception of each tanmatra appears\nonly as a flow of time. All the tanmatras have emanated from Asmita (ego). Asmita\n(ego) is the pretentious feeling relating to self. Asmita also refers to the\npure I-sense, buddhi, which is the subtlest form of egoism. Combination of\none\u2019s ego with the organs of perception creates I-sense which is called\nAbhimana.Organs represent different modifications of asmita. Knowledge of\nlight, for example, implies the sense of identification of the Knower with the\nsensation of light. This feeling \"I am the knower of light\" is the\nego called Asmita. Mahat or buddhi is the awareness that \"I exist\" or\npure \"I-sense\". Modifications like \"I am the hearer\" etc is\nthe modification of \"I\" and is termed ego or Ahamkara. Mahat tattwa\n(element) is the cause for Ahamkara. The Mahat principle gives rise to the six\nAvisheshas \u2013 Asmita (ahamkara) followed by the five tanmatras.At the time of\ndissolution, all elements disappear in the reverse order of creation. Finally,\nMahat disappears into the unmanifest (Avyakta) prakriti. All manifested objects\nlike Mahat etc are created to serve the two-fold purpose of Purusha (sutra\n2.18). Unmanifest Prakriti, however, is eternally present, and is not created\nbecause it has no purpose to serve for the Purusha. Objects like Mahat are\nbeginning-less; however, they are not without an end \u2013 they end when the purpose\nof Purusha (attaining the state of Kailvalya) has been served. All objects are\nthe product of the three Gunas (sattva, rajas and tamas). Gunas are always\npresent in Prakriti. The unmanifest state is one of equilibrium of the three\ngunas. At the time of dissolution, when the objects merge back into Prakriti,\nthere is no dissolution for the gunas; they just merge back into Prakriti. The\ncategory \u2018vishesha\u2019 refers to the final evolutes that do not produce further\nproducts or evolutes. The category \u2018avishesha\u2019 refers to those evolutes that\nproduce the final \u2018vishesha\u2019 evolutes. So, the five elements \u2013 earth, water,\nfire, air and ether are the vishesha evolutes of the avishesha \u2013 sound, touch,\ntaste, sight and smell. Avishesha also includes \u2018ahankara\u2019 (ego) which is\nresponsible for these evolutes \u2013 five organs of action (speech, hands, feet,\nanus, and genitals), five organs of perception (ears, eyes, skin, tongue, and\nnose) and the mind. The \u2018linga-matra\u2019, literally mark or a sign only, category\nrefers to \u2018mahat\u2019 or \u2018buddhi\u2019 (the cosmic intellect) which is a mark or a sign\nfor prakriti. Buddhi is like the root of a tree. It is the closest to the seed\nthat produced it&nbsp; and is also the cause\nof trunk, leaves, branches etc. Buddhi is also a transformation of the gunas.\nIt represents pure \u2018beingness\u2019. Vyasa says that it is neither existence nor\nnon-existence, neither real nor unreal. The final category, the subtlest of\nall, is prakriti itself which has been called \u2018alinga\u2019 (not a mark or symbol\nfor anything). There is no sign to discern prakriti until there is disturbance\nin the balance of the gunas which results in the first evolute \u2018mahat\u2019.\nPrakriti is eternal whereas all its evolutes are temporary manifestations of\nprakriti. Everything that one experiences in manifest reality, including the\nsubtlest level of viveka (discrimination) is taking place in the buddhi. In the\nalinga state, the gunas are balanced and cannot fulfill the objectives of\nPurusha \u2013 namely, experience and liberation (sutra 2.18). In that sense they\nmay seem \"non-existent\". However, the gunas are capable of producing\neffects (evolutes) and hence can be termed \"existent\". Comparing\nthese Samkhya concepts with those of the Vedanta school, we notice that in\nVedanta, prakriti, the gunas and the entire manifest world are all mental\nconstructs and mere superimpositions of templates on the only real existent,\nBrahman. On the other hand, as per Samkhya and Yoga, prakriti is existent, real\nand eternal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.20 --</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">drashta\ndrishimatrah shuddhopi pratyayanupashyah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The seer is pure\nconsciousness. He witnesses nature without being reliant on it.&nbsp; </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The seer ( unlike a\nschizophrenic ) has a clear boundary between the real physical world and the\ninvisible world.. This sutra moves on from nature to soul, the Supreme Seer,\nthe absolute knower. It is the pure essence of consciousness beyond words.\nThough the soul is pure, it is liable to see through its agent, the\nintelligence (buddhi) and being carried away by the manipulation of nature, it\nloses its identity. The previous sutra dealt with nature (prakrti) and\ndiscernible objects. Here, the nature of the seer, the soul (purusa) is\ndescribed. Atma, drasta and drsimatrah are terms which illustrates the innate\nnature of the seer. Intelligence obscures consciousness in such a way that it\ncomes to identify itself as the true seer and forgets the soul. But if\nintelligence can keep its power of discernment, consciousness too will remain\nuncoloured. If consciousness is clear, the seer is un-obscured. Intelligence,\nbelonging as it does to manifest nature, is constantly in the process of\nchange, sometimes conscious and often unconscious. It is subject to sattva,\nrajas and tamas, while the seer, purusa, is beyond all these, immutable and\never-conscious.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When you use psychic power you tap into\nthe level of the universe, where individuality does not exist. At this level\neach of us is a part of a universal and cosmic consciousness where we are\nconnected as though held together by invisible threads.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By\nlearning to project your will and change your vibration through altering the\nstate of your consciousness , you will begin to develop psychic powers.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nexpanded abilities of self awareness is abstract reasoning, free will,\ncreativity, foresight etc.&nbsp;&nbsp; Our culture\nis oriented towards reducing one\u2019s self awareness rather than expanding it.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most\npeople never raise their consciousness much above that of the beast and the\nspark of divinity within them remains dormant the whole of their lives .\nPerception occurs in the gap of alert attention. This is the inner space. When\nyou visit new places , the experiencing and sense perception takes up more of\ntheir consciousness than thinking .</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You can create a gap in\nthe mind stream simply by directing the focus of your attention into the\nNOW.&nbsp; Consciousness enables us to think\nand at the same time observe our thinking process.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nbrain without consciousness is inert and lifeless.&nbsp; Consciousness is a form of matter just as\nmatter is a form of consciousness. All atoms in the entire universe are capable\nof mind reading and communicating with other atoms. Our consciousness is a\ncosmic DVD player.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">India there is the ancient tradition of\nthe enlightened sage, the one who breaks free of ordinary human conditioning\nand attains a state called \"awakening By various means such as deep\nmeditation or by pure devotion, or by the control and understanding of the mind\nthese historical figures broke through into universal consciousness itself, and\nbeyond that even, into the pure awareness of the absolute. They experienced a\nquantum leap and a arrived a state that cannot be defined and described. People\nsimply called them the enlightened ones. Cosmic Consciousness lies in a mystic\nstate above and beyond Self-consciousness, which is an acute sense of\nself-awareness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 150%;\">2.21 -- tadarth eva drishyasyatma</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The very existence of\nthe seen is for the sake of the seer.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nature and intelligence\nexist solely to serve the seer's true purpose - emancipation.&nbsp; Intelligence exists to serve as the seer's\nagent, to liberate the consciousness from avidya. If the sadhaka slackens in\nhis sadhana and becomes inattentive, the senses agitate the seer and he is\nagain hitched within the pleasures of the senses. This study of mind and\ninvestigation through intelligence is the innermost pursuit - antaratma\nsadhana. This sutra conveys that consciousness, the essence of nature, which is\ncognisable, exists for the sake of the seer who sees for the sake of seeing. &nbsp;As a dancer,&nbsp;\nafter having performed for the observer , stops dancing, so does Prak\u1e5bti\ncease to perform for an individual Puru\u1e63ha when her task is accomplished\u2014a corner\nstone of Samkhya Vedanta . The dancing girl dances as long as the male observer\nis there. The moment the observer ceases to look at her and understands the\ndance perfectly, she fails to amuse him anymore. Purusha, or supreme\nconsciousness ( BrahmAn ) , is the impassive observer of all phenomena. She\nmoves from transcendence to immanence and undergoes a series of transformations\nthrough which the multiform world comes into being.&nbsp; Purusha, was never really in bondage, or\nenmeshed with Prakriti.&nbsp; Prakriti cannot\nbe perceived, not because of its non-existence, but because of its subtlety. It\nis perceived in its effects. Sankhya&nbsp;\naccepts the principle of satkarya-vada, i.e. the effect exists in cause.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ignorant\ndifferentiate between Sankhya and Yoga; not the wise. He who considers the two\nas integrated has the right insight <b>\u2013\nBhagawat Gita (5.4) 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I have said before that\ntwo paths are available in this world - Yoga of knowledge as followed by the Samkhyas\nand Yoga of action as practiced by the Yogins .\u2013 <b>Bhagawat Gita (3.3)- 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The root cause\n(Brahman) is to be apprehended by Samkhya-yoga - <b>Svetasvatara Upanisad (6.13) -5000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is no wisdom like\nSamkhya \u2013 <b>Mahabharata 4000 BC<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Samnkhya, direct\nperception is the most important and fundamental source of all knowledge. When\nsenses cannot directly perceive due to their limitations, inference is needed\nsuch as in philosophical disputations. The very existence of Purusa ( BrahmAn \u2013\nmorphogenetic consciousness ) is possible only through inference. Patanjali\ndrew heavily upon Sankhya philosophy in the development of his Yoga Sutras, and\nmany of the practical methods and techniques of yoga rest on Sankhya's\nphilosophical foundations. . Yoga is&nbsp; a\ncomplete exercise program for body,&nbsp; mind\nand spirit.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">SaMkhya and SaNkhya is\nsame .</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Samkhya as you can see was a\nmasterpiece of modeling the ways of the inner universe. Maharishi Kapila said\nthat the universe arose through the union of nature (prakriti) and\nconsciousness (purusha).</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of all trees I am the\nbanyan tree, and of the sages among the demigods I am Narada. Of the Gandharvas\nI am Citraratha, and among perfected beings I am the sage Kapila.- <b>Bhagawat Gita (10.26)<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sankhya unified the two\nconcepts of science and religion by demonstrating its equivalence through\naxiomatic laws. The Sankhya system is based on Sat-k\u0101rya-v\u0101da or the theory of\ncausation. According to Satk\u0101ryav\u0101da, the effect is pre-existent in the cause. Philosophical\ntexts from this era such as the Katha Upanishad, Shvetashvatara Upanishad and\nBhagavad Gita have clear references to Sankhyan terminology and concepts. The\nSankhya system is an evolutionary theory of matter beginning with primordial\nmatter. In evolution, Prakriti is transformed and differentiated into\nmultiplicity of objects. Evolution is followed by dissolution. In dissolution\nthe physical existence, all the worldly objects mingle back into Prakriti,\nwhich now remains as the undifferentiated, primordial substance.&nbsp; Tantric system borrows the abstract dualism\nof Sankhya and modifies it into a personified male\u2013female dualism. The white\ninvader converted Tantra into debauched sex. As we evolve, the spirit will\ncontrol the mind and body to determine our thoughts, words and actions. At the\napex of evolution, the mind takes its cues from the spirit and the body from\nthe mind.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.22\u2014 kritarthan prati\nnashtam apyanashtan tadanyasadharannatvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The relationship with\nnature ceases for emancipated beings, its purpose having been satiated, but its\nprocesses continue to affect others</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As soon as the vehicles\nof nature which act as agents of the seer fulfill their task of freeing him\nfrom his mental and sensory prison, they are stilled, having reached their\npurpose. The bond between the seer and nature comes to a culmination. Nature\nceases to exist for him. He is able to perceive his own form (svarupa). However,\nthe vehicles of nature, elements, their subtle qualities, cosmic intelligence,\nindividual self, ego, intelligence, senses of perception and organs of action\nare common to all, so for others, who remain caught up in the world's\ncommotions, the bondage lives on. In the thirteenth chapter of the Bhagavad\nGita, the one who sees the field (prakriti) as distinct from the knower of the\nfield (purusha) is called wise. Krishna advises Arjuna that \"He who sees\nhimself not to be the doer, he sees indeed (Bhagawad Gita &nbsp;XIII:29). When the seer is perceived as\ndistinct from the \"I\" that claims, the yogin then loses interest in\nthe generation of compulsive citta-vrittis (mind chatter ).. Nothing is claimed\nby the \"I\". With this movement the sediment of prior conditioning\n(samskara) is cleared away; objects shine forth devoid of inherent, defined\nform (svarupa-sunya); the consciousness-of or \"I-vs.-that\"\nconsciousness has retreated; pure witnessing takes place. In this state of pure\nconsciousness, attention cannot be separated from the intended: awareness is\nboth subject-free (anahamvadi) and object-free (nirvastuka). Yoga may thus be\ndefined not as a union of appropriating self with objects, even religious\nobjects of appropriation, nor as Cartesian separation of thinker from thought,\nbut rather as a moment in which there is the nonseparation of knower, knowing,\nand known. The point of yoga is to have direct access to the intended world\nwithout the interference of impure residues. Yoga seeks to sever projects,\npresent from a time without beginning, that obscure direct perception through\nthe seer. the yogi excises a part of his corpus of being--citta vritti--so that\nthe unseen seer, the witness, may be known. 'Mind' is not a proper English\ntranslation of what the Yoga calls 'Chitta', especially in the system of\nPatanjali. The entire mind-stuff is called Chitta. It is better to use the word\n'psyche' instead of the word 'mind', because the former denotes a larger\ncomposite structure than the single function indicated by the word 'mind'. Mind\nis that which thinks in an indeterminate manner; the intellect is that which\nthinks in a determinate manner; the ego is that which asserts the individuality\nof one's own self. There are other functions of the psyche such as memory,\noften associated with the subconscious level. It is impossible for anyone to be\naware that something is outside, unless there is an isolated thinking or an\nindividualising principle, known in the Vedanta psychology as the Antahkarana,\nand in the Yoga psychology of Patanjali as Chitta. \"Antahkarana\" is a\nSanskrit term, which literally translated into English, would mean, \"the\ninternal organ\". That is perhaps the best way we can put it in English.\nThe internal organ, by which we cognise or perceive things outside, is the\nAntahkarana. The same thing is called Chitta in Yoga psychology. Yoga is\ncontrol of the mind, restraint of the mind-stuff. Yoga is\nChitta-vritti-nirodhah. As a word, vritti means literally vortex (of\nconsciousness), or \"circular activity with no beginning and no end\". Training\nin yoga in the larger sense \u2013 namely, concentration, attention, and meditation\n\u2013 can help stop these fluctuations and quiet the chatter, so that you can get\nin touch with a truer sense of self, and a more peaceful, watchful sort of\nawareness. In the context of Hinduism and yoga, vrittis refer to different\ntendencies, or psycho-physical propensities, which give scope for the mind to\nexpress a variety of feelings and emotions. Hindu texts describe samskaras to\nbe a result of past actions and experiences that have left an imprint on the\nmind. The expression of samskaras gives rise to vrittis, which collectively\nrepresent the behaviour that makes each person unique: their desires and\nrepulsions, their predispositions and complexes.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purusha is the\nWitness. Prakriti produces effects for his enjoyment. Purusha is \u2018solitary,\nneutral, a spectator, and non-agent\u2019 (Samkhya Karika). Purusha is solitary\nbecause even though as consciousness he is the Witness to the effects produced\nby Prakriti and her three gunas, Purusha remains pure and untouched.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nthree gunas are born of Prakriti. It is their imbalance that causes the\nwheels-within-wheels to turn and produce the hologram. After a cyclical\nDissolution of the world the gunas return to and remain in a state of perfect\nbalance until next time of Creation. Purusha abides in Prakriti (prakritsthas)\nas Witness to the effects of her gunas (Bhagawad Gita .XIII.21).</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even\nthough Purusha as Witness remains untouched by the gyrations and effects of\nPrakriti\u2019s gunas, Purusha temporarily mistakes these \u2018transformations\u2019 as his\nown.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purusha\nwrongly assumes that he is the \u2018agent\u2019 of Prakriti\u2019s manifestations. The\nSamkhya Karika states that it is his proximity with Prakriti that causes this\nfalse impression. In the process of his enjoyment of the world, Purusha begins\nto consider the polarities of pleasure-and-pain (sukha-duhkha), etc. as his\nown. This confusion, caused by attachment, eventually makes Purusha realize\nthat he has become bound in the webs of Maya that are produced by Prakriti's\ngunas.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Therefore\nafter experiencing pain, Purusha realizes that he has become attached\n(guna-sangas) to those polarities which are the cause of the endless cycles of\nbirth and death in both good and evil wombs (sad-asad-yoni-janmasu).</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nAtman enters into human bodies and becomes Purusha, which is Consciousness.\nThere Purusha \u2018correlates\u2019 with the Unmanifest principle Prakriti, which is not\nconscious but has the female power (Shakti) to produce and manifest this\npolarity universe through the three gunas. The proximity - a sort of illusory\nunion - of Purusha to Prakriti causes Purusha to forget his real state, which\nin reality is not capable of being affected by Prakriti\u2019s changes; and he\nbegins to mistake these effects, pleasure-and-pain (sukha-duhkha), as his own.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Krishna\ntells Arjuna that the one who Knows from direct experience (vetti) this\ntemporal and actually nonexistent \u2018correlation\u2019 between Purusha the real Self\nas Atman and the unreal Prakriti who produces the illusory, is not born again!\nKnowledge of the Real brings release from endless transmigration ( Bhagawad\nGita XIII.23).</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purusha is the Witness and experiencer.\nPrakriti works through the three gunas and the five senses to produce what\nPurusha experiences. Purusha would not develop this Discriminative Wisdom\nwithout Prakriti providing the experiences of pleasure (sukha) and pain\n(duhkha), etc.Purusha becomes indifferent ...The game is over once Purusha\nrealizes the mechanics of their \u2018correlation\u2019 through his newly acquired\nDiscriminative Wisdom. He recognizes that she is distinct from him. He comes to\nknow her. The text says literally that she is \u2018seen\u2019 by him (maya drsta) and\ntherefore he becomes indifferent (iti upeksha-kah).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The one (Purusha)\nthinks: \u2018she has been seen by me\u2019 and therefore loses all interest; the other\n(Prakriti) thinks \u2018I have been seen\u2019 and ceases to act further. Therefore, even\nif there is still connection there is no motive for further evolution.---\nSamkhya Karika, Verse 66.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The writer of the Samkhya Karika\ncompares Prakriti to a maiden who is modest in the sense of being extremely\ndelicate with an acute sensitivity and \u2018who cannot bear exposure to the prying\nglance of a stranger ... Having been seen [recognized] once by the Purusha\nthrough discrimination, will in no case expose herself again.\u2019&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">My opinion is that\nnothing is more modest than the Prakriti: Knowing&nbsp; that \u2018I have been seen,\u2019 she no more comes\nwithin the sight of Purusha.---- Samkhya Karika, Verse 61.While this comparison\nobviously is taken from another time when women of noble descent were not\npermitted to be seen by strangers or even the sun, the meaning is conveyed that\nfor Prakriti the performance is over and she will not continue her dance. The\ngunas will cease their allure and stop the show.Destroyed like a burnt up seed\n...</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We\nare told that perfect Knowledge is attained by this \u2018recognition\u2019 and\nafterwards Purusha \u2018continues to live for a while invested with the body, just\nlike a potter\u2019s wheel continuing to revolve, even when the potter ceases in his\nefforts at revolving the wheel due to the momentum of the past impulse\u2019\n(Samkhya Karika 67).,,The attainment of \u2018direct knowledge\u2019 causes the \u2018entire\nstock of subliminal impressions of deeds,\u2019 which are the fuel of repeated\nbirths, to get \u2018destroyed like a burnt up seed, and no more produces any fruit\nin the form of experiences of rebirth, life, etc.\u2019\u2018 ... is not born again\u2019.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.23\u2014 svasvamishaktyoh\nsvaroopopalabdhihetuh sanyogah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The conjunction of the\nseer with the seen is for the seer to discover his own nature.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The powers of purusa\nand prakrti are designated for Self-Realisation. The purpose of their contact\nis the blossoming of their innate powers, and the seer's discovery of his own\nessential nature. &nbsp;This sutra makes clear\nthat a desire for synthesis or a close association or assimilation between the\nowner, the 'owning' and the owned has existed since the beginning of\ncivilization. By the light of pure knowledge, the owner, the seer, perceives\nand cognises whatever is to be perceived or cognised through his association\nwith nature. If this association is fed by ignorance, it leads the master\ntowards enjoyment, desire, and complaints, and ties him down. But if\nnon-attachment is garnered, it leads to detachment or renunciation - vairagya. If\nthe master maintains constant vigilant awareness of his consciousness,\nassociates with nature without attachment and stays a witness, nature (prakrti)\nleads its owner, the soul, to freedom \u2013 moksa. The cause of our painor pleasure\nis always our joining ourselves with the body.Samyoga is connection or an\nintimate union between the mind and the being or Purusha, which allows the\nPurusha to observe the outside world. It is another story that although the\nexperience is happening outside of the Purusha, this very union causes the Purusha\nto associate and attach with the experience and get dragged around by it. &nbsp;&nbsp;Rather than simply observing, when the\nPurusha gets attached to the experience due to the samyoga, that is the root\ncause of suffering. The union of Owner (Purusha) and owned (Prakiti) causes the\nrecognition of the nature and powers of them both. Union is necessary for the\nPurusha to realize himself with the help of Prakriti. When apart, they don\u2019t\nexpress themselves. Through the Prakriti we realize that we are the Purusha. Perceiving\nthe worldly objects is experience and perception of the real nature of the seer\nis liberation. Ignorance is the cause of the union between the seer and the\nseen whereas true knowledge dispels ignorance.&nbsp;\nTrue knowledge is not the real cause of liberation, but technically it\nis the absence of ignorance that results in liberation. Full liberation is a\nstep beyond discriminative intelligence and involves complete separation\nbetween purusha and buddhi. Prakriti, or buddhi, shows ignorance as it needs\npurusha for its functioning. &nbsp;&nbsp;Purusha,\ntoo appears to have \u2018adarshana\u2019 as it needs to provide illumination to the\nbuddhi. In sutra 2.17 Patanjali states that \"union between purusha and\nprakriti is the cause of the suffering that can and should be avoided\". &nbsp;Now in sutra 2.23 we note that \"this\nunion between purusha and prakriti is REQUIRED to understand the true nature of\nthe powers of both purusha and prakriti\".&nbsp;\nSo, it seems as if this union is both good and bad depending upon how we\nlook at it. My understanding is that it causes suffering when we are only\ninterested in the \u2018experience\u2019 of the material world. On the other hand this\nunion can lead to kaivalya if start working on developing discriminatory wisdom\nand finally realize the separation between purusha and prakriti.
