Pleasurable experiences spawns\ngreed and lust, which strengthen attachment and provokes a greater passion, as\none always wants more and more. One becomes absorbed by the pursuit of\npleasure, and addicted to satiation of the senses. The aspirer may thus forget\nhis chosen path and allow himself to be caught up in sorrow and sickness.&nbsp; When Consciousness appears to be an\nindividual, which happens after the veils of avidya and asmita are added, it\ncan look at the rest of the apparent manifestation and start to like parts of\nit. When a sensory impression comes into the mind and ahamkara colors it with\nlike, with attraction, it means the another veil is added, namely that of raga.\nThis adds another false identity to \u201cme\u201d, because it is the appearance of \u201cI\u201d\nwho likes, so anything colored with raga is immediately related to me.</span> &nbsp;<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;These are the things we want to do, keep,\nhave, feel, experience.&nbsp; In modern terms,\nit\u2019s much like the pleasure principle \u2013 there\u2019s a strong attraction to what\nbrings instant pleasure and gratification. Sometimes, we want these pleasurable\nthings so much that we cling to them when we have them.&nbsp; Raga causes us to endlessly chase after our\ndesires. &nbsp;&nbsp;Raga keeps us unsatisfied even\nwhen what we want is in our lap, either by trying to retain it or by the\nimpulse to want more.&nbsp; We cling like a\nbarnacle to the things that we\u2019re comfortable with and make us feel good when\nRaga asserts itself.&nbsp; Raga can cause\nrestlessness, despair, and havoc in the mind. Raga and Dvesha are two sides of\nthe same coin<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.08\u2014 duhkhanushayi\ndveshah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">That repulsion which\naccompanies pain is Dvesa</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pain, sorrow and misery\nspark off a chain of hate or loathing. Recalling lost pleasures, excruciated by\ndesires unfulfilled, man is driven towards sorrow. In utmost anguish he comes\nto hate himself, his family, neighbours and surroundings, and feels a sense of\nworthlessness. A discriminating person endeavours to acquire knowledge, so that\nhe may strike a balance between sukha and duhkha and live at the mercy of\nneither pleasure nor pain. We run away from conceived pain. .</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When\nthe Ragas and Dveshas rear their heads, try to see them for what they are \u2013\ncolors that you are painting over external things.&nbsp; Dvesha is repulsion felt towards a person or\nobject which is a source of unhappiness. Raga and dvesha go together \u2013 they are\nlike the opposite sides of the same coin. &nbsp;Raga and dvesha which bind us to external\nobjects condition our life in such a way that we begin to think, feel and act\naccording to these biases. Raga and dvesha bind us down to the lower levels of\nconsciousness where consciousness functions under the greatest limitations. Dvesha\nbinds us the same way as raga. We are tied to the person we hate even more than\nthe person we love since it is more difficult to transmute the force of hatred.&nbsp; Every morning detractors of my blogsite dwell\non each word I write and corrode in their own juices.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some\nminds hang on you through Raga, while some others hang on you through Dvesha. &nbsp;Vairagya is not just freedom from raga but\nequally from dvesha. Raga and dvesha belong to the vehicles (elements of\nprakriti) but owing to avidya we associate us with them. These are responsible\nfor much of human misery. Aversion is the feeling of opposition, propensity to\nhurt and anger towards misery or object producing misery, arising from\nrecollection of misery experienced before. As in Raga, the latencies of misery\nare falsely attributed to the self and the inactive self is regarded as the doer.&nbsp; In the Bhagavad Gita there is a often-quoted\npassage (shlokas 2.62-63), sometimes referred to as \"the ladder of\ndestruction\" . --\"Repeated focus on an object results in affection\n\u2018sanga\u2019. From affection results strong desire \u2018kama\u2019.&nbsp; If you are not able to satisfy the desire or\nkama you will end up with anger \u2018krodha\u2019. Increased anger results in increased\nego and focus on the inner self \u2018sammoha\u2019. When this happens, past experience\n\u2018smriti\u2019 is forgotten and a person loses judgement \u2018smriti vibramaha\u2019. Lack of\njudgement results in destruction of wisdom \u2018buddhi nashaha\u2019 and finally the\nperson is lost \u2018pranashyati\u2019.\" But, moving amidst (unavoidable) sense\nobjects with sense organs which are under control and which are free from likes\n(raga) and dislikes (dvesha), a man of self-control enjoys tranquility.However,\nit becomes a \u2018raga\u2019 (attachment) only when that desire becomes a craving (addiction\n&nbsp;like porn ) and results in suffering if\nnot fulfilled. &nbsp;If we can develop an\nattitude of indifference to the outcome of a desire, then having a desire is\nnot bad.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Raga (attraction), Dvesha (repulsion) and Tatastha\nVritti (indifference) are the three important Vrittis of the mind. Raga and\nDvesha (like and dislike or love and hatred or attraction and repulsion) are\nthe two currents in the mind which bind a man to the Samsaric wheel of birth\nand death. Raga and Dvesha are the two Doshas or faults in the mind that have\nbrought you to this world. The Svarupa of Bandha (bondage) is Raga and Dvesha.\nThe Svarupa of Ajnana is Raga and Dvesha. All the emotions come under the\ncategory of Raga-Dvesha. These two currents are the Dharma (characteristics) of\nthe mind and not of the spirit. Pleasure and pain, Harsha and Soka,\nexhilaration and depression are due to Raga-Dvesha. If Raga and Dvesha vanish\nfrom the mind, Harsha-Soka also will disappear.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fear is hidden\nin Raga. When you have got Raga for body, fear of death comes in. When you have\nRaga for money, there is fear of losing money, as money is the means of getting\nobjects of enjoyment. When you have Raga for a beautiful woman, you become obsessed\nin protecting her. Fear is a very old, intimate friend of Raga.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Raga-Dvesha\nhas four Avasthas, viz., Dagdha (burnt up), Tanu (attenuated or thinned out),\nVicchinna (concealed) and Udara (fully expanded). The first two states pertain\nto a Yogin; the last two to worldlings. In a fully developed Yogin, the Vrittis\nof Raga-Dvesha are burnt up by Nirvikalpa Samadhi. They are Dagdha (like\nburnt-up seeds).</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mind is set in motion or\nvibration through the currents of Raga-Dvesha, real Karmas begin. Real Karma\noriginates from Sankalpas of the mind. It is the actions of the mind that are\ntruly termed Karmas. External actions manifest later on. It is desire that sets\nthe mind in motion. When there is a desire, Raga and Dvesha exist side by side\nin the mind. Desire is a motive force. Emotions and impulses co-exist with\ndesire.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That\nYogin or Jnanin who has destroyed these two Vrittis of Raga and Dvesha is the\nhighest man in the three worlds. He is the real King of kings, Emperor of\nemperors.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even if a Jnanin or Yogin sometimes exhibits traces\nof anger, it is Abhasamatra (mere appearance). Just as the impression made in\nwater with a stick passes away soon, as also the anger will disappear in the\ntwinkling of an eye, even though it manifests in a Jnanin. This can hardly be\nunderstood by worldly people.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He who has no Raga but possesses\nTitiksha (power of endurance) can do anything. He can move about wherever he\nlikes.. His happiness, freedom and peace are unbounded. Their extent can hardly\nbe imagined. The freedom and joy of such Sannyasins cannot be imagined by the\npoor, petty-minded worldlings. It is Raga and luxury that have enfeebled the householders\nwho must keep up with the Joneses and must get an invite for a page 3 party. Destroy\nthe true modifications of the mind, Raga-Dvesha, by Vichara and Brahma-Chintana\n(right thinking and meditation). Go beyond the Dvandvas (pairs of opposites).\nYou will get eternal, infinite bliss and peace. Amongst the several Vrittis in\nthe mind, FAALTHU &nbsp;Raga-Dvesha and Moha\nare very deep-rooted. They demand strenuous and persistent efforts for their\neradication.&nbsp; Remember the opposing forces\nwhich forces you into bad karma.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.09\u2014 svarasavahi\nvidushopi tatharoodho bhiniveshah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Self-preservation or\nattachment to life is the subtlest of all afflictions. It is found even in wise\nmen.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Abhinivesha is a layer\nof fear that is added on top of an attraction (raga) or an aversion (dvesha).Patanjali\nindicates that every human being has had a taste of death, which lurks. This\nimpress is the seed of fear. Abhinivesa is an intuitive defect which can be\ntransformed into intuitive knowledge and insight by practising yoga. While\npractising asana, pranayama or dhyana, the sadhaka penetrates deep within\nhimself. He experiences unity in the flow of intelligence, and the current of\nself-energy. In this state, he perceives that there is no difference between\nlife and death, that they are simply two sides of the same coin. He understands\nthat the current of self, the life-force, active while he is alive, unites with\nthe universe when it leaves his body at death. Through this understanding, he\nloses his fixation for life and conquers the fear of death. This liberates him\nfrom afflictions and sorrows and leads him towards kaivalya. If avidya is the\nroot cause of afflictions, so abhinivesa results in pain. In realising the\noneness of life and death there is an end to ignorance in the aspirer, and he\nlives forever in the flow of tranquillity.A person becomes wise only when all\nthe five kleshas have been completely eradicated. The second point in the sutra\nis that this desire for life is \u2018swarasavahi\u2019 which means it is sustained by\nits own inherent force. Abhinivesha is merely the final manifestation of all\nthe kleshas.&nbsp; Raga (attractions) and\ndvesha (repulsions) are the immediate cause of abhinivesha. Thus, stronger are\nthe likes and dislikes, more prominently noticeable will be the desire for life\nor fear of death.Abhinivesha is a result of the past memory of death.&nbsp; Even animals fear death.&nbsp; &nbsp;Since\ndeath happened in a past life, this sutra establishes previous lives.If it be\ntrue that all our knowledge has come from experience, then it is sure that that\nwhich we never experienced we cannot imagine, or understand. Even a new-born animal&nbsp; is afraid of death. This can only be\nexplained by a latent impression (samskara) of a previous experience of death. The\nword abhinivesha is a compound word derived from the root word \u2018vish\u2019 (to\nenter), preceded by the two prefixes \u2018abhi\u2019 and \u2018ni\u2019. The literal meaning of\nthe word is \u2018strong desire to hold on to something\u2019. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the context of this sutra it represents a\nstrong desire to cling to life with the extended meaning of \u2018fear of death\u2019. &nbsp;Essentially the word may mean any kind of\nfear. This klesha is a result of the previous two kleshas \u2013 raga (attraction)\nand dvesha (repulsion). Raga leads to the fear of losing something that we\ndesire to hold on to, or the fear of not being able to get what we strongly\ndesire. Dvesha leads to the fear of getting something that we truly dislike\n(disease, for example), or the fear of not being able to get rid of something\nthat we dislike (again disease, for example). The ultimate fear, of course, is\nthe fear of death. To control our passions we have to control them at their\nvery roots; then alone shall we be able to burn out their very seed. As fried\nseeds thrown into the ground will never come up, so these passions will never\narise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.10 \u2014</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">te\npratiprasavaheyah sookshmah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Subtle afflictions are\nto be minimised and eradicated by a process of involution</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Afflictions may be\ngross or subtle; both must be neutralised and eliminated, quietened at their\nvery roots. The Upanishads mention past-life regression.&nbsp; &nbsp;Pata\u00f1jali\ndiscussed the idea of the soul becoming burdened with an accumulation of\nimpressions as part of the karma from previous lives.&nbsp; Pata\u00f1jali called the process of past-life\nregression prati-prasav (literally \"reverse birthing\"), and saw it as\naddressing current problems through memories of past lives.&nbsp; &nbsp;Some\ntypes of yoga continue to use prati-prasav as a practice</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">the\n\"memories\" recovered by techniques like past-life regression are the\nresult of cryptomnesia: narratives created by the subconscious mind using\nimagination, forgotten information and suggestions from the therapist. Memories\ncreated under hypnosis are indistinguishable from actual memories and can be\nmore vivid than factual memories. The five adversities - ignorance, egoism,\nlust, malice and attachment to life appear gross (sthula) on the surface, but\ntheir subtle nature may be either latent or highly lively, or may alternate\nbetween the two . Meditation helps to exterminate them. The subtle afflictions\nstart with attachment to life, travel in the reverse order, contrary to\nspiritual evolution and end with the gross affliction, ignorance. Subtle\nafflictions need to be overcome before they lead to trouble. &nbsp;If a seed becomes seared, it cannot sprout; so\none must render an affliction infertile by tracing it back to its source. The\nmother of subtle afflictions is the mind, whose movements should be directed\ntowards the seer by the yogic process of involution (prati prasava). In this\nmanner, subtle afflictions are crushed and an un-polarised state of pure\nknowledge is chanced upon. These, the subtle ones, can be reduced by resolving\nthem backward into their origin.The kleshas can exist in one of two states,\nactive and potential. A person in a fit of anger is expressing the klesha of\ndvesha in an active state. Through the practice of yoga a person may acquire\nthe ability to remain calm in difficult situations. Even at that time the\nkleshas remain in a dormant or potential state where, given the right trigger,\nthe kleshas can again become active. Essentially there are three stages of\ndealing with the kleshas \u2013 attenuation (tanukarana), converting to inactive\n(prasupta) state, and finally burnt seeds. Pratiprasava literally means to go\nback to the original cause. &nbsp;&nbsp;In the case\nof kleshas, avidya (ignorance) is the root cause of the subsequent kleshas. To\neliminate the lowest level of klesha, abhinivesha (fear of death), we need to\ngo to the cause which are raga (likes) and dvesha (dislikes). From there we\nneed to trace the cause back to ego and then back to avidya. In order to uproot\nkleshas altogether we need to eliminate avidya and reach the state of kaivalya.\nAs long as the seed remains, even though it may be in a potential (sushupta)\nstate, it can still fructify given favorable triggers. To destroy the seeds\ncompletely, one needs to go through the various stages of samadhi and attain\nthe state of \"kaivalya\". The word \"pratiprasava\",&nbsp; which is the opposite of \"prasava\",\nmeans resolving into the cause. &nbsp;These\nkleshas are subtle; they are destroyed when (the mind) dissolves back into its\noriginal matrix. When the mind has fulfilled its purpose of attaining\n\"nirbija samadhi\", then it dissolves back into prakriti. The mind at\nthis point becomes redundant. The kleshas too dissolve along with the mind.\nLike burnt seeds, kleshas do not disappear as long as the mind is still active.Three\nstages of dealing with the kleshas:Attenuation (tanu-karana), Burning the seeds\n(dagdha bija),--by Prati Prasava we can &nbsp;accessing the deep hidden negative memories of\nthe past this and previous lifetimes.&nbsp;\nThese memories remain hidden deep in the subconscious mind though\n\u2018forgotten\u2019 by the conscious mind that are the root causes of our negative\nreactions, habits, and actions that cause more karmic, thus falling into the\nendless loop of cause and effect. In Prati Prasav sadhna all these deep-rooted\nemotions and psychic impressions are accessed and surfaced to be released and\nhealed. Our present is nothing but the reflection of what we did in the past\ndue to soul samkaras picked up in past lives. This explains phobias. &nbsp;The purpose of our birth is to resolve the\nissues that remained unresolved from our past lives. The circumstances and the\nproblems one is facing is due the stored baggage of psychic impressions that\none has collected in various lives with every action, word and thought. The\npsychic impressions are not just from past lives but also received and absorbed\neven in the infant and fetus stage in the mother\u2019s womb. Obstacles in life\nindicates unresolved issues and more the obstacles and issues in life, the more\nare the unresolved issues, which need to be resolved so that one does not get\nstuck in similar circumstances again and again repeatedly, birth after birth.\nThis unresolved issue is what is called as samskars or sanchit karmas or\npsychic impressions. In order to release the suffering, pain or disease of\npresent life or to attain the higher level of spirituality and experience the\nultimate truth one has to release the sanchit karma or samskaras or psychic\nimpressions. Prati Prasav Sadhna teaches how to shed this heavy load and bring\nout the inner light in the form of health happiness and prosperity. By\nreleasing these impressions which are the reasons behind the cause of our\npresent sufferings, one is able to weed out the root cause of sufferings and\nblockages in one\u2019s life. By Prati Prasav Sadhna we can dissolve fears, phobias,\nsufferings, limitations and awakening of your consciousness towards infinite\ndimension.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In order to release the suffering, pain or disease\nof present life or to attain the higher level of spirituality and experience\nthe ultimate truth one has to release the sanchit karma or samskaras or psychic\nimpressions. &nbsp;Prati Prasav Sadhna teaches\nhow to shed this heavy load and bring out the inner light in the form of health\nhappiness and prosperity. Our cellular memory can store the memory of physical\ntrauma like accidents, wounds, surgeries, abuse,trauma , fear etc that\nmanifests in low self-esteem, stress etc. When trauma is suppressed into the\ncellular memory, that energy can get stuck. &nbsp;&nbsp;Vaccines can be used to explain cellular\nmemory. You are given a shot that contains a small controlled amount of a\nbacteria. Your immune system immediately sets up a counter-offensive to keep\nyou from getting sick from it.&nbsp; Then your\nimmune system 'remembers' that type of experience to keep you healthy. This\nmeans vaccines evoke cell memory by their actions. Cells can \u201cremember\u201d how to\nfight a virus so you won\u2019t get reinfected. All these modern psychiatrists talk\nabout past life regression.&nbsp; This means\nthey are Hindus or they have stolen from our ancient texts. For only in\nHinduism we have endless re-births till a person obtains Moksha , as a result\nof NIL Karmic baggage .&nbsp; Past life regression\na Vedic technique of Charaka is recommended for people who are willing and\ndecided to change, to secure relief from vices, negativity, repetitive\nillnesses, phobias, separations and conflicts, inability to love,trust, learn.\netc.&nbsp; Upon completion of the past life\nregression therapy, subjects are able to \u201creverse and resolve\u201d phobias,\nnegativity and vices&nbsp; which, they were\nunable to solve through any other modern treatment or therapy.&nbsp; Each cell in our body stores memories from\nearly life, intra-uterine life, our parents and ancestors as well as, many past\ngenerations.&nbsp; A bio computer essentially\nacts like a file which when triggered causes us to act in a repetitive\nmanner..&nbsp; Erasing stored traumatic\nexperiences from our cellular memory is akin to deleting a virus from a\ncomputer.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;All Vedic healers were psychiatists . How many\nof modern psychiatrists are healers ?If each cell contains all of the\ninformation for the whole organism, then our experiences, good or bad, are also\nrecorded on a cellular level.&nbsp; Those\nexperiences that we perceive as life threatening will continue to resonate\nwithin the memory banks of the body\u2019s crystalline cellular and molecular matrix\nbecause we were not able to resolve the conflict or dissipate its energy. Every\ncell in our body has the ability to remember.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cells retain the\ninformation of all life experiences that has been absorbed from genetic\nheritage, nothing ever experienced whether positive or negative escapes being\nprogrammed...Without past life regression therapy it can be almost impossible\nto heal, as the memories are suppressed and we are not aware of holding onto\nthem.The healer&nbsp; helps the subject access\nthe specific internal negative file and then reprograms or formats it.&nbsp;&nbsp; If you magnify your cells down to your\natoms, you would see that you are made up of subtle bundles of\n\"info-energy.\"&nbsp; Release stored\nemotions from your subconscious mind and cellular memory and find peace with\nyour past, by past life regression.Cells are constantly growing and dying they\nare the ultimate reflection of how the universe works.&nbsp; The universe is constantly changing,\nconstantly transforming chaos to order, darkness into light and requires all\nwho inhabit it.&nbsp; So either we make the\nconscious decision to live and grow or do nothing, which is a personal choice. This\nis the meaning of old progamming of new cells\u2014it is about cell memory. This is\nwhy is that if you have some skin disease ( our skin renews every 28 days\n)&nbsp; , the new skin which comes does NOT\ncure the disease.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.11 \u2014 dhyanaheyastadvrittayah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The fluctuations of\nconsciousness created by gross and subtle afflictions are to be silenced\nthrough meditation.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali offers\nmeditation as another method to calm the mind. &nbsp;By these means, the mind's whims are reduced\nto their subtlest point and it is constrained to rest silently in its source,\nthe soul. Afflictions are of three intensities - gross (sthula), subtle\n(suksma), and the subtlest of the subtle (suksmatama). Tapas, svadhyaya and\nishavara pranidhana exterminate the gross, the subtle and the subtlest\nafflictions respectively. &nbsp;Isvara\nPranishana is less of a devotional dedication or a surrendering, and more of an\n\u2018opening up to what is\u2019, and instead of fighting against life\u2019s twists and\nturns, remaining open to experiencing life as it unfolds.&nbsp; Dhyana can help suppress the modifications\nproduced by kleshas even further. In order to achieve that result, one must\npractice the three elements of kriya yoga with intense concentration of the\nmind. The kleshas must be reduced to a latent, passive state where even with a\nstrong trigger, the kleshas will not come to the surface. Moreover, each klesha\ncan assume multiple forms of expression and each one of these expressions must\nbe tackled in order to eliminate the klesha.Gross manifestations of kleshas,\nbased on asmita etc, are attenuated by kriya yoga. They are further reduced to\nan unproductive state by meditative insight on discriminative knowledge and\nthen totally annihilated by dissolution of the mind. Vrittis produced by the\nkleshas are eliminated (turned into burned seeds). In the final stage, even the\nsubtlest form of the kleshas are completely dissolved by dissolving the mind\nback into its origin .<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.12 \u2014 kleshamoolah\nkarmashayo drishtadrishtajanmavedaniyah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The accumulated\nimprints of past lives, rooted in afflictions, will be experienced in present\nand future lives</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every past life we have\nhad ended in death. Each death is a decisive transition stage for the soul. In\ntherapy, this is where the most crucial part of the healing begins\u2014finishing\nthe unfinished business. Samskara is the Malayalam / Sanskrit word for an\nindelible impression, from a current or past life, stored in the subconscious\nmind which cannot be easily recalled to the conscious mind and generates a\npredetermined thought pattern, behavior or influence that can negatively affect\none\u2019s current life. By erasing the influence of the Samskara, a person can\nbecome free of its effect in order to lead a more conscious, productive, happy,\nand fulfilled life. Samskaras from a previous life or lives can still have an\ninfluence in and upon our current life. Some of the strongest impressions are\nfrom a traumatic death which then shows up as fears and phobias.&nbsp; Past life regression cannot erase past Karmas\nbut helps in performing Karmas better by removing some of the impediments.Vasanas\naffect our ability to live fully in the present moment and curtail our true\nnature.&nbsp; The conscious mind can access\nthe conscious mind, memories and intellect, but not the subconscious.&nbsp;&nbsp; The subconscious mind, the causal body, that\nstores these impressions can be tackled through subconscious states.&nbsp;&nbsp; Through deep meditation we can access these\ndeeper layers of our existence and memories from previous lives. By exploring\nour own past lives we become aware of these repetitive, unconscious patterns\nand we erase our past by resolving those patterns.&nbsp; Only then, are we free from our past and the\nwhole past is dropped. Without making peace with the past we will not\nprogress.. Karma is not punishment system. Karma is a feed back system through\nthat we learn our lessons from the past and evolve. Past-Life-Regression helps\nindividuals to understand the karmic patterns involved and the resultant energy\nblockages. It is these energy blockages that manifest as diseases, which are\nsometimes chronic. The understanding that flows clears the energy blockages and\nthereby the disease is healed. For example a person who had this fear of closed\nspaces (claustrophobia) had experienced a past life where he was buried alive\nin an earthquake. Once he relives this trauma, he was able to overcome his\nclaustrophobia immediately. Past-Life-Regression helps us to explore our past\nlives and through this exploration we realize that we are eternal beings. We\nunderstand that death is a mere transition from one state to another and that\nthe essence of our being continues into eternity as we have lived before and\nare going to live again after \u2018death\u2019. Samskaras which have left a very deep impression\non our personality.&nbsp; Samskara has nothing\nto do with our intellect or buddhi. We should not look at things only from the\nintellectual standpoint but from the aspect of the total personality. This is\nwhat meditation teaches.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as a healthy body can resists\ntoxins and pathogens, a healthy mind can ward off the negative sensory\ninfluences around itKarma or the actions that you do in the present life is\npassed on to the next life.&nbsp; But fate is\nnot passed on to the next life. Fate ( vidhi )is the outcome of our past karmic\nbaggage \u2013 and god has decided in advance this is what you deserve.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karmic\nnegative baggage has to be lived and worked out. There is no way of avoiding\nit.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Humans\nare the result of their deeper mind and its store of countless impressions from\nthe past. Sankalpa is a resolution for self transformation out of free\nwill.&nbsp; When divinity is added to the\nSankalpa; it gains strength and gets proper direction. . Yoga Nidra provides\nthe tools to \u2018weed out\u2019 these unconscious negative patterns and in their stead\nplant positive seeds deep in the subconscious mind, gradually allowing\nexpression from the highest aspect of the self.&nbsp;&nbsp; Past actions are the seeds of adversity,\nwhich in turn brings about other actions, necessitating further lives, or\nreincarnation. This is known as karma, or the universal law of cause and\neffect. Afflictions and actions intermix and interact, and the cycles of birth\nand death roll on. Actions rooted in desire, greed, anger, lust, pride and\nmalevolence invite adversity, just as those which are free from the spokes of\nthe wheel of desire lead towards the state of ecstasy. The effects of both\ntypes of action may be visible or invisible, manifest or latent; they may\nsurface in this life or in future lives. Whatever work we do, the mind is\nthrown into a wave, and, after the work is finished, we think the wave is gone.\nNo. It has only become fine, but it is still there. When we try to remember the\nthing, it comes up again and becomes a wave. So it was there; if it had not\nbeen there, there would not have been memory. So, every action, every thought,\ngood or bad, just goes down and becomes fine, and is there stored up. They are\ncalled pain-bearing obstructions, both happy and unhappy thoughts, because\naccording to the Yogis, both, in the long run, bring pain. All &nbsp;appiness which comes from the senses will,\neventually, bring pain.. There is no limit to man\u2019s desires; he goes on\ndesring, and when he comes to a point where desire cannot be fulfilled, the\nresult is pain. Therefore the Yogis regard the sum-total of the impressions, good\nor evil, as pain-bearing obstructions; they obstruct the way to freedom of the\nSoul. It is the same with the Samskaras, the fine roots of all our works: they\nare the causes which will again bring effects, either in this life, or in the\nlives to come.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.13 \u2014 sati moole\ntadvipako jatyayurbhogah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When the root\nexists, its fruition is birth, life and experience.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Life itself springs\nfrom the admixture of good and bad actions, favourable and unfavourable\nimpressions. These form one's birth, &nbsp;type of human life, span of life and the kind\nof experiences one has to go through. According to the law of karma, every\ncondition in the nature of human birth and life stem from one's past actions,\nand are responsible for the experiences, pleasant or otherwise, which one meets\nin life. The fruits of the actions gathered in this &nbsp;past lives &nbsp;are called soul samskaras, which become\nresidual imprints or impressions. &nbsp;&nbsp;Soul\nsamskaras are impressions remaining unconsciously in the mind from past good or\nbad actions, giving rise to pleasure or pain.Samskaras become the cause of\nfuture actions. Every action leaves a deep trace in the citta as printing or\nimpression ( samskara ). All the impressions accumulated in the citta and which\nis the fruit of action is what we mean by karm\u0101\u015baya. Karmashayas are of two\nkinds \u2013 those that must mature (niyata vipaka)and those that may not mature\n(aniyata vipaka). Aniyata Vipaka karmashayas may take one of these three\ncourses: Karma may get nullified by a stronger karma of the opposite kind A\ndominant karma may subdue a minor karma and may not fructify in the next life. The\nunfructified minor karma my bear fruit in&nbsp;\na future birth.Karma can bear fruit only when the kleshas exist. Grains\nof rice can germinate only when they are not burnt and the husk is not removed.\nAt the time of death, the karmashaya will determine the three fruits: type of\nbirth, life span and life experience \u2013 pain or pleasure. Karmashaya contains\nimpressions of deeds \u2013 samskaras \u2013 from countless previous lives. At the time\nof death, the subtle body, which contains the karmashaya, is transferred to the\nnew body. Only the gross body is destroyed on death. Most of the karmas will\nfructify in the next life. In each re-birth on earth , we acquire some bad\nkarma and some good karma.&nbsp; Only\nconscious humans have bad karma baggage . Animals do NOT have karma as they\nhave never risen beyond their mooladhara chakra.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In each\nincarnation we suffer the consequences of some of our previous bad karma \u2013and\nevery human soul has a&nbsp; resultant karmic\nbaggage plus some picked up samskaras , which affect current life on the planet\n, like phobias , deep rooted vices etc . Though weighed down by past life\nsamskaras , the soul ( ball of energy ) within you is a part of the mother\nfield of brahmAn ( god ) .&nbsp;&nbsp; Yoga\nempowers you to take charge of your destiny , though it cant alter your fate.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\npurpose of life on this planet is to be happy while pursuing the goal of\nlessening your karmic baggage as much as possible</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nUniverse is&nbsp; not inanimate but conscious;\nit records our actions and provides feedback to us for our psychic growth\nthrough the mechanism of karma. This karma gets recorded in the form of\ninchoate formations in the higher mental worlds.&nbsp; These formations get fleshed out as they\ndescend through the various planes of consciousness until they materialize at\nthe appropriate time as events in the physical world. The Law of Karma is\ninfallible and everyone&nbsp; is subjected to\nit.. As per the law of karma, every positive deed which we do, generates&nbsp; positive marks, while every sin ( laws of universe\nignored ) results in negative arks , which subsequently we need to repay by\nenduring happiness or unhappiness in this life of the next</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During\nour day-to-day interactions, we are either increasing or reducing the karmic\nbaggage weight.&nbsp; If the karmic baggage\nweights you will have another re-birth and another chance to lighten it.&nbsp;&nbsp; We are not consciously aware of the\ngive-and-take karmic accounts generated in our previous births.&nbsp;&nbsp; In our subsequent births, we may or may not\nbe equipped to settle our destiny and the paradox is that at the same time we\nare creating new karmic accounts.&nbsp;&nbsp; Thus,\nthis loop of karma and destiny binds us and we remain entangled in it. The only\nway through which we can nullify our give and take account and destiny is\nthrough sustained and regular spiritual practice.&nbsp; In Sanatan Dharma the true purpose of life is\nto overcome karma (destiny) and attain moksha where you become god. The ball of\nenergy within you ( soul ) merges with brahmAn ( mother energy field ).&nbsp; The soul was once part of it. It is REAL home\ncoming .&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.14 \u2014 te\nhladaparitapafalah punyapunyahetutvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">According to one's\ngood, bad or mixed actions, the quality of life, its span, and the nature of\nbirth are experienced as being pleasant or painful</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Happy or painful\nexperiences are based on whether the thoughts, feelings or actions that produce\nthem were \"virtuous\" or \"vicious\". This is the basis law of\nkarma. Virtuous deeds are those that follow the universal moral code. Vice,\napunya, produces a short life which is stressful (paritapa) and gives painful\nexperiences. Virtue,&nbsp; punya, produces\ngood karma resulting in happy (hlada) experiences. There is NO escape from laws\nof Karma . Organised religion applies severe retribution method at the hour of\njudgement \u2013 Sanatana Dharma applies Karma.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Willfully and knowingly\ntransgressing the laws of the universe generates a lot more negative karma than\nunintentional or ignorant transgressions.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Whenever you act with\nintention you create Karma. Actions are considered to be thoughts, emotions,\nwords and deeds, and the motive, desire and intent behind each. The purpose of\nKarma is to attain harmony.Although many of the major events in your life are\nastrologically predestined, , god has given you consciousness and free will to\nmitigate the impact of the event, or to transcend it entirely.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Beliefs\ncan be changed when you recognize those that are not working for you, and begin\nprogramming what will create success and harmony in your life.&nbsp; You are NOT an animal\u2014you are a conscious\nhuman with free will and the power to choose.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nThe unlimited creative power of your mind, through dedication, awareness\nand training, can be the wisdom to rise above your Karma.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Sanatana Dharma guides you in this aspect.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There\nare no accidents in the way the cosmos works.Your energy, translated into\nthoughts, words, emotions, and deeds, causes all your experiences. This assures\nthat you always have the learning opportunities you require to resolve your\nKarma, and, as with you, the collective thoughts, words, emotions, and deeds of\nmankind create the environment for us all. The purpose of karma is to attain\nharmony and balance. The universe is perfectly balanced. When you are in\nharmony you are in balance.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Until you have resolved your Karma\nand fulfilled your Dharma, you will continue to reincarnate into sequential\nlifetimes upon the earth.&nbsp; You decide\nwhat lessons you need to learn for each life experience. Whenever you act with\nintention (actions being your thoughts, emotions, words and deeds and the\nmotive, intent and desire) you create karma.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nDis-harmonious acts, are rooted in fear-based emotions, must be\neventually balanced and resolved. When you can live a life of perfect harmony,\nliberation will follow.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karma can be experienced in pain and\nsuffering, or it can be experienced in grace. The choice is yours. If you give\nlove , fairness with grace , you will receive the same in return.&nbsp;&nbsp; Karma is simply an opportunity to make good\nby CHANGE \u2013&nbsp; it neither punishes nor\nrewards; it simply guides.&nbsp; Karma is a\nmatter of basic cause-and-effect without the need of a deity to mediate the\neffects.The law of karma is not the cause of suffering,&nbsp; it is merely the change agent. Karma is self-balancing\ndivine justice; it is 100% fair and absolutely infallible.&nbsp; It doesn't matter if a criminal seems to GET\nAWAY WITH IT \u2013 see evil Jew Rothschild has got away with it. There is no\ngetting away with it \u2013 karma will eventually catch up with him&nbsp; -if not in this life then the next life. After\ndoing sins no dip in Ganges, no puja, no pilgrimage , no endless prayers to god\ncan lessen the weight of your karmic baggage.&nbsp;\nIt can be reduced only by good karma.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karma is not\nsome mysterious metaphysical, or supernatural, force or power that somehow\ncomes back to haunt you.&nbsp;&nbsp; Karma is simply\nwhat we do in a conscious manner .</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karma is a Sanskrit\nword meaning \"action\".&nbsp; Karmic\nbaggage is a resultant \u2013 and is negative bad karma.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.15 \u2014</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">parinamatapasanskaraduhkhairgunnavritti\n- virodhaccha duhkham eva sarvan vivekinah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The wise man knows that\nowing to fluctuations, the qualities of nature, and subliminal impressions even\npleasant experiences are tinged with sorrow, and he keeps aloof from them.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The wise man knowing\nthat all instant addcitive gratification and hedonistic pleasure leads to pain.\nPure inner peace can be reached by winning the right knowledge that will weed\nout the roots of pain and petty pleasures.&nbsp;\nAs per this sutra, all experiences are actively or potentially full of\nmisery to the \"viveki\", a wise person whose spiritual perception has\nawakened. In the previous sutra we learned that virtue and vice will bring out\npleasurable and painful experiences respectively. Parinama means change or\ntransformation. Everything in the universe is in a state of constant flux and\nchange is happening every moment whether or not we are aware of it. It is the\neffect of Maya that we are unaware of the constant change happening all around\nus. We become aware of this change only after we attain the state of viveka\n(discriminatory wisdom). At that time, we develop a sense of fear and\nloneliness as everything seems to move so rapidly. It is only when we follow\nthe practice of yoga intently that we begin to realize that there is something\nEternal deep inside us despite all the change happening. With that comes the\nrealization that little pleasures and ambitions in life are only transitory. Tapa\nmeans anxiety.&nbsp; We are constantly in fear\nof losing those objects which give us instant pleasure. Whether it is love or\nmoney or any other possession, we always have a sense of anxiety that we will\nlose it one day. Happiness is not pleasure.</span> &nbsp;&nbsp;Happiness is free . <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is about\nfilling up the space deep inside, or gratification of the soul. It is about\nequilibrium or dynamic balance -life is a combination of spiritual,\nintellectual and physical aspects. It is achieved by deserving.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One\nof the great secrets to happiness is to be immersed in an activity that is\ncomplex, where you have the skills to match that activity.&nbsp; Samskara means impressions . Every experience\ncreates an impression in our mind. Repeated similar impressions create habits. Surroundings\nand circumstances in life are constantly changing. There is a conflict between\nthe \u2018status quo\u2019 expected due to habits and the change that is always\nhappening, threatening the very habits that we develop. This conflict is a\ncause of misery and unhappiness. The wise man knows that any instant pleasure\nin life is only transitory and will ultimately result in pain and suffering.&nbsp; Experience of happiness is due to attachment\nto objects and that of suffering is caused by hatred or dislike for an object.\nThe karmashaya (storehouse of karma) is a result of these experiences. When the\nsenses are accustomed to short experience of happiness, they are not inclined\nfor renunciation since their attachment is increased. For a Yogin, even these\npleasant experiences are source of ultimate misery and he shuns attachment to\nthese objects.&nbsp; Greed and infatuation are\nthe cause of aversion which brings misery as one pursues to overcome the source\nof aversion. The mind of a yogin or a wise man is as sensitive as the surface\nof the eyeball. The touch of a falling cobweb hurts only the eyeball, but no\nother part of the body. Similarly, miseries due to the changing nature of\nthings affects only a yogin due to his enhanced sensitivity. Others, under the\ninfluence of ignorance (avidya) suffer from misery due to their own deeds. They\ngo through the cycle of birth and death .&nbsp;\nEven when an addictive desire is fulfilled, it never is fully satisfied\nas it grows even stronger for the same or similar objects \u2013 like fire that\nflares up with the oblation of ghee. The main idea in the sutra is to\nunderstand that pleasure and pain are all associated with material objects\nwhich are transitory.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hedonists, strive to\nmaximise their total pleasure (the net of any pleasure less any pain or\nsuffering). They believe that pleasure is the only good in life, and pain is\nthe only evil, and our life's goal should be to maximize pleasure and minimize\npain.&nbsp; 7000 years ago Patanjali wrote\nabout the <span style=\"background-color: cyan;\">PARADOX of hedonism</span>. &nbsp;When one\naims solely towards pleasure itself, one's aim is frustrated.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">P</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">leasure and happiness are strange\nphenomena that do not obey normal principles, in that they cannot be acquired\ndirectly, only indirectly and we often fail to attain pleasures if we\ndeliberately seek them.&nbsp;&nbsp; Pleasure cannot\nbe the standard or guide to action, as that would result in intellectual and\nphilosophical abdication.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">THIS POST IS NOW CONTINUED TO PART 55, &nbsp;BELOW-</span></b></span><br />\n<b><span style=\"background-color: lime; color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_22.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_22.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">At my younger son's Manipal college convocation ceremony. &nbsp;A grand affair. &nbsp;Verses from Atharva Veda were recited. &nbsp;The chief Guest ISRO chairman Kiran Kumar said \" <span style=\"color: blue;\">Our ancient texts, the core of Indian wisdom , &nbsp;should NOT be disregarded</span>\" .&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">He said \" S<span style=\"line-height: 22px; text-align: justify;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">cience as it is known today is of relatively modern origin but the traditions out of which it had emerged \u201creach back beyond recorded history.</span></span><span style=\"color: #333333; line-height: 22px; text-align: justify;\">\u201d</span>&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\">There were NO unwashed, crass, rustic, NIL class &nbsp;Kanhaiya Kumars ( who wants BHINDOW seat and PROMOSSANN ) there in the outdoor hall. &nbsp;JNU does not require attendance. , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Yoga Sutras were\npenned down in 5000 BC by Maharishis Patanjali-- 196 Sanskrit sutras\n(aphorisms).</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali divided his Yoga Sutras into four chapters.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; , serif;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hjduAAvCD8E/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/hjduAAvCD8E?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">1.32\u2014 tatpratishedhartham\nekatattvabhyasah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Adherence to\nsingle-minded effort prevents these impediments</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To remove the thirteen\nobstructions and thwart their reappearance, several specific methods have been\ndistinguished. &nbsp;But absolute surrender to\nGod is beyond the abilities of most ordinary men and women, who are still\nentangled in pleasure and pain, joy and sorrow, success and failure. Meditation\nundoubtedly helps to minimise the mental agitations of such people. But in\norder to conquer all the obstacles to Self-Realisation, all the eight stages of\nyoga must be followed. Only when body, mind and intelligence are fully\nsanctified is it possible to submit whole-heartedly to God, without awaiting\nany return. This is a surrender of the highest order, beyond the capacity of\nthe average individual.&nbsp;&nbsp; In brief the\neight limbs, or steps to yoga, are as follows: Yama :&nbsp; Universal morality, Niyama :&nbsp; Personal observances, Asanas :&nbsp; Body postures, Pranayama :&nbsp; Breathing exercises, and control of prana, Pratyahara\n:&nbsp; Control of the senses, Dharana :&nbsp; Concentration and cultivating inner\nperceptual awareness, Dhyana :&nbsp; Devotion,\nMeditation on the Divine, Samadhi :&nbsp;\nUnion with the Divine. These eight steps of yoga indicate a logical\npathway that leads to the attainment of physical, ethical, emotional, and\npsycho-spiritual health. Yoga does not seek to change the individual; rather,\nit allows the natural state of total health and integration in each of us to\nbecome a reality.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">1.33\u2014 maitreekarunamuditopekshanan\nsukhaduhkhapunyapunyavishayanan bhavanatashchittaprasadanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">By cultivating\nfriendliness towards happiness and compassion towards misery, gladness towards\nvirtue and indifference towards vice, the mind becomes pure.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Citta viksepa is a\ncurrent of distressed thoughts running like a river. In citta prasadana,\ngraceful diffusion, the turbulent flow is dammed up and consciousness imbues\nserenely like a lake. &nbsp;If the citta is\ncaught in the mesh of the senses, and the sadhaka fails to cultivate\nfriendliness, compassion, delight and equanimity, sorrow and unhappiness\ndevelops within his heart. This sutra asks one to be rejoiced with the\nhappiness, to be empathetic to the sorrowful, friendly to the virtuous, and\nunsympathetic to those who continue to live in vice, despite endeavours to\nchange them. This mental adjustment ramps up social as well as individual health.\nIn addition to cultivating these qualities, one should follow the social\nvirtues oiyama &nbsp;for the well-being of\nsociety as a whole. This approach to life keeps the mind of the sadhaka\ntranquil and pure. These attitudes of the mind towards the different subjects\nthat come before it will make the mind peaceful. Each time we suppress hatred,\nor a feeling of anger, it is so much good energy stored up in our favour; that\npiece of energy will be converting into the higher powers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">1.34\u2014 prachchhardanavidharanabhyan\nva prannasya</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Optionally, mental\nequanimity may be gained by the even expulsion and retention of energy.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Prana is not exactly breath. It is the name\nfor the energy that is in the universe. Whatever you see in the universe,\nwhatever moves or works, or has life, is a manifestation of this Prana. &nbsp;&nbsp;Throwing\nout and restraining the Prana is what is called Pranayama. &nbsp;He means that you simply throw the air out,\nand draw it in, and hold it for some time, (pranayama ) the mind will become &nbsp;calmer. &nbsp;The vitality of the breath is the Prana. By\nthis process of breathing we can control all the various motions in the body,\nand the various nerve currents that are running through the body. Pranayama\u2014\nwhere you exhale twice as long as inhale\u2014 it is more about dumping old\nexperiences rather than mere oxygenation of blood and producing Nitric oxide by\nMMMMMM.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Breathe\nin the new , breathe out the old. Pranayama\u2014inhale and exhale with awareness\u2014\nlong exhales with the sound of mmmm. Humming boosts level of nitric oxide\u2014this\nin turn ups the oxygen intake by 98%, the biggest secret . Ordinary breath is a\nmere 4%.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is amazing Nitric oxide was discovered by Indian\nyogis 11000 years ago.&nbsp; For re-inventing\nthis a Nobel prize was given 2 decades ago.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitric oxide is\nnecessary for- 1. Destruction of viruses, parasitic organisms, and malignant\ncells in the airways and lungs by inactivating their respiratory chain enzymes.\n2. Regulation of binding - release of O2 to hemoglobin. 3. Vasodilation of\narteries and arterioles (regulation of blood flow or perfusion of tissues). 4.\nInhibitory effects of inflammation in blood vessels. 5. Hormonal effects.\nNitric oxide influences secretion of hormones from several glands (adrenaline,\npancreatic enzymes, and gonadotropin-releasing hormone) 6. Neurotransmission.\nMemory, sleeping, learning, feeling pain, and many other processes are possible\nonly with NO present (for transmission of neuronal signals). Obviously, during\nmouth breathing it is not possible to utilize one's own nitric oxide which is\nproduced in the sinuses.When there is lack of oxygen in your blood , you living\nto a small percentage of your potential.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The power of breathing\nlies in its relationship with your energy source. The mind is intimately\nconnected to your breathing. Deep breathing triggers the lymph, your body\u2019s\nsewage system which will give your cells more efficiency. It keeps the blood\nfully oxygenated. Breathe in the ration 1/4/2.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The physical\naspect of lack of oxygen in the body is not as important as the mental and\nspiritual aspect.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stress, fear and anxiety causes muscles\nto contract and blood vessels to constrict. When blood cannot be transported\nfreely through the body to provide oxygen, and antibodies and to carry away and\ndispose toxic wastes, illness sets in.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mind is non material ,\nbut it works in partnership with communicator molecules. With every thought\nmind moves atoms of hydrogen, carbon , oxygen and other particles in the brain\n. Knowing the connection between breath and consciousness, the ancient yogis\ndevised PRANAYAMA to stabilise energy and consciousness.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All\nthat vibrates in this universe is the cosmic personality and prime mover Prana,\npotent in all living beings and non-living beings --- heat, light, gravity,\nmagnetism, vigor , power , vitality,life, spirit.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When\na man is contented and happy , he has more Prana inside him. Anxiety vanishes\nentirely when you are one with the rest of the universe. When your mind is\ndisturbed the fundamental energy Prana leaks . Pranayama just reverses the\nprocess.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yoga says that longevity depends on slow diaphragmic\nbreathing. Fluctuations of mind are controlled and hence Pranayama prepares you\nfor meditation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">1.35\u2014 vishayavati va\npravrittirutpanna manasah sthitinibandhini</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Or activity of the\nhigher senses causes mental steadiness.</i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One may equally attain\nan exhilarated state of consciousness by becoming entirely engulfed, with\ndedication and devotion, in an object of interest. &nbsp;The deity in a temple is just a tool. The\npractice of contemplating upon an object is the basis of mental stability.\nTotal absorption in the object brings about direct perception of its essence.\nThis sutra demonstrates how to develop awareness and sensitivity in\nintelligence. &nbsp;If a man whose mind is\ndisturbed wants to take up Dharana &nbsp;practices of Yoga, yet doubts the truth of\nthem, he will have his doubts set at rest, when, after a little practice, these\nthings come to him. Dhara\u1e47a may be translated as \"holding steady\",\n\"concentration\" or \"single focus\". The prior limb\nPratyahara involves withdrawing the senses from external phenomena. Dhara\u1e47a\nbuilds further upon this by refining it further to ekagrata or ekagra chitta,\nthat is single-pointed concentration and focus, which is in this context\ncognate with Samatha.</span> &nbsp;<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhara\u1e47a\nis the initial step of deep concentrative meditation, where the object being\nfocused upon is held in the mind without consciousness wavering from it.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As\nthe seer becomes more advanced, dwelling in the subsequent stage of Dhy\u0101na,\nconsciousness of the act of meditation disappears, and only the consciousness\nof being/existing and the object of concentration register (in the mind). In\nthe final stage of Sam\u0101dhi, the ego-mind also dissolves, and the seer becomes\none with the object. Generally, the object of concentration is God, or the\nSelf, which is seen as an expression of God.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Having\ncontrolled the Prana through Pranayama and the Indriyas through Pratyahara, you\nshould try to fix the mind on something. In Dharana you will have only one\nVritti or wave in the mind-lake. The mind assumes the form of only one object.\nAll other operations of the mind are suspended or stopped.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana\ncan be done only if you are free from the distractions of mind.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Concentration\nwithout purity is of no use. There are some occultists who have concentration.\nBut they do not have good character. This is the reason why they do not make\nany progress in the spiritual path. Ethical perfection is of paramount\nimportance. The mind can be fixed easily on any pleasing object-the reason why\nwe have a choice of ishta devata.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">1.36- - vishoka va jyotishmati</span><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Or the state of sorrowless Light.</span></i><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\nHere, the concentration is on the innermost nucleus of the\nheart, where alone the sorrowless, effulgent light luminescences. That is the\nseat of the soul. The mind is guided in such a way that it becomes absorbed,\nand imbues towards its source. Movements in the form of thoughts in the mind\nare the waves, and citta, or the seat of consciousness, is the ocean. The\nsadhaka must learn to keep the citta motionless and thoughtfully silent,\nwithout creating waves of thought. This effort of stilling and silencing the\ncitta brings forth the sorrow less effulgent light of the soul.&nbsp; The last stage of meditation &nbsp;is the abandoning of any sense of\nsatisfaction, pain, or serenity because any inclination to a good or bad state\nof mind has disappeared. The meditator thus enters a state of supreme purity,\nindifference to everything, and pure consciousness. &nbsp;Meditation abstracts the self from conscious\nthought, and frees the mind from feelings that cause stress and suffering.&nbsp;&nbsp; It fosters creative intelligence, raise\nconsciousness, and enables fuller use to be made of mental potential. During\nmeditation thinking is separated from perceiving, so that the individual can\nstand apart from the emotional self.&nbsp; Mysticism\nprovides an escape from a life of uninspired existence.
