Where is your halting place, where rest ye for the night? O Heroes,\nthis I beg of you. 'Be near me in the day, be near me in the night'.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Seers\nsaw that stupid verse above ?&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Oh yeah ?<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THE\nFAKE YAJNAVALKYA SMRITI WAS USED BY BR AMBEDKAR TO DRIVE A WEDGE BETWEEN\nHINDUS AND BUDDHISTS.</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nYajnavalkya Smriti says that the very sight of a monk with red robes and shaven\nhead (referring to Buddhists), even in a dream, is a bad sign.<b> [Yajnavalkya\nSmritiI/272-273]</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader used BR Ambedkar to say this WHITE LIE-<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">That Adi\nShankaracharya said that the Buddha was suffering from &nbsp;schizophrenia. Shankaracharya said that-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">QUOTE\n: \u201che (Buddha) was a man given to make incoherent assertions or else that\nhatred of all beings induced him to propound absurd doctrines by accepting\nwhich they would become thoroughly confused.\u2013So that\u2013and this the S\u00fbtra means\nto indicate\u2013Buddha\u2019s doctrine has to be entirely disregarded by all those who\nhave a regard for their own happiness.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">[Shankar\nBhashya on Brahmasutra 2/2/32]&nbsp; UNQUOTE<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">ABOVE\nIS POISON INJECTED--<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">ADI\nSHANKARACHARYA LIVED IN 2000 BC.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">THE\nREAL BUDDHA LIVED IN 1900 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">THE\nFAKE BUDDHA OF ROTHSCHILD LIVED IN 500 BC<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">THE\nGREAT INDIAN EMPEROR ASOKHA WHO CONVERTED FROM BAAAAD HINDUSIM TO GOOOD\nBUDDHISM NEVER EXISTED. .<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">FAKE Ashoka\nin his Rock Edict I and Pillar Edict I declared how originally thousands of\nanimals were killed in the royal kitchen. Considering the popularity of\nbeef-eating among the Hindus people even Ashoka, the great propagator of\nahimsa, resolved later on to discontinue the slaughter of animals only for some\ndays in the year; for example, he included the breeding bull but not the cow in\nthe list of animals not to be slaughtered on those days. WHITE LIES !<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/chanakya-taxila-university-professor.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/chanakya-taxila-university-professor.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">ROTHSCHILD\nHISTORIANS WROTE THAT THE NON-EXISTENT RISHI YAJNAVALKHYA WAS FOND OF EATING\nBEEF .</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader injected POISION all over our ancient scriptures to prove that\nancient maharishis ate beef.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">BR\nAMBEDKAR DID NOT KNOW SANSKRIT.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;NOR DID&nbsp;\nHE READ VEDAS OR UPANISHADS. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">YET\nAFTER HE FINISHED HIS EDUCATION IN ROTHSCHILDs OPIUM FOUNDED COLUMBIA\nUNIVERSITY, HE KNEW EXACTLY WHICH ALL \u201cPOISON INJECTED \u201c PASSAGE IN VEDAS AND\nUPANISHADS TOLD ABOUT ANCIENT MAHARISHIS EATING BEEF ( SIC )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: purple; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\"><b>Did\nHindus Never Eat Beef?<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">By BR\nAmbedkar</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>To the\nquestion whether the Hindus ever ate beef, every Touchable Hindu, whether he is\na Brahmin or a non-Brahmin, will say \u2018no, never\u2019. In a certain sense, he is\nright. From times no Hindu has eaten beef. If this is all that the Touchable\nHindu wants to convey by his answer there need be no quarrel over it. But when\nthe learned Brahmins argue that the Hindus not only never ate beef but they\nalways held the cow to be sacred and were always opposed to the killing of the\ncow, it is impossible to accept their view.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>What\nis the evidence in support of the construction that the Hindus never ate beef\nand were opposed to the killing of the cow? There are two series of references\nin the Rig Veda on which reliance is placed. In one of these, the cow is spoken\nof as Aghnya. They are Rig Veda 1.164, 27; IV.1.6; V 82-8; V11.69. 71; X.87.\nAghnya means \u2018one who does not deserve to be killed\u2019. From this, it is argued\nthat this was a prohibition against the killing of the cow and that since the\nVedas are the final authority in the matter of religion, it is concluded that\nthe Aryans could not have killed the cows, much less could they have eaten\nbeef. In another series of references the cow is spoken of as sacred. They are Rig\nVeda V1.28.1.8. and VIII, 101. 15. In these verses the cow is addressed as\nMother of Rudras, the Daughter of Vasus, the Sister of the Adityas and the\nCentre of Nectar. Another reference on the subject is in Rig Veda VIII. 101. 16\nwhere the cow is called Devi (Goddess). Raliance is also placed on certain\npassages in the Brahmanas and Sutras.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>There\nare two passages in the Satapatha Brahmana which relate to animal sacrifice and\nbeef-eating. One is at 111.1.2.21 and reads as follows:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>\"He\n(the Adhvaryu) then makes him enter the hall. Let him not eat (the flesh) of\neither the cow or the ox, for the cow and the ox doubtless support everything\nhere on earth. The gods spoke, \u2018verily, the cow and the ox support everything\nhere; come, let us bestow on the cow and the ox whatever vigour belonged to\nother species (of animals); and therefore the cow and the ox eat most Hence\nwere one to eat (the flesh) of an ox or a cow, there would be, as it were, an\neating of everything, or, as it were, a going to the end (or, to destruction)...\nLet him therefore not eat (the flesh) of the cow and the ox.\"<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>The\nother passage is at 1, 2, 3, 6. It speaks against animal sacrifice on ethical\ngrounds. A similar statement is contained in the Apastambha Dharma Sutra at 1,\n5, 17, 29. Apastambha lays a general embargo on the eating of cow\u2019s flesh.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Such\nis the evidence in support of the contention that the Hindus never ate beef.\nWhat conclusion can be drawn from this evidence?<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>So far\nas the evidence from the Rig Veda is concerned the conclusion is based on a\nmisreading and misunderstanding of the texts. The adjective Aghnya applied to\nthe cow in the Rig Veda means a cow that was yielding milk and therefore not\nfit for being killed. That the cow is venerated in the Rig Veda is of course\ntrue. But this regard and veneration of the cow are only to be expected from an\nagricultural community like the Indo-Aryans. This application of the utility of\nthe cow did not prevent the Aryan from killing the cow for purposes of food.\nIndeed, the cow was killed because the cow was regarded as sacred. As observed\nby Mr. Kane: \"It was not that the cow was not sacred in Vedic times, it\nwas because of her sacredness that it is ordained in the Vajasaneyi Samhita\nthat beef should be eaten.\" (Dharma Shastra Vichar in Marathi, p. 180).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>That\nthe Aryans of the Rig Veda did kill cows for purposes of food and ate beef is\nabundantly clear from the Rig Veda itself. In Rig Veda (X. 86.14) Indra says:\n\u2018They cook for one 15 plus twenty oxen\". The Rig Veda (X.91.14) says that\nfor Agni were sacrificed horses, bulls, oxen, barren cows and rams. From the\nRig Veda (X.72.6) it appears that the cow was killed with a sword or axe.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>As to\nthe testimony of the Satapatha Bramhana, can it be said to be conclusive?\nObviously, it cannot be. For there are passages in the other Bramhanas which\ngive a different opinion. To give only one instance. Among the Kamyashtis set\nforth in the Taittiriya Bramhana, not only the sacrifice of oxen and cows is\nlaid down, but we are even told what kind and description of oxen and cows are\nto be offered to what deities. Thus, a dwarf ox is to be chosen for sacrifice\nto Vishnu; a drooping horned bull with a blaze on the forehead to Indra as the\ndestroyer of Vritra, a black cow to Pushan, a red cow to Rudra, and so on. The\nTaittiriya Bramhana notes another sacrifice called Panchasaradiya-seva, the\nmost important element of which was the immolation of seventeen five-year old\nhumpless, dwraf bulls, and as many dwarf heifers under three year old.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>As\nagainst the statement of the Apastamba Dharma Sutra, the following points may\nbe noted. First is the contrary statement contained in that very Sutra. At 15,\n14, 29, the Sutra says: \"The cow and the bull are sacred and therefore\nshould be eaten\". The second is the prescription of Madhuparka contained\nin the Grahya Sutras.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Among\nthe Aryans the etiquette for receiving important guests had become settled into\ncustom and had become a ceremony. The most important offering was Madhuparka. A\ndetailed description regarding Madhuparka are to be found in the various Grahya\nSutras. According to most of the Grahya Sutras there are six persons who have a\nright to be served with Madhuparka namely, (1) Ritwija or the Brahmin called to\nperform a sacrifice, (2) Acharya, the teacher, (3) The bridegroom (4) The King\n(5) The Snatak, the student who has just finished his studies at the Gurukul\nand (6) Any person who is dear to the host. Some add Atithi to this list.\nExcept in the case of Ritvija, King and Acharya, Madhuparka is to be offered to\nthe rest once in a year. To the Ritvija, King and Acharya it is to be offered\neach time they come.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>What\nwas this Madhuparka made of? There is divergence about the substances mixed in\noffering Madhuparka. Asv.gr and Ap.gr. (13.10) prescribe a mixture of honey and\ncurds or clarified butter and curds. Others like Par.gr.l3 prescribe a mixture\nof three (curds, honey and butter). Ap.gr. (13.11-12) states the view of some\nthat those three may be mixed or five (those three with fried yava grain and\nbarley). Hir.gr.L, 12, 10-12 give the option of mixing three of five (curds,\nhoney, ghee, water and ground grain). The Kausika Sutra (92) speaks of nine\nkinds of mixtures, viz., Brahma (honey and curds). Aindra (of payasa), Saurnya\n(curds and ghee), Pausna (ghee and mantha), Sarasvata (milk and ghee), Mausala\n(wine and ghee, this being used only in Sautramanai and Rajasuya sacrifices),\nParivrajaka (sesame oil and oil cake). The Madhava gr.l.9.22 says that the Veda\ndeclares that the Madhuparka must not be without flesh and so it recommends\nthat if the cow is let loose, goat\u2019s meat or payasa (rice cooked in milk) may\nbe offered; the Hir.gr. 1.13, 14 says that other meat should be offered;\nBaud.gr. (1.2,51-54) says that when the cow is let off, the flesh of a goat or\nram may be offered or some forest flesh (of a deer, etc.) may be offered, as\nthere can be no Madhuparka without flesh or if one is unable to offer flesh one\nmay cook ground grains. Thus the essential element in Madhuparka is flesh and\nparticularly cow\u2019s flesh. The killing of cow for the guest had grown to such an\nextent that the guest came to be called \u2018Go-ghna\u2019 which means the killer of the\ncow. To avoid this slaughter of the cows the Ashvateyana Grahya Sutra (1.24.25)\nsuggests that the cow should be let loose when the guest comes so as to escape\nthe rule of etiquette. Thirdly, reference may be made to the ritual relating to\ndisposal of the dead to counter the testimony of the Apastamba Dharma Sutra.\nThe Sutra says (Kane\u2019s vol. II, Part I, p. 545.):<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>1. He\nshould then put the following (sacrificial) implements (on the dead body)<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>2.\nInto the right hand the (spoon called) Guhu.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>3.\nInto the left the (other spoon called) Upabhrit.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>4. On\nhis right side the wooden sacrificial sword called Sphya, on his left side the\nAgnihotrahavani (i.e., the laddle with which the Agnihotra oblations are\nsacrified).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>5. On\nhis chest the (big sacrificial laddle called) Dhruva. On his head the dishes.\nOn his teeth the pressing stones.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>6. On\nthe two sides of his nose, the two smaller sacrificial laddles called Sruvas.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>7. Or,\nif there is only one (Sruva), breaking it (in two pieces).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>8. On\nhis two ears the two Prasitraharanas (i.e, the vessels into which the portion\nof the sacrificial food belonging to the Brahmin) is put<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>9. Or,\nif there is only one (Prasitraharana), breaking it (in two pieces).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>10. On\nhis belly the (vessel called) Patri.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>11.\nAnd the cup into which the cut-off portion (of the sacrificial food) are put.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>12. On\nhis secret parts the (staff called) Samy.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>13. On\nhis thighs two kindling woods.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>14. On\nhis legs the mortar and the pestle.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>15. On\nhis feet the two baskets.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>16.\nOr, if there is only one (basket), breaking it in two pieces.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>17.\nThose of the implements which have a hollow (into which liquids can be poured)\nare filled with sprinkled butter.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>18.\nThe son (of the deceased person) should take the under and the upper mill-stone\nfor himself.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>19.\nAnd the implements made of copper, iron and earthenware.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>20.\nTaking out the omentum of the she-animal he should cover therewith the head and\nthe mouth (of the dead person) with the verse, \u2018But on the armour (which will\nprotect thee) against Agni, by that which comes from the cows.\u2019 (Rig Veda. X.\n16.7).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>21.\nTaking out the kidneys of the animal he should lay them into the hands (of the\ndead body) with the verse, escape the two hounds, the sons of Sarma (Rig Veda X\n14.10) the right kidney into the right hand and the left into the left hand.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>22.\nThe heart of the animals he puts on the heart of the deceased.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>23.\nAnd two lumps of flour or rice according to some teachers.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>24.\nOnly if there are no kidneys according to some teachers.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>25.\nHaving distributed the whole (animal), limb by limb (placing its different\nlimbs on the corresponding limbs of the deceased) and having covered it with\nits hide, he recites when the Pranita water is carried forward (the verse),\n\u2018Agni do not overturn this cup,\u2019 (Rig Veda, X. 16.8).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>26.\nBending his left knee he should sacrifice Yugya oblation into the Dakshina fire\nwith the formulas \u2018To Agni Svaha, to Kama Svaha, to the world Svaha, to Anumati\nSvaha\u2019.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>27. A\nfifth (oblation) on the chest of the deceased with the formula \u2018from this one\nverily thou hast been born. May he now be born out of thee. To the heaven\nworlds Svaha.\u2019 \"<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>From\nthe above passage quoted from the Ashvalayan Grahya Sutra it is clear that\namong the ancient Indo-Aryans when a person died, an animal had to be killed\nand the parts of the animal were placed on the appropriate parts of the dead\nbody before the dead body was burned.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Such\nis the state of the evidence on the subject of cow-killing and beef-eating.\nWhich part of it is to be accepted as true? The correct view is that the\ntestimony of the Satapatha Brahmana and the Apastamba Dharma Sutra in so far as\nit supports the view that Hindus were against cow-killing and beef-eating, are\nmerely exhortations against the excesses of cow-killing and not prohibitions\nagainst cow-killing. Indeed the exhortations prove that cow-killing and eating\nof beef had become a common practice. That notwithstanding these exhortations\ncow-killing and beef-eating continued. That most often they fell on deaf ears\nis proved by the conduct of Yajnavalkya, the great Rishi of the Aryans. The\nfirst passage quoted above from the Satapatha Brahmana was really addressed to\nYajnavalkya as an exhortation. How did Yajnavalkya respond? After listening to\nthe exhortation this is what Yajnavalkya said: \" I, for one, eat it,\nprovided that it is tender.\"<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>That\nthe Hindus at one time did kill cows and did eat beef is proved abundantly by\nthe description of the Yajnas given in the Buddhist Sutras which relate to\nperiods much later than the Vedas and the Brahmanas. The scale on which the\nslaughter of cows and animals took place was colossal. It is not possible to\ngive a total of such slaughter on all accounts committed by the Brahmins in the\nname of religion. Some idea of the extent of this slaughter can, however, be\nhad from references to it in the Buddhist literature. As an illustration,\nreference may be made to the Kutadanta Sutta in which Buddha preached against\nthe performance of animal sacrifices to Brahmin Kutadanta. Buddha, though\nspeaking in a tone of sarcastic travesty, gives a good idea of the practices\nand rituals of the Vedic sacrifices when he said:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>\"And\nfurther, O Brahmin, at that sacrifice neither were any oxen slain, neither\ngoats, nor fowls, nor fatted pigs, nor were any kind of living creatures put to\ndeath. No trees were cut down to be used as posts, no Darbha grasses mown to\nstress around the sacrificial spot. And the slaves and messengers and workmen\nthere employed were driven neither by rods nor fear, nor carried on their work\nweeping with tears upon their faces.\"<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Kutadanta,\non the other hand, in thanking Buddha for his conversion gives an idea of the\nmagnitude of the slaughter of animals which took place at such sacrifices when\nhe says:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>\"I,\neven I betake myself to the venerable Gotama as my guide, to the Doctrine and\nthe Order. May the venerable One accept me as a disciple, as one who, from this\nday forth, as long as life endures, has taken him as his guide. And I myself,\nO, Gotama, will have the seven hundred bulls, and the seven hundred steers, and\nthe seven hundred heifers, and the seven hundred goats, and the seven hundred\nrams set free. To them I grant their life. Let them eat grass and drink fresh\nwater and may cool breezes waft around them.\"<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>In the\nSamyuta Nikaya (111,1-9) we have another description of a Yajna performed by\nPasenadi, king of Kosala. It is said that five hundred bulls, five hundred\ncalves and many heifers, goats and rams were led to the pillar to be\nsacrificed.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>With\nthis evidence no one can doubt that there was a time when Hindus, both Brahmins\nand non-Brahmins, ate not only flesh but also beef.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">[B. R.\nAmbedkar, \u2018Did the Hindus never eat beef?\u2019 in The Untouchables: Who Were They\nand Why They Became Untouchables? in Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Writings and\nSpeeches, vol. 7, (Government of Maharashtra, Bombay, 1990, first edition 1948)\npp. 323-328.]</span></i><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">AT\nEVERY DESH DROHI LITERARY FEST THEY DISCUSS HOW RISHI YANJAVALKYA ATE BEEF</span></b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: magenta;\">OUR\nDESH DROHI AND BENAMI MAIN STREAM MEDIA REGULARLY TELL ABOUT RISHI YAJNAVALKHYAs\nGREED FOR BEEF</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nSatapatha Brahmana gives a picture of the inordinate fondness of FAKE Yajnavalkya\nfor beef who said: \u201cI for one eat it, provided it is tender (amsala)\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In Taittiriya\nand the Pancavimsa Brahmanaswe the white invader injected POISON that sage\nAgastya slaughtered hundred bulls at a sacrifice. Sorry, our Yagnas were bloodless\nscarifices . &nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">GHEE was used.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/11/all-animal-sacrifices-in-hindu-temples.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/11/all-animal-sacrifices-in-hindu-temples.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader created FAKE sutras about maharishis eating beef.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">In FAKE Sankhyayana\u2013sutra a bull or a sterile\ncow should be killed in the house of the father of the bride on the wedding day\nand also in the house of the bridegroom when the husband and the wife arrive\nafter marriage.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader gave FAKE Yajnavalkya\u2019s passages about the need to offer BEEF on\nshraddh to dead ancestors to appease their souls.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\u201c at\nsraddhas or periodical oblations to the manes, the sacrifice of a bull or cow\nis recommended by the Apastamba and Paraskara grhyasutras.&nbsp; Yajnavalkya indicates how the aroma of beef\nwas thought to be an ailment for the spirits\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In the\nFAKE and poison injected Vasistha\u2013sutra \u201can ascetic who, invited to dine at a\nsacrifice . . . rejects meat shall go to hell for as many years as the\nslaughtered beast has hairs.\u201d <b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">There\nis NO hell in Hinduism\u2014sorry !<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader created FAKE Khadira and Gobhila\u2013Sutras where you cannot enter a\nnew home unless ou ate beef \u201c &nbsp;the\nsacrifice of a black cow to the deity of the dwelling-houses when a new house\nwas constructed\u201d <b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nwhite invader wrote that every Hindus home must offer a guest beef \u2013as part of\nour culture of ATHITHIDEVO BHAVAH and injected poison in Satapatha Brahmana and\nthe Aitareya Brahmana.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">BR\nAmbedkar wrote that Manu &nbsp;recommended the\nmadhuparka with beef for the reception of kings. &nbsp;He quoted the FAKE Yajnavalkya-smrti \u2013 \u201cmah-oksa\nor \u2018big bull\u2019 is to be slaughtered on such occasions\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In the\nFAKE \u2018Vanaparva\u2019 of the Mahabharata it is POISON injected \u201c cows killed in\nsacrifices to the accompaniment of Vedic mantras went to heaven and it narrates\nthe story of king Rantideva in whose sacrifices two thousand animals, including\ncows, were killed every day\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Here\nis another POISON injection \u2013 \u201c In the \u2018Udyogaparva\u2019 king Nahusha was cursed\nand hurled down from heaven by the great sage Agastya because he ventured to\ncast doubts on the Vedic injunctions for the sacrifice of cows and offered\ninsult to a Brahmana\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">In Uttararamacharita\nthe FAKE and non-existent Bhavabhuti wrote about how heartless Sri Rama kicked\nhis pregnant wife into the forest.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">At every literary fest they discuss\nBhavabhuti\u2019s FAKE story of Sita being banished by a jealous Rama<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Bhavabhuti\u2019s\nnarrative is full of ridiculous melodrama about Vishnu avatar Rama.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>QUOTE:&nbsp; Rama finds himself in Dandakaranya. Wandering\ninto Janasthana, he is assaulted by the memories of his once happy days there,\nspent in the company of his beloved Sita. His distress makes him cry out:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Alas!\nalas! my queen! My heart breaks, my limbs fall apart,<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>A fire\nconsumes me incessantly, the world seems empty.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>My\ndistressed soul sinks despondent into a blinding darkness,<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>And a\nstupor comes over me. Luckless as I am whatever shall I do?<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><i>Sita\nwho lives in the underworld with Ganga and Prithvi is in the forest too but she\nis invisible. She hears Rama cry out in pain. She sees him, pale and thin with\nthe smouldering agony within. He faints again and again when memories becomes\nunbearable. Sita rushes to him to restore him to consciousness with the touch\nof her hand. Rama senses her presence, recognises her dear and familiar touch.\nHe manages once to grasp her hand, ``beautiful like a pile of snow, soft like a\nfresh lavali sprout'', but is confused when he does not see her. He despairs\nthat his tortured mind is playing tricks on him. Sita fully realises that\nRama's love is hers forever. Her anger melts away and the thorn in her heart is\nremoved. She could now go back to him with honour and dignity. , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Skanda\nPurana III.ii.36.62 \u201c[Kumarapala said] O Brahmanas, I shall not abide and\nhonour the Royal Charter issued by Rama. I disown the Brahmanas who indulge in\nviolence and kill animals in Yajna. There is no question of my having any respect\nfor and devotion to these killers.\u201d <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Padma\nPurana II.37.32b-42 \u201c[The sinful one said] I shall tell you another fierce act\n(mentioned) in the Vedas. When a guest goes (ie. arrives) to the house, a\nbrahmana (kills and) cooks (the flesh of) a goat. (They kill) a horse in a\nhorse- sacrifice, and a bull in a bull sacrifice; a man in human sacrifice and\ngoats in a Vajapeya sacrifice. O great king, a great slaughter of many animals\nis done at a Rajasuya sacrifice. At a Pundarika sacrifice one would kill (i.e.\none kills) an elephant, and at an elephant sacrifice (they kill) an elephant.\nAt the Sautramani sacrifice a beast is seen to be fit for being sacrificed.\nThus, O prince, listen how at rites of various forms of killing of beasts of\nvarious species is laid down\u2026<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vishnu\nSmriti 51.64 When honoring a guest, at a sacrifice, or when worshipping the\nmanes, or the gods, a man may slay cattle, but not otherwise on any account<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">.POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Sankhayana\nGrihya Sutra 2.15.1-3 Should any one of the six persons (mentioned in the\nSrauta-sutra and in the Sutras 4-9) to whom the Arghya reception is due, visit\n(him), let him make (ready) a cow, a goat, or what (sort of food) he thinks\nmost like (thereto). Let the Argha not be without flesh. On the occasion of a\nsacrifice and of a wedding let (the guest) say, \u2018Make it (ready).\u2019<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Asvalayana\nGrihya Sutra 1.24.33 Let the Madhuparka ( food for guest )not be without flesh,\nwithout flesh. <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON </span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vishnu\nSmriti 51.61 It is for sacrifices that beasts have been created by the\nself-existent (Brahman) himself. Sacrificing causes the whole universe to\nprosper; therefore is the slaughter (of beasts) for a sacrifice no slaughter.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Yajnavalkya\nSmriti verse 177-8 Of the five toed animals, the porcupine the iguana-lizard,\nthe tortoise, the hedge-hog; and the hare; among fishes the Simhatundaka and\nthe Rohita. So also the pathina, the Rajiva, the sasalka may be eaten by the\ntwice born classes.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Yajnavalkya\nSmriti verse 258-59 (The Pitris are satisfied) verily for a moth with the\nhavisya (sacrificial food), but for a year with the milk rice, with the fish,\nwith the meat of gazelles, with mutton, with the flesh of birds, with the flesh\nof kids, with flesh of spotted deer. With the flesh of black antelope, with\nthat of Ruru deer, with the meat of boars, and with the meat of hares\nrespectively for a period progessively increasing by a month are satisfied when\noffered to the Grandfathers here.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Apastamba\nDharma Shastra, Prasna II, Patala 7, Khanda 16.3-4 At that (rite) the Manes (of\none\u2019s father, grandfather, and great-grand father) are the deities (to whom the\nsacrifice is offered). But the Br\u00e2hmanas, (who are fed,) represent the\n\u00c2havan\u00eeya-fire. That rite must be performed in each month [26] Beef satisfies\n(the Manes) for a year.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Apastamba\nDharma Shastra, Prasna II, Patala 7, Khanda 16.28. By this (permission of the\nuse of buffalo\u2019s meat) it has been declared that the meat of (other) tame and\nwild animals is fit to be offered.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Devi\nBhagwatam 1.18.48-61\u2026O King! One can see before one\u2019s eyes that the drinking of\nSoma rasa, the killing of animals, the eating of fish and flesh and so are\nadvised in the Vedas; so much so that in the sacrificial ceremony named\nSautr\u00e2mana the rule of drinking wine and many other vratas are clearly\nmentioned; even gambling is advised in the Vedas<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Devi\nBhagavatam 3.26.32-34 Those who eat meat, they can sacrifice animals in this\nworship of the Dev\u00ee; and, for this purpose, goat and wild boars are the best. O\nsinless one! The goats, etc., offered as a sacrifice before the Dev\u00ee attain to\nunending heavens. Therefore persons offering the sacrifices of goats do not\nincur any sin. O king! The goats, etc., and other beast offered as a sacrifice\nbefore the Devas undoubtedly go to the heavenly regions; therefore, in all the\nS\u2019\u00e2stras, it has been decided that this killing of animals in a sacrifice is\nconsidered as non-killing. <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vasistha\nDharma Shastra 14.15. For it is declared in the Veda, \u2018At a sacrificial session\n(sattra), which lasted one thousand years, Agastya went out to hunt. He had\nsacrificial cakes prepared with the meat of beasts and fowls good (to eat).\u2019 <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vishnu\nSmriti 51.65 That twice-born man who, knowing the exact truth (promulgated) in\nthe Veda, slays cattle for the sacrifices (ordained in the Veda) will convey\nhimself and the cattle (slain by him) to a blissful abode.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Gutama\nDharma Shastra 17.37-38 And (animals) that must be slain for (the fulfilment\nof) the sacred law. Let him eat (the flesh of animals) killed by beasts of\nprey, after having washed it, if no blemish is visible, and if it is declared\nto be fit for use by the word (of a Brahmana). I.e animals offered at Sraddhas\nand Srauta-sacrifices, though under other circumstances forbidden, may be eaten\nboth by the priests and other Brahmanas.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vishnu\nSmriti 51.67 That slaughter which is in accordance with the precepts of the\nVeda, and has been fixed for this world of movable and immovable creatures,\nshould be considered as no slaughter at all; because it is from the Veda that\nlaw shines forth.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Markandeya\nPurana 32.2-5; Matsya Purana 17-31-36 The Pitris are satisfied with clarified\nbutter and rice for a month. The paternal grandfathers receive satisfaction\nwith fish meat for two months. Venison should be known to satisfy the pitris\nfor three months; and the flesh of hares nourishes the pitris for four months;\nbird\u2019s flesh satisfies them for five months; hog\u2019s flesh for six months; goat\u2019s\nflesh for seven months; and flesh of the black antelope for eight months; flesh\nof the ruru deer gives them satisfication for nine months, without doubt; flesh\nof gayal gives satisfaction for ten months.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Apastamba\nDharma Shastra, Prasna II, Patala 7, Khanda 17.1-3 (If) rhinoceros\u2019 meat (is\ngiven to Brahmanas seated) on (seats covered with) the skin of a rhinoceros,\n(the Manes are satisfied) for a very long time. (The same effect is obtained)\nby (offering the) flesh (of the fish called) Satabali, And by (offering the)\nmeat of the (crane called) <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vishnu\nPurana 2.16 AURVA continued.\u2013\u201cAncestors are satisfied for a month with\nofferings of rice or other grain, with clarified butter, with fish, or the\nflesh of the hare, of birds, of the hog, the goat, the antelope, the deer, the\ngayal, or the sheep, or with the milk of the cow, and its products. They are\nfor ever satisfied with flesh (in general), and with that of the long-eared\nwhite goat in particular. The flesh of the rhinoceros, the K\u00e1la\u015b\u00e1ka potherb,\nand honey, are also especial sources of satisfaction to those worshipped at\nancestral ceremonies.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 1.162.12 They who observing that the Horse is ready call out and say, the\nsmell is good; remove it; And, craving meat, await the distribution, -may their\napproving help promote labour<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 1.162.13 The trial-fork of the flesh-cooking caldron, the vessels out of\nwhich the broth is sprinkled, The warming-pots, the covers of the dishes,\nhooks, carving-boards,-all these attend the Charger.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 1.162.18 The axe penetrates the thirty-four ribs of the swift horse : the\nbeloved of the gods, (the immolators), cut up (the horse) with skill.. <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 10.91.14-15 He [Agni/Fire] in whom horses, bulls, oxen, and barren cows,\nand rams, when duly set apart, are offered up,- To Agni, Soma-sprinkled,\ndrinker of sweet juice, Disposer, with my heart I bring a fair hymn forth. Into\nthy [Agni\u2019s] mouth is poured the offering, Agni, as Soma into cup, oil into\nladle\u2026 <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 1.162.19 Of Tvastar\u2019s Charger there is one dissector,-this is the\ncustom-two there are who guide him. Such of his limbs as I divide in order,\nthese, amid the balls [of meat], in fire I offer.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rig\nVeda 4.18.13 In deep distress I cooked a dog\u2019s intestines.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> POISON </span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\u201dAnd\nby rules of Veda guided slew the horse of noble breed, Placed Draupadi, Queen\nof yajna, by the slain and lifeless steed\u2026\u201d <b><span style=\"color: red;\">ASHWAMEDHA YAGNA <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span></span></b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Yajur\nVeda 5.4.12.1&nbsp; It is the twenty onefold\nday, on which the horse is slain, there are twelve months, five seasons; these\nworlds are three<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Yajur\nVeda 2.5.5.3-4 On the full moon (the Soma) is pressed for the gods; during this\nhalf-month it is pressed forth for them, and a cow for Mitra and Varuna is to\nbe slaughtered for them at the new moon. In that he sacrifices on the day\nbefore\u2026In that he sacrifices at the new moon with clotted curds for Mitra and\nVaruna, the cow which is slaughtered for the gods becomes his also. <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ramayana,\nAyodhya Kanda 2.20.29 \u201dI shall live in a solitary forest like a sage for\nfourteen years, leaving off meat and living with roots, fruits and\nhoney.\u201d<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ramayana\nAyodhya Kanda 2.96.1-2 \u201cHaving shown Mandakini River in that manner to Seetha,\nthe daughter of Mithila, Rama set on the hill-side in order to gratify her\nappetite with a piece of flesh. Rama, whose mind was devoted to righteousness\nstayed there with Seetha, saying; \u201cThis meat is fresh, this is savoury and\nroasted in the fire.\u201d <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ramayana\n3.47.22b-23 \u201cBe comfortable for a moment, here it is possible for you to make a\nsojourn, and soon my husband will be coming on taking plentiful forest produce,\nand on killing stags, mongooses, wild boars he fetches meat, aplenty.\u201d <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Satapatha\nBrahmana 11.2.5.1. And, verily, even on this occasion, they slaughter the\nsacrificial horse (Asvamedha) as a sacrifice to the gods\u2026<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Satapatha\nBrahmana 13:2:1:1-2 Prag\u00e2pati assigned the sacrifices to the gods; the\nAsvamedha he kept for himself. The gods said to him, \u2018Surely, this\u2013to wit, the\nAsvamedha\u2013is a sacrifice: let us have a share in that also.\u2019<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Satapatha\nBrahmana 11:2:5:5 Verily, then, for him who, knowing this, offers both the\nAgnihotra and the Full and New-moon sacrifices, they slaughter the sacrificial\nhorse month by month; and month by month the Asvamedha is offered for him, and\nhis Agnihotra and Full and New-moon sacrifices come to pass into the Asvamedha.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Brihadaranyaka\nUpanishad 6.4.18 And if a man wishes that a learned son should be born to him,\nfamous, a public man, a popular speaker, that he should know all the Vedas, and\nthat he should live to his full age, then, after having prepared boiled rice\nwith meat and butter, they should both eat, being fit to have offspring. The\nmeat should be of a young or of an old bull.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Maitrayana\nBrahmaya 6.36 \u2026 Therefore (to the former) sacrifice must be offered on the\nhouse-altar with hymns, herbs, ghee, meat, cakes, sthalipaka, and other things;\nto the latter, with meat and drinks (belonging to the great sacrifices) thrown\ninto the mouth, for the mouth is the Ahavaniya-fire; and this is done to\nincrease our bodily vigour, to gain the world of purity, and for the sake of\nimmortality.<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ramayan\n1.14.33-38 With great delight coming on her Queen Kausalya reverently made\ncircumambulations to the horse, and symbolically killed the horse with three\nknives. Queen Kausalya desiring the results of ritual disconcertedly resided\none night with that horse that flew away like a bird\u2026Then the priest, one with\ncontrolled senses and rich in scriptural wealth, took up the omentum [fat] of\nthe horse and cooked it as per scriptures while dropping into the altar of fire\nto bake as a food to the celestials\u2026Those remaining body parts that horse are\nthere, the sixteen officiating priests have procedurally oblated all of them\ninto fire. <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Brahma\nPurana 137 \u201dAfter performing these tasks Rama thee most excellent among the\nvirtuous performed ten horse-sacrifices where flesh was offered to the\ndeities.\u201d <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">POISON</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%;\"><b>SORRY--\nASHWAMEDHA IS A BLOODLESS &nbsp;YAGNA\u2014IT IS A \u201cVOTE\nOF CONFIDENCE\u201d<o:p></o:p></b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot;
